transcript: Hello friends!
I am Dr. Ritu Sharma.
I am faculty at National Law University, Delhi.
We are here as a part of MOOCs programme, you must have gone through the various modules
on MOOCs and other subjects.
Today also, we are going to talk about, as a part of MOOCs programme, we are going to
talk about reliability and validity, which is a very important concept of research methodology.
You will be needing this concept again and again in all types of research that you carry out.
So, while understanding the concept of reliability and validity, we will be talking about the
meaning and definitions of reliability and validity.
We will also be discussing about the types of reliability, we will understand how to
reach the reliability of qualitative datas.
And then we will go onto the discussing the concept of validity and what relationship
does reliability has with validity.
So, when we talk about the concept of reliability, in simple term, the concept of reliability
means the extent to which a measurement procedure gives the same results however and whenever
it is carried out.
Validity is the con… extent to which it gives the correct results.
So there is a, they are very famous scholars named Kirk and Miller.
They are given a beautiful example of physical world.
For example, a thermometer shows the same reading of eighty two degree celsius every
time we plugged in, in a boiling water.
It is obviously a reliable thermometer.
But a thermometer that gives different reading near about hundred Celsius each time it is
placed in boiling water may not be reliable, but it is certainly quite valid.
So in other words, validity refers to the true or exact value of a finding.
Any research that wants to be called as objective has to be both reliable as well as valid.
So according to Oxford Dictionary, when we talk about reliability, reliability is the
degree to which the results of a measurement, calculation or specification can be dependent
on the accurate on to be accurate.
So, one can clearly say that reliability is about consistency, and a research would be
reliable if when repeated using the same method, it brings about the same results.
A researcher need to be, need to establish the usefulness of the data he or she gathered
to ensure that whe… whether the conclusion reached are representative enough to be applicable
to everyone and is it possible to repeat the research if others want to carry it out?
And if they do, will they get the similar results?
So these questions can only be answered by researchers with the help of reliability and validity.
So reliability of data becomes important because if we do not have reliable data, the conclusion
reached on their basis will be quite useless.
So, to have a better understanding of the concept of reliability, there are two things
which we need to understand.
They are consistency and precisions.
As it is important to obtain consistency, similar response to the same question in similar
circumstances and one has to know how systematic is the form of data that is based on asking
people questions about things that they know little about.
So, another typical feature which is very important with regard to reliability is repeatability.
That is, if anyone wants to carry out the same research as has been carried out by another
researcher, would he get the same results as the result of the researcher who carried
out the research first?
If this happens, then the research of the first researcher would have repeatedly of
the data collected method.
So, there are four general estimators that researcher may encounter.
One, observer reliability, that is the degree to which different observer gives consistent answer.
Second, test-retest reliability, the consistency of a measure evaluated over time.
Third, parallel-form reliability, the the reliability of two tests constructed the same
way from the same content.
And finally, internal consistency reliability, the consistency of results across items, often
measured with Cronbach’s Alpha, a statistical tool used as an estimate of the reliability
of a psychometric test.
So we will talk about the types of reliability, Kirk and Miller have discussed three types
of reliability which will help a researcher to understand how reliable is his data.
So they are as follows- One, quixotic reliability, this refers to the circumstances in which
a single method of observation yields the same measurement over and over again.
In other words, when a researcher ask questions, respondents respondents tend to give politically correct answers.
For example, if the subjects are asked questions like if they believe in giving equal rights
to their daughters in property, most of the respondents give response in affirmation but
the reality is something else.
This is called that the findings have only quixotic reliability because people tend to
give those answers that they think are correct.
To get a correct view, one can ask the respondent if he would mind sharing his property with
his sister or do you mind if your wife give away her rights in her parent’s property?
Such questions can give a better and a clear picture.
The second type of reliability is diachronic reliability.
This refers to the stability of an observation over time.
Some examples include the test-retest paradigm of experimental psychology and survey research,
in which survey are conducted afresh after a gap of time to see if the results are the same.
And then, the third part is called a synchronic reliability.
This refers to the similarities of observation withi… within the same time period, which
can be evaluated by comparison of the same data by different methods.
Unlike quixotic reliability, synchronic reliability involves observation that are consistent in nature.
In the words of Kirk and Miller, synchronic reliability is often more useful if it is absent.
In other words, if different methods or approaches to a problem throw up different results, it
may caution the researcher to consider the other aspects of research, which he she has ignored earlier.
A researcher should try to work towards increasing the reliability of data.
He can achieve this by documenting his field notes so that they can be compared with the
other field researcher and other colleagues.
Berman recommends extensive, explicit and perceptive field notes, self-analytical repo…
reporting of research procedure, and research context, documentation of the ethnographer’s
theories of society and his biases.
To make your field notes accessible to others, certain guidelines must be followed that enables
others to separate the concept of the observed from those of the observer.
So, the other method of achieving reliability can be by training the researcher before he
or she enters the field and by checking his interview notes regularly and guiding him
or her accordingly.
This should be done immediately after the first interview so that correct measures are
taken at the earliest.
Thus, we can say that reliability is achieved by presenting the data in such a way that
the results speak not only about the interpretation given by the researcher, but also the voice of the respondents.
Apart from the results, the procedure adopted by the researcher should also be taken into account.
Now, we have discussed about reliability.
We come to the next topic which is very close to reliability is called validity.
What is this Validity?
Validity refers to the accuracy of the data generated by the research instrument like
an interview schedule or questionnaire or some other means of research.
Validity answers questions like whether the method adopted by the researcher affects the
results of the factors that should have been considered but were ignored.
These answers refer to the internal validity of a researcher.
Validity of a research is also about answering the question, how valid is one’s conception of the situation?
How generalised are one’s results?
So, answer of these que… answer to these questions refer to the external validity of
your research, which can be explained as the generalised from the, from a sample to a population.
Establishing external validity for an instrument then follows directly from sampling.
There is also a face validity and the content validity.
Face validity means stati… statistical measure of validity.
For example, type one error will will require rejection of the hypothesis when it is true
and type two error will require acceptance of the hypothesis when it is false.
This the concept of hypothesis is linked here.
So, if you have to understand the concept of hypothesis, you can go back to my module
on hypothesis and discuss that validity part there.
So, content validity on the other hand refers to the appropriateness of the content of an instrument.
In other words, do the measure that is questions or observation logs, etcetera, accurately
assess what you want to know?
This is particularly important with the achievement test.
Consider that a test developer wants to maximise the validity of a unit test for seventh grade mathematics.
This would involve taking representa… representative questions from each of the sections of the
unit and evaluating them against the desired outcomes.
So, that will be called as content validity.
It is easy to achieve validity in research as one has to keep in mind the adequate sampling,
precision of observation and the subtle changes in environment and people are observed carefully.
One can say that the concept of validity refers to the next extent to which the data provide
a true measurement of social reality.
Let us take an example from IGNOU material on research methodology of shortage of power supply.
You may be quite sure of the statistics about power shortage week by week.
You also have to be sure how valid or accurate a picture of power shortage in the whole town
or the state is, your static… statistics presence.
If you were to compare your figure with those collected by government agencies, its figure
may be re… reliable, but the government’s definition of power shortage may not be the
same as is used in your research.
So and if this is the case, then the two set of statistics are not valid for the purpose
of comparison because the comparison is not between two things alike and therefore, research is not valid.
How do we achieve validity in our research?
So this is the question that we have to answer.
To bring about validity in the research process, Wolcott has suggested some guidelines.
They are, one should refrain from talking.
When you are in the field, listen as much as possible.
Secondly, produce field notes that are exact as as much as possible.
Begin to write early so that you will not forget the little details that separate good
research from the ordinary research.
Write in such a way that your research can see for themselves the points you are trying to bring out.
In other words, provide enough data to enable readers to draw out their own inferences and
follow the ones you are making.
Your report should be as complete as possible.
See feedback on your findings and presentation from your colleagues.
Your presentation should be characterised by a balance between the various aspects you
have studied rather than leaning too heavily on one or the other aspect.
Your presentation should display accuracy in writing.
To check the validity of your research, one of the method is field research.
The very nature of field work is its flexibility and openness, which enables one to study the
data in a variety of ways.
As in field situation, routine contact with people on day-to-day basis over an extended
period of time will help the researcher to test the emerging hypothesis.
This method is very sensitive to discrepancies between meaning presumed by investigations
and those understood by the target population.
So one has to clearly define his or her concept.
Defining the concept is also very important for the researcher as the field is better
known to respondent than to the researcher.
In a controlled experiment, the situation is other way around.
But here the researcher has to work according to the respondent’s will.
If the researcher is sincere and devoted to his field work and is receptive of the inputs
given by the respondents, then his or her research has greater chances of being valid.
The validity can also be checked by taking respondents into the confidence and try try
to involve them into research by the method of discussion.
The researcher can share his or her data with the respondents and while discussing can ensure
that there is no discrepancy in what the respondent said and what he or she has written.
This method of checking also has its own drawback, as sometimes respondents may deny of what
the researcher has written as they might feel that it shows them in bad light.
Here the role of the researcher becomes important as he or she has to differ… differentiate
between the real responses and the released responses.
Lincoln and Guba in their book, Naturalistic Inquiry suggests that for checking the validity
of any data, a researcher should adopt few techniques while collecting the data and interacting
with the respondent.
The researcher should spend more time in the field, which will help the researcher to understand
his field and respondents better.
Spending more time in the field will also help in the accuracy of the data as the researcher
will be having a clear picture of the field and it is less likely that the respondent
is able to deceive the researcher.
Now, when we have discussed the concept of reliability and validity, let us also understand
try to understand the relationship these two concepts have.
So reliability and validity are two different concepts that may or may not be related to one another.
Mostly, if data are valid, they must be reliable.
If people rec… receive very different scores on a test every time they take it, the test
is not likely to be to predict anything.
However, a test can be considered reliable but not valid.
For example, AILET or CLAT score can be used as a prediction of success in college.
It may be considered a reliable test, but only a moderately valid indicator of success.
Taking the same example of CLAT or AILET scores can, we can say that validity is more important
than reliability, as in college admission, AILET or CLAT score may be a reliable test,
but not necessarily valid measure of other qualitative qualities college seeks, for example,
leadership participation in various academic and cultural activities.
So, we can say this is reliable but not a valid measurement.
The combination of the these aspects alongside the AILET or CLAT score is more valid measure
of the applicant’s potential of, for graduation, later social involvement, and professional development.
Last and the most important is the data should be both reliable as well as valid.
Proponent of AILET and CLAT argue that it is both a reliable as well as valid test as
it measures student’s knowledge and aptitude, mathematics, language and reasoning.
So to understand the relationship between reliability and validity, we can conceptualise
them under four heads, that is Reliability and Validity, when the data is consistent
and also measures what it meant to measure, that is, a stable construct.
In that case, a data will be reliable as well as valid.
In the second condition, when the data is reliable that is, there is a consistency in
the data but not valid.
That means, it measures something consistently but it does not measure what it is meant to measure.
Third, the data is unreliable, that it is not consistent, but and not valid.
That is it is inconsistent measures which does not measure what it meant to measure.
Finally, data is unreliable that is it is not consistent and valid that it measures
what it means to measure.
So, here unreliable data but it is measuring what it means to measure, that is, an unstable construct.
A very important aspect with reliability and validity is how to measure the two.
So, while measuring reliability there are few methods that we have to keep in mind.
One of them is stability or test-retest method.
That means, it gives the same assessment twice separated by days, weeks or months.
Reliability is stated as the correlation between scores at time one and time two.
And this is how we can measure the reliability.
The other way of measuring reliability is alternate form.
It creates two forms of the same tests that vary the items slightly.
Reliability is stated as correlation between score of test one and test two.
The last way of measuring reliability is the internal consistency method.
This is also known as Alpha method.
It compares one half of the test to the other half or use methods such as Kuder-Richardson
Formula twenty, that is KR twenty or Cronbach’s Alpha.
The value for reliability coefficient range from zero to one.
A coefficient of zero means no reliability and one means perfect reliability.
Since all tests have some error, reliability coefficient never reaches one.
Generally, if the reliability of a standardised test is above point zero eight, it is said
to have very good reliability.
If it is below point five zero, it would not be considered a reliable test.
As we have measured reliability, there is a method of measuring validity as well.
Validity refers to the accuracy of an assessment whether or not it measures what it is supposed to measure.
Even if a test is reliable, it may not provide a valid measure.
Let us imagine a bathroom scale that consistently tells you that you weigh one thirty pounds.
Reliability of the scale is very good, but it is not accurate because you actually weigh
one forty five pound and you reset the scale in a weak moment.
Some teachers, parents and school districts make decision about students based on assessments
such as grades, promotion and graduation.
The validity inferred from the assessment is essential, even more crucial than the reliability.
Also, if a test is valid, it is almost always reliable.
There are three ways in which validity can be measured in order to have confidence that
a test is valid and therefore the inference we make based on the test scores are valid.
All three kinds of validity evidence should be considered.
To measure a content validity.
What is the content validity?
The extent to which the content of the test matches the instructional objective.
Example for this would be a semester or a quarter exam that only includes content converted
during the last six weeks is not a valid measure of the course’s overall objective.
It has a very low content validity.
Criteria validity, it means the extent to which scores on the test are in
agreement with concurrent validity or predict that is, predictive validity and external criteria .
If the end of the year math test in fourth grade correlate highly with the statewide
math test, they would have high concurrent validity.
Construct validity is the extent to which an assessment correspond to other variables
as predicted by some rational or theory.
If you can correctly hypothesize and ESOL students will perform differently on a reading
test than English speaking student, because of theory, the assessment may have construct validity.
This is how you can measure the validity and reliability of any test.
Reliability and Validity are two important concepts for any research.
And it is important for the researcher to understand the relationship as well as the
distinction between the two.
It helps a researcher to have a better understanding of his or her results and make his or her
research more authentic.
Reliability and validity are independent of each other.
A measurement may be valid, but not reliable or reliable, but not valid.
So, both qualitative as quantitative research requires reliability and validity.
Thus a researcher should keep in mind that for a research data to be use and value, it
should be both reliable as well as valid.
So this gives us a concluding remark on reliability and validity.
Hope this discussion is useful for you in conducting your research.
And in case you have any queries, you can always email me or you have questions you
can always post it to me.
Thank you so much.
Dear students, I am Doctor Manish Singh.
I am from Doctor Ram Manohar Lohiya National Law University, Lucknow.
The probable learning outcomes of this module are to make you understand the contemporary
debate surrounding the qualitative and doctrinal methods of research.
To make you understand the meaning and concept of qualitative research.
To let you understand the meaning and concept of doctrinal method of research.
To encapsulate the methods of conducting doctrinal and qualitative research.
To discuss the broad aims and objectives of qualitative and doctrinal methods of research.
It abso… it also helps you to comprehend the advantages and limitations of qualitative
and doctrinal method of research.
To also help you understand the distinguishing factors between qualitative and doctrinal
method of research.
and doctrinal methods of conducting research.
What is doctrinal legal research?
Doctrinal method.
What is qualitative research?
Common elements in every qualitative research and the distinguishing factors.
Aims and objectives of qualitative and doctrinal methods of research.
Basic tools of qualitative and doctrinal research.
Advantages and limitations of qualitative and doctrinal methods of research and finally,
the summary of what we have learned so far.
A brief short a brief short introduction to qualitative or doctrinal research debate
would be fit to locate both of them and analyse them with respect to their positives and shortcomings.
Bryman had identified some eleven ways to integrate these two types of researches.
According to Bryman, the logic of triangulation means to check, for examples of qualitative
against doctrinal research.
The qualitative research outcome can support doctrinal method and vice-versa.
Both are combined in to provide a more general pictures of the issue under study.
Structural features are analysed with doctrinal methods and processual aspects with qualitative approaches.
The perspective of the researcher derives the quantitative approaches, while qualitative
research emphasises the viewpoint of the subjective.
According to Bryman, the problem of generality can be solved for qualitative research by
adding doctrinal findings, whereas qualitative findings may facilitate the interpretation
of relationship between variables in datasets.
The relationship between micro and macro levels in a substantial area can be clarified by
combining the two researches which can be appropriate in different stages of the research process.
Finally, there are hybrid forms that use qualitative research and quasi experimental designs.
The doctrinal legal research can be defined as research into legal doctrines, through
analysis of a statutory provisions and cases by the application of reasoning.
The emphasis upon analysis of legal rules, principles or doctrines as compared to non-doctrinal
legal research, which aims at research on relationship of law with society, groups, and people.
It involves an empirical inquiry into the operation of law, how the doctrine or principle
which has been adopted in real-world settings.
Thus, the doctrinal legal research emphasise upon research in law focusing.
Thus, the doctrinal legal research emphasise upon the research in law, force focusing on
the black letters of the law.
The non-doctrinal research focuses on research about law.
Here the researcher is interested in knowing about the law inaction.
The former can be understood as amateur research, or basic or fundamental research, the latter
is empirical research.
It begins, the doctrinal method begins by taking up a proposition as a starting point of focus.
He then locates the law and statutes, judicial pronouncements and discussions and commentaries,
textbooks, journals and debates.
Reads them in a holistic manner, analyse them and write his findings.
For example, a research on proposition of prevention against double jeopardy under criminal
law would begin with locating the law in constitution and criminal law materials.
On the basis of the analysis of the same, the researcher may advance the set of formulations
or may also highlight the objective behind the proposition and may propose what it ought to be.
On the other hand, qualitative research developed as an alternative to quantitative research,
it has grown from simply not being quantitative research.
It has gained multiple dimensions now, which can be understood from the general understanding
that this research focuses at the real-world in order to understand, describe, and explain
social phenomena from the inside in multiple ways.
It is done by analyzing experiences of individuals or groups, by analysing directions and communications
or by analysing documents.
However, the common element is that it seeks to identify how people view the world, what
they are doing or what is happening to them in terms which are meaningful and offer rich insights.
There are certain common elements in every qualitative research.
They are that every qualitative research is it methodological, theoretical, epistemological,
has certain common elements, which can be broadly identified as below.
Experiences, interactions, and documents are analysed in the natural context.
Concepts and hypothesis are developed and refined in the process of research.
It is starts from the idea that theory and method should be appropriate to what is studied.
They can be adapted if they do not fit in.
Researchers themselves are also an important part of the research process, either due to
their own personal experiences or research experiences.
It takes cases and context seriously.
A major part is dependent on text and documents, thus issues of transcribing complex social
situations into texts is one of the major concerns of qualitative research.
Experiences, interactions and documents are analysed in the natural context.
Concepts and hypothesis are developed and refined in the process of research.
It starts from the idea that theory and method should be appropriate to what is studied.
They can be adapted if they do not fit in.
Researchers themselves are also an important part of the research process, either due to
their own personal experiences, or research experiences.
It takes cases and context seriously.
A major part is dependent on text and documents, thus issues of transcribing complex social
situation into texts is one of the major concern of qualitative research.
There are certain distinguishing factors between qualitative and doctrinal methods.
The qualitative legal research is different from doctrinal legal search on many grounds,
some of them are – It lays down a different emphasis upon legal doctrines and concepts,
while the emphasis of doctrinal is purely basic and fundamental in exposing the law as it exists.
The latter look it from the perspective of social reality.
Qualitative research seeks to answer broader issues as clear from the aims and objectives
as would be discussed below.
The doctrinal research has a focus on a particular point of law.
It does not focuses exclusively on case reports, and other traditional primary and secondary
legal documents for analysis.
However, it is dependent on doctrinal methods in the sense that without a thorough grasp
on fundamentals, the qualitative researcher would not be able to chart his voyage in a
meaningful manner.
It takes a different route for research wis… which has in focus to analyse law in action,
as distinguished from law in books.
The qualitative and doctrinal methods have different aim objectives.
While the former is about finding, analysing the legal concepts and doctrines like for
example, the principle of a strict liability under law of torts.
The latter is concerned with law in action, that is, as to analyse the legal idealism
from the lens of social reality.
Each has its own utility and uniqueness and are interdependent on each other.
To discuss the aims and objectives of doctrinal research – Doctrinal research helps to find
the law in the legal statutes, subordinates legislations and judicial precedents.
It aims at consistency and certainty of law, to some extent it looks into the purpose and
policy of law that exists.
Doctrinal research also aims to study legal institutions like courts, police machinery,
jail, tribunals, etcetera.
Discussing the aims and objectives of qualitative research – A qualitative research focuses
on the social facets of the law.
Its primary aim is to determine through empirical data, how law and legal institutions affect
or mould human attitudes and what is their impact on the society they create.
The researcher primary looks into, How far the law and legal institutions are serving
the needs of the society?
Are they suited in the social context in which they operate?
It determines the forces that shape reshapes and mould the law.
It is helpful in analysing how far the law has been enforced and administered.
It discusses the causes for the factors responsible for the poor performance of the law.
It also look into the factors which moulds the enforcement machinery attitudes and behaviour
while interpreting enforcing the law.
Are beneficiaries under the law using it or the law is merely symbolic?
Whether the targeted beneficiaries are benefiting out of the law?
If the law is failing to help people, where does the problem lie?
Impact of law on behaviour and attitude of society, people in groups are also determined
by this method.
Every research has its own specific tools and methods.
Research instruments are the tools in the hands of the researcher to conduct the research.
Proper tools ensure a well-planned and systematic inquiry.
The researcher shall aim at developing procedures which are reliable and valid.
By being reliable it is meant that there is consistency of a measure, while being valid
means to which the measure achieves it aims.
They can be classified into primary and secondary sources.
Let us have a look into the tools of these two types of researchers.
First, we shall discuss the basic tools of qualitative research.
There are several ways of collecting data for qualitative research.
The primary sources are interview, questionnaire, schedule, interview guide and observation.
It can be collected from either posing selected respondents to a set of predetermined questions
or sketchy questions.
It involves a face-to-face conversation and this tool of data collection is known as interviewing.
The predetermined questions can also be mailed, send by post, fax, or other ways in order
to gather responses from selected respondents.
This tool of data collection is known as data collection by way of questionnaires.
The researcher can also collect data by the method of observation.
The secondary sources are the published or unpublished reports, for example, crime reports.
The secondary sources are the published or unpublished reports, for example, crime records,
report of international organisation, etcetera.
A general understanding of tools like interview, questionnaire, schedule, interview guide and
observation would be useful.
Interview is a verbal technique of data collection.
It may be structured or unstructured.
It is a structured when the researcher uses a set of predetermined questions and highly
standardised technique of recording the responses.
It is unstructured when there is flexibility in the approach to the questioning and much
lesser standardisation.
It is unstructured when there is flexibility in the approach to the questioning and much
lesser standardised way of recording the responses.
The strength of this tool is that it remains to be the most effective method of gaining
information about respondent’s perception and opinions.
It also enables the researcher to authenticate the information coming from the respondents
by observing the body language or respondent.
However, administering and interview is an art.
One needs to have the one needs to have the required skillset in order to conduct
a meaningful interview.
Undoubtedly being most effective, it has its limitations, like memory bias, inability of
the respondents to provide every information asked for and bias.
Questionnaire – In questionnaire, a number of typed or printed predetermined questions
are used for collecting data, it is sent to the respondents with the request to send it
back to the researcher after filing the responses.
It may also be structured or unstructured.
The questions may be open-ended, close-ended, mixed or pictorial.
The method can be very effective in circumstances where the respondents are scattered in a vast area.
It is queaper…
It is quicker and cheaper as compared to interviews.
Schedule is more or less same as the questionnaire.
But the major differences are that schedule is referred to form filled in by the
interviewer during his personal interview with the respondents and questionnaire, being
impersonal is rigid.
The schedule is flexible, because it gives the opportunity to the researcher to calify…
the, to clarify the questions, if they are not clear to the respondents.
Interview guide – It contains only the topics of broad headings upon which the respondents
are asked to answer.
Usually, the questions are formulated on the spot and the responses are thereby recorded.
Observation is a visual method of data collection.
It is another specific way of data collection, it is another scientific way of data collection
when planned in a systematic manner and recorded systematically and is subject to check and
control on validity and reliability.
There are certain basic tools of doctrinal research, statutory materials, subordinate
legal materials, and case laws constitute the primary sources.
While the secondary sources the researcher refers to are the textbooks, legal articles,
parliamentary debates, etcetera.
For example, if someone has to undertake a study on the principles of compulsory licencing
under the law of patents, then the relevant provisions of the Patents Act nineteen seventy
international instruments pertaining to compulsory licencing, law on compulsory licencing in
different jurisdictions, findings of the court and intellectual property appellate board
like in the Matter of Application for Compulsory Licence by Natco corporation income advisor, one
constitutes primary sources.
While the commentaries on the provision pertain to compulsory licence, in a standard textbooks,
commentaries, articles and law journals, news reports, blogs, etcetera, would constitute second resources.
So, what are the advantages of doctrinal method?
Doctrinal method provides quick answers to the practical problem at hand by analysing
the legal principles, concepts and doctrines, thereby serving as a ready reference to people
who didn’t have a time at the disposal to understand that research by themselves.
Because comparatively speaking, a doctrinal research requires less time.
So thereby, it ensures the constant stream of information on a regular basis.
Doctrinal method gives insights into the evolution and development of the law, for example, consumer protection law.
It offers a logical explanation to the law and at the same time also highlights inconsistencies
and uncertainties in the law.
It reveals gaps, ambiguities, and inconsistencies in the law.
Thus, informs us as to how law can be more purposive and effective.
It lay down a roadmap to develop the law for avoiding the pitfalls.
It helps in increasing the legal knowledge base.
Future direction of the law can be predicted on the basis of such studies.
It provides a sound basis of non-doctrinal research, because in deficit of the required
preliminary knowledge, the venture of non-doctrinal research would be directionless and therefore
futile, but there are certain limitations of doctrinal method.
The first limitation is that it can be subjective and suffer from the voice of perception of
the researcher about the required subject matter.
Therefore, another person can reach upon an entirely different dimension to the same question.
Further, it is devoid of any support from social facts.
Therefore, his projection might be far off the social reality.
This is a serious concern, as law can act as an instrument of social transformation.
It neglects the factors that lie outside the strict brackets of law, which might have a
bearing upon the legal principle, theory or doctrine.
For example, the recent amendment in the criminal law regarding rape, were in a huge public
outcry was a extra legal factor that shaped the law.
The actual practice and attitudes of people who are the functionaries and those who implement
the law is also not taken into account.
For example, the attitude of judges, lawyers, police,
administrative authorities, courts
and tribunals, etcetera.The qualitative research has following merits.
It highlights the gaps between goals and social reality.
It depicts a true picture of law in action.
It highlights the gaps in relation to practice of law, enforcement agencies and as well as
in the use and underuse of the law by the beneficiaries of the law.
It highlights the reasons behind failure of a law in real-world.
It may be inactiveness or lack of willingness on the part of those entrusted with the task
of enforcing the law or maybe resistance on the part of intended beneficiaries for multifarious
time and money.
It thus exposes the weakness in the operation of law.
In the modern welfare state law acts as a tool of social and economic transformation.
The qualitative research can bring forward the role and contribution of law in bringing
about desired changes.
It also can highlight the gaps that have been left in the law and social reality so that
law can be reassessed in the light of new information.
It serves as a significant resource in the form of a social feedback to policy framers,
It shapes social legislations in tune with the social enduring doctrine of the modern state.
But there are certain limitations of qualitative research also.
Qualitative research is extremely time consuming and also very costly.
The researcher in this research has to build upon the bedrock of doctrinal research.
He must be true with the doctrines and concepts, otherwise his research and endeavour would be futile.
The primary tools of data collection, namely interviews, questionnaires and observation
requires a specialised skill set right from the stage of planning to the execution.
Now, let us recapitulate what we have learned so far.
From the above analysis, it can be understood that qualitative research arose primarily
as a critique of doctrinal research.
It was felt that the research outcomes were inadequate and incomplete in absence of an
analysis done in real-world settings.
Nevertheless, both research methods had their own merits and shortcomings.
But it can safely be concluded that both informs the law and policy and are interdependent on each other.
Thank you.

For understanding the concept of research, it is necessary to understand this concept

After applying seeking that knowledge, he applies that knowledge and try to resolve

Whether his problem will be solved or not, it depends.

This whole process may be called as non-research action and non-research action is always other

There is a difference between non-research action and research process.

If the results are not reliable, and applying those results in, to satisfy any problem of

On the contrarily, research process is a scientific process of searching knowledge.

research.
And any such data which has been obtained by pursuing the scientific process, its results

And any such reliable and valid conclusion can be used in the stock of knowledge, can

After dis… discussing about the concept in its ordinary way.
Now, it is necessary to understand the concept with its technical sense.
In technical sense, we can say that research is the composition of two terms, one is re
and second one is search.
Re is the Latin term means again, afresh and repeated investigation.
Search means to find out something by looking or otherwise seeking.
Here these two terms are itself suggesting the whole process, means to find out something
by directly observing the phenomena or by any other sources or methods, this is the
research.
after selec… selecting any research problem researcher moves to solve that problem.

He try to gather all such relevant information facts relating to his problem and after analyzing

The research process includes some major questions like what, what to search?
Why to search?
And, how to search?
The term ‘what’ it denotes the object of research.
‘Why’ denoting the purposes thereof and third ‘how’ stands for the methods used
for the research.
used for data collection, data analysis and interpretation thereof.
It is necessary to make it clear and distinguish between two terms which are usually and repeatedly
used with every research that is the objectives of research and purpose of research.
Objective of research and purpose of research are not the same.
Objectives have different working and purposes have different results.
quality of research or philosophy or the principle of research.

Who would be the beneficiary of the res… results, how that research conclusion, research

Object and purpose are somewhere relating terms, are not independent having nectious

This relation of the object and purpose of research have been shown by one example and

Object of A, B and C are the same, whereas they have their individual purpose.

That means, we can better understand that there is a relation between objective of research

Any research topic undertaken by the researcher at the same time, at different times may have

he may be interested to work for any funding agencies.
Here the object of research is the same but the purposes of the research may different

On the basis of different objectives, the research can be classified as inventive research,
exploratory research, explanatory research, diagnostic research, remedial research, comparative
research, experimental research and at last historical research.
All these explanations, classifications of research are illustrative one or not conclusive.
The first category or what we can say, the first kind of research on the basis of its
objective to invent something that is called inventive research.
inta…
Inventive research is the process by which the researcher wants to search any theory
is not existed earlier.
This method is based on the pure science and personal skills of the researcher.
analysis.
And any such knowledge which is not exist earlier, he try to collect that knowledge
at the primary stage and on the basis of that knowledge he develop or built his theory.
And by that, by applying that theory he innovates any material product or thing.
Example of inventive research is articles, instruments, machineries or devices.
After inventive research, the second research that is the exploratory research.
Object of exploratory resea… research is to explore any unknown fact, though the fact
already exists somewhere in this world.
But the society is not aware as to the existence of that fact.
The focus of researcher is to explore those facts and to present those facts before the
society.
In this research no preliminary data exists for assisting the researcher or to guide him
to proceed with his objective.
Mysterious facts, those facts which are dis… difficult to explain are searched and interpreted
and shown before the society by this exploration method.
After exploratory research, another kind of research is explanatory research.
Object of this kind of research is the explanation of knowledge.
Any knowledge, any fact which exist in the society and society and group of peoples are
already know or aware with the existence of fact.
The focus of researcher is to give the true explanation of the facts by which he can correct
the social perception towards that concept of life.
Because this is very necessary or what we can say this is matter of social development
if the society at large is misleaded, mispleaded or having misconception towards the truth…
truthiness of any fact.
This is the moral duty of the researcher to work on that particular social issue and explain
and make the society aware with the reality.
After explanatory research, another is diagnostic research, where any problem exist in the society.
Peoples are affected by that problem, but they have no knowledge how to resolve that
problem, where the causes or the variables of such problem which causing the existence
of problem, subsistence of problem are not known by this researcher.
This research, researcher exercise to find out causes or variables responsible for origin,
existence and subsistence of problem, and finally he diagnose the causes of any problem.
This is also called the causal research.
After causal research, another important research is remedial research, where the causes of
any problem are already known to the society.
But, how to cope up that problem, that is the question.
Causes of problem have already identified, how to prevent or control such problem is
a question.
By this research, researcher try to investigate those facts or variables which can be useful
for controlling or eradication of such social problem.
After remedial prob, research, another research is comparative research.
Object of this research is the comparison of two or more groups, phenomena, society,
policy, instrument, principles or theories.
Here the research, researcher makes the comparison between two or more set of principles, theories
or groups.
And after analyzing them, he comes with the conclusion that which particular theory or
model is beneficial to achieve any defined objective.
The next research is experimental research.
In experimental research, effects of variable is observed by controlling and manipulating
the variables.
Here the researcher has control over the variables used in the research and he try to study the
effects of their manipulation or their reaction with the other variable.
the hypothesis.
Testing of variables is also called the laboratory research.
Experimental researches are rarely used in legal research.
Historical research is another kind of research having its own distinct objective, and this
is very important kind of research.
By past events, researcher try to explain the present phenomena, present condition and
it can also be beneficial for the future decisions.
In this research, researcher collects the scattered recorded facts and analyze them
and summarize to give a valid statement as to the past events.
After this classification of research on the basis of objectives, come with the research
process.
Research process contain three major steps.
First part that is the collection of data, second, analysis of data and third one is
the interpretation of data.
In all these three stages, the researcher required the skill, analytical methods to,
for collection, analysis and interpretation of data.
With this process, the researcher interest with the re… research is to know about their
importance.
Importance of research can be explained in the words of Juris Hudson said that all progress
is born of enquiry.
Doubt is often better than overconfidence, for it leads to enquiry, and enquiry leads
to investigation.
Research progress somewhere beneficial for future actions or decisions.
Where the person is aware about the reality, truthiness of the facts and the phenomena
he can take the best decision as to his life.
that is there is no shortcut to the earth, there is no shortcut to the truth, no way
to gain knowledge of the universe, except through the gateway of scientific method.
He has advocated the use of scientific methods, scientific investigation to know the reality.
For the law scholars after understanding the basics of research, it is necessary to explain
about the nature of legal research.
Le…
Legal research is the subject related to the social science approach because law is the
normative science, law cannot be studied independently.
Law is an instrument to control the social behavior, social ordering, that is why the
legal research has to be studied in the life, light of social phenomena, but the characteristic
of legal research is distinct from other streams of social science because of its distinct
authoritative sources of knowledge.
Basic sources of knowledge are the legislation, precedent and customs.
Society is a dynamic concept, so law cannot be static.
That is why the legal research is very important for the social development and social utility.
Objective of legal research can be explained in following points – finding out the objectives
of existing law and customs, to check their utility in changing social demands, to find
out the lacuna if any exist and to take the necessary steps to overcome such problem,
to find out the possibilities of prevention and control of social evils by enactment and
changing technologies affecting individual rights, social order and legislative provisions,
their implementation, enforcement and infringement.
Comparison of two or more legislations resulting conflict is also a common object of legal
research.
To discover new facts, test and verify old facts, analyze the facts in new technol, theoretical
framework can be the objective of legal research.
There are some specific procedural models and method which are commonly used in legal
research.
These are evolutive, explicative, identificatory, collative, impact analysis and interactive
model.
prohibition and control is suggested by the legal research.

where the objective of research is to ascertain the nature, scope and sources of any law,

And there after any conclusion may be drawn as to the real nature of law, objectives and

searching those persons, beneficiaries of any law, legislative schemes or provision

If any law has been enacted with certain objective and there its objective is denoting that certain

The purpose of researcher is to check this thing whether this legislation is actually
serving the stated objectives or not.
Or is there any other person behind the curtain, who is the beneficiary of these provisions
and schemes.
Next is projective model – projective model is used to find out the attitude, responsiveness
and reactivity of the society towards particular piece of legislation.
Invitation of public opinion before introducing any new legislation or amending existing one,
so that difficulties arise in implementation of policy can overcome.
any legislative action.
Next is collative model – The collative model makes the comparison between two existing
law, provisions of law, models of law.
Its objective is to compare two rules to find out which one is more workable and by which
the desired effect may be achieved.
Next is impact analysis.
By the term itself you can understand that impact ana… analysis process is focused
to find out the impact of any rule, legislative principle, provisions on society.
Here the impact of legal principles, rules and institution on society are studied.
For necessary changes can be made for improvement, these are the objective of impact analysis.
After impact analysis, another model is interactive model.
Study the involvement of some other factors while interaction of legal provision with
the society.
During the interaction of law with the social phenomena, other factors variables, which
are interacted their role, their nature and effects are studied.
The focus of researcher in this model is to find out the evidences showing the interaction
of certain variables, their nature and effects on the law and society.

Research is a systematic process of investigating unknown facts or explanation of existing facts

Hello everyone, as we have reached to the fag end of Research Methodology course, today
we are going to discuss a very important topic called Drawing Conclusion.
As you all know I am Doctor Ritu Sharma and I have been dealing with Research Methodology
modules and today we are going to discuss how to draw conclusion, because that is the
most important part of the research.
So, in this module you will learn that to understand the role of conclusion and what
role does it play in research.
And then it will also, we will also discuss the importance of a good conclusion and we
will explain the structure of a good conclusion and finally we will examine the problem that
we need to avoid while writing a conclusion.
And we will also see various steps that we can use in the process of drawing conclusion.
So, drawing conclusion, as I told you is one of the most important activities in research
as it gives the final critical reflection of the research conducted.
The conclusion plays an important role as it determines the success or failure of a research.
Whether we conduct a doctrinal or empirical research, it is the final conclusion that
makes research a success.
If we, if the result of the research is satisfying and the experimentation is excellent but conclusion
is weak, then the result of the research will not be appreciated.
Thus, drawing conclusion plays a very important role.
A conclusion helps the reader in understanding the research conducted and how it will be helpful to them.
It also helps in paving the way for future research.
It is just not a summary, but also gives key point to the research.
The conclusion of a research has three important points.
One, it gives an ending to your project and highlights what a research result means.
Second, it helps the researcher in explaining how his or her research contributes to the new knowledge.
Third, it gives an impression of the work done by the researcher.
Now, when we talk about this introduction, we should also know that what is the importance
of a good conclusion and here we are going to quote David Bunton who has pointed out
the importance of a good conclusion.
He says that a well written conclusion provides you with important opportunity to de… demonstrate
to the reader your understanding of the research problem.
And these include, first, presenting the last word on the issue you raised in your paper.
So, just as the introduction gives the first impression to your reader, the conclusion
offers a chance to leave a lasting impression.
Do this, for example, by highlighting key points in your analysis for results or by
pointing important or unexpected implications applied or practiced.
Second, summarising your thoughts and conveying the larger significance of your study.
The conclusion is an opportunity to succinctly answer the question, “so what?” by placing
the study within the context of the past research about the topic you have investigated.
Then, it identifies how a gap in the literature has been addressed.
This is a third point.
The conclusion can be where you describe how a previous identified gap in the literature
described the, in your literature review has been filled by your research.
So, it actually fil, fulfils the gap which is already there in the research.
So, when you are concluding, you give a kind of idea to the person that till now in literature
this was the gap and my research is actually fulfilling that gap.
Then the fourth point is dem… it demonstrates the importance of your ideas.
Now, in conclusion, when you are writing a conclusion you...you should not be shy.
It should offer you the opportunity to elaborate on the impact and significance of your findings.
So, your idea also plays a very important role when you are actually writing a conclusion.
Then, introducing possible new or expanded ways of thinking about the research problem.
Once you have conducted your research, once you have got the result, you are writing a
conclusion and this writing of conclusion does not refer to introducing new information,
because it should be avoided but to offer a new insight and creative approach for framing
or contextualizing the research problem based on the result of your study, because by coming
to a conclusion you have already seen the various aspects of the research, and when
you are actually observing the various aspects, you also know that where a new field can also
be opened after your research, right?
So, then it will, as a result it will be introducing new or expanded ways of thinking about the research problem.
Now, as we have understood what is the significance of a good conclusion, we should also understand
what should be a structure of a good conclusion.
Joseph Assan has discussed the structure and the writing style of the conclusion.
He says while writing a conclusion, a researcher should follow some points.
For example, first, it should state the conclusion very clearly, very sim… in a very simple
language and it should state how the findings differ or support those of the others and why
It should not simply reiterate your results, or the discussions of your results, it should
provide a synthesis of arguments presented in the paper to show how all these coverge
to address the research problems and the overall objective of your study.
So, it should indicate opportunities for future research if you haven’t already done so
in the discussion section of your paper.
And finally, it should highlight the need for future research, which provides the reader
with evidence that you have an in depth awareness of the research problem.
He further says that the function of your paper’s conclusion is to restate the main argument.
It reminds the reader of the strength of your main arguments and reiterates the most important
evidence supporting those arguments.
So, do this by stating clearly the content, background, and necessity of pursuing the
research problem, you investigated in relation to the issue, controversy, or a gap found
in the literature.
Make sure, however, that your conclusion is not simply a repetitive summary of the findings.
This reduces the impact of the arguments you have developed in your study.
According to him, a researcher should consider the following points to help ensure that his
conclusion is appropriate.
One, if the argument or purpose of your paper is complex, you may need to summarise the
argument for your reader.
Second, if prior to your conclusion, you have not yet explained the significance of your
findings or if you are proceeding inductively use the end of your paper to describe your
main points and explain their significance.
Move from a detailed to a general level of consideration that actually we have already
discussed that there should be a inductive method.
So, what does it mean?
It means that move from a detailed to a general level of consideration that returns to the
topic, to the context provided by the introduction or within a new context that emerges from the data.
Leora and Jerry in their chapter on conclusion describe these strategies on how to develop
a compelling conclusion.
And these strategies are, if your essay deals with the contemporary problem, warn the reader
of the possible consequences of not attending to the problem.
Then, recommend a specific course or courses of action that if adopted shou..., could address
a specific problem in practice or in the development of a new knowledge.
Cite relevant quotation or expert opinion already noted in your paper in order to lend
authority to the conclusion you have reached, a good place to work is research from your
literature review.
Then, explain the consequences of your research in a way that elicit actions or demonstrate
urgency in seeking change.
Then, relate a key statistic, fact, or visual image to emphasize the ultimate point of the paper.
If your discipline encourages personal reflection, illustrate your conclusion pointing with the
relevant narrative drawn from your own life experience.
Return to anecdote, an example, or a quotation that you presented in your introduction, but
add further insight derived from the findings of your study.
Use your interpretation of results to recast it is in new way.
Provide a “take-home” message in the form of a strong, succinct statement you want the
readers to remember about your research.
Then, there are some points that you should keep in mind to avoid while you are writing a conclusion.
The research guide of the University of Southern California mentions about the points we need
to keep in mind and problems to avoid while writing conclusion.
According to them, a researcher usually makes the following mistakes while writing a conclusion.
One, a conclusion should be concise, it should be concise and to the point and should not
have unnecessary information in it.
The researcher’s emphasis should be on implications and evaluation rather than on methodological details
Secondly, focus should be on significant issues, because the job of the researcher is to use
deduction method, the introduction and the induction method, the conclusion.
In other words, a researcher should place his or her research in the larger context
by focusing on the contribution it has made in the research field.
Then, do not ignore the negative results.
A researcher should definitely talk about the problems and challenges encountered by
him or her as it will make his or her research rich.
The challenges faced by the researcher will pave way for the future research and this
will be a success for a researcher.
Then he, he or she should provide a clear summary of the research.
The summarisation that is done in the conclusion should be very clear, or in other words a
summary should always be succunt.
Conclusion should match your objectives.
When you are starting your research, you always highlight the objective.
Remember that your conclusion should match your objective.
A conclusion should always reflect on the researcher’s achievement of his objective.
Then, it shou..., it shows if the researcher has accomplished what he intended to accomplish
in his, in his or her research.
It actually shows that if the researcher has accomplished what he intended to accomplish
in his or her research.
If there is anything, if there is any discrepancy then the researcher should document the re…
reasons and try to use it as a data in the research and if possible should try to go
back and refine the original objectives.
Then, finally, conclusion should reflect researcher’s confidence about his or her research.
A researcher whe..., a researcher when conducts a research he has a thorough understanding
of his research than anyone else.
So, he should take advantage of this fact and should try to reflect that confidence
and understanding of the research in his conclusion.
Now, as we have understood what is a good conclusion, how to write con, a good conclusion,
what should be avoided while writing a con..., good conclusion, let’s focus on how a good,
how a good conclusion is drawn.
So, Shuttleworth has described few points in highlighting, or in explaining how to draw a conclusion.
He sums up the whole thing in a very succintly manner and he says that the researcher can
draw the conclusion in one or, in these five points.
One, what he has learnt?
First thing is his conclusion should focus that what he has learnt in his research.
The researcher will summarize what they have learnt from the research, and their findings
of the research.
Doing so he or she should try to assess strength of the hypothesis.
For example, in a research if a null hypothesis is acceptable, the researcher can analyse
why the results were not as per the predictions in his or her conclusion.
This will make his or her conclusion very strong.
The researcher, the researches where there is no hypothesis like the onal research, the
researcher will analyse the findings and will try to establish if any valuable information
is not covered.
Aspects for the future research.
The one, When you are drawing conclusion it should have aspects for the future research,
because all researches leads to new research.
A good conclusion should deal with the aspects of the future research.
All researches lead to new research.
Most of the researches uncovers the new questions, and researchers can use these to suggest new
directions for the future study.
If the hypothesis is accepted, the research results are as predicted by the researcher,
and if a hypothesis is not accepted, it paves way for the future research.
Then, one should evaluate the flaws in the research.
The researcher should try to analyse the problems that occur during the experiment.
First of all, he or she should try to analyse the errors in the research design that can
influence the results in any manner.
All experiments suffer some or the other kind of weakness error.
The researcher should able to justify the methodology and should try to give reasoning
for the errors that have occurred in the experiment.
Shuttleworth explains this with a beautiful example.
He says that while drawing conclusion the researcher may think that another variable
influence the results and this variable was not eliminated during the experiment process.
A refined version of the experiment may help to achieve better results, if the new effect
is included in the design process.
So, giving example of global warming he says that, “in the global warming example the
researcher might establish that, Carbon Dioxide   emission alone cannot be responsible for global warming.
They may decide that another effect is contributing, so purpose is that methane may also be a factor in global warming.
A new study would incorporate methane into the model.”
This argument also supports our previous point that deals with the new aspects for the future research.
Then, a conclusion should also talk about the benefits of the research.
Once the researcher has evaluated the flaws, the researcher he, he or she should evaluate
the advantage and benefits of the research.
In explaining this point, Shuttleworth gives an example from the medicine and psychology
field and says that, “in medicine and psychology the result may throw out a new way of treating
a medical problem, so the advantages are obvious.
However, all well-constructed research is used, even if it is just adding to the fount
of the human knowledge.”
Suggestions based on the conclusions are very important.
The last stage and one of the most important stage is the recommendation stage, which is
based upon the results of researcher’s field study.
Researcher could make suggestions for refinement or, of the experimental design or highlight
the interesting areas for the further study.
This final piece of the researcher’s paper is the most critical and pulls together all
the findings and as stated earlier it will pave way for the new research.
So, the this is the most important part.
Then finally, when you are summarising in a conclusion.
The strength of the result is summarising.
The most important part about drawing conclusion is to check if the method and methodology
used correctly, is used correctly in the research.
This also calls for following of the steps of scientific research and design correctly.
If the research design is strong, then the focus would be conclusion rat… rather than the method.
Shuttleworth explained the above points and make it very easy for a researcher to draw

So, while drawing conclusion a researcher must try to check all the following points.
One, first of all the researcher should check if he has answered the ‘so what’ question

A researcher need to provide a convincing explanation of his research, which is loud,

So, in this module we have actually explained how do we draw conclusion.

an impression of his or her research.
The conclusion of the research not only summarises the researcher’s thought, but explain the
