Now, why do we need a research proposal?
In order to address the major questions and issues of everyday social life, the researcher
may well need to conduct empirical work of some description.
However, such research pro… work is not an isolated activity.
It is a social activity that has potential repercussions for others, whether that be
the people or the organization or the culture that we are studying or the people that we
work with as student or employee or community group members.
For instance, a project idea that aims to investigate work place harassment needs to
consider all sorts of matter that one might not initially consider to be part of the research process.
Such matters might include the potentiality trau… traumatising impact on respondents
who might themselves have been victims of bullying, but have lived with this in enforced silence.
Or perhaps as a consequence of the research revealing endemic yet hidden workplace bullying,
the employing organisation may find itself the target of a law suit, by failing to provide
adequate duty of care of employees.
Whether you are a student intending to commence with the masters or doctoral research program
or a project leader applying for func… funding, support your research idea will need to be
assessed by others and you will need to present a convincing case in the form of a research proposal.
All researchers should therefore be able to prepare a proposal for a research topic a professional standard.
Being able to produce such a proposal is an important skill.
Intending doctoral students are required to prepare such a proposal when applying for
studentship and seeking formal registration for their project.
The research proposal is the means by which we are able to demonstrate that we are ab…
what we are able to do.
As such, it allows us to spell out what exactly is the research problem that we are retai…
intending to investigate.
Why this is worthy of investigation and how we intend to carry out the research?
In putting such a proposal together, we shall not only need to demonstrate a knowledge of
the area in which we are interested, but also we require to show that we have the necessary
methodological competence and sensitivity to carry out the research.
Now, what is a research proposal?
The research proposal is an application that is prepared by a student or a university academician
or professional researcher for support prior to embarking upon a research study.
At one level the objectives of a research propo… proposal may be seen as providing
a statement about the purpose of the research, how it is to be carried out, the resource
implication of the proposed investigation as well as the timescales for completion.
At another level, however, the research proposal is an argument.
Through the document, you are presenting a case, in which the intention is to convince
others of the general merits and feasibility of the proposed study.
The research proposal should therefore aim to convey three key aspects of an intended research project.
First, its objective and scholarly significance.
Second, your technical qualifications.
Third, the level of funding required.
Now, how to draft a research proposal?
Prior to the da… drafting of a research proposal, the nature of the research design
is to be selected should be set out.
Whether one is intending to adopt a broadly qualitative research design or a strategy
that is largely quantitative in nature is likely to affect the shape and the format
of the research proposal.
Of course, those charged with the reviewing proposal would have very clear expectation
that certain content will be included in the proposal regardless of the intended research strategy.
However, some elements of a quantitative research proposal will not be included in a qualitative
research proposal and vice versa.
Furthermore, quantitative research proposals are likely to be more uniform than those designed
for broadly qualitative based studies.
As Punch in his book on Introduction to Social Research- Qualitative and Qualitative Approaches
say that- It is easier in many respect to suggest proposal guidelines for a quantitative
study, since there is a greater variety in qualitative studies and many qualitative studies
will be unfolding rather than pre-structured.
An emerging study cannot be a specific in the proposal about its research question or
about details of the design.
When this is the case, the points need to be made in the proposal.
In the remainder of this chapter the core elements of a research proposal will be rew…
reviewed where appropriate, the specific aspects that are necessary for drafting either a qualitative
or quantitative research.
Now, let’s consider, ‘Is there a formula for writing successful research proposal?’
A research proposal, then is a written plan for a study.
It spells out detail what the researcher intend to do.
It permits others to learn about the intended research and to offer suggest for improving the study.
It helps the researcher to clarify what needs to be done and aims to avoid unintentional
pitfall or unknown problems.
Module is intended to serve as a general framework, not a definite set of instructions.
The only general rule that must always be adhered to is that the research proposal should
be both succinct and complete.
Other than that each university research committee or external funding agency will have its own
expectation about the actual format of the research proposal, and some will be more explicit
than the others in this respect.
Research proposal often vary significantly in terms of length.
In some cases application forms that prescribe precisely what is wanted and will need to be completed.
In other the researcher will have more latitude to decide upon the format of the project.
However, the onus will be on the researcher to bend to meet the requirement of the university
review committee or external funding agency.
However the onus will be on the researcher to bend to meet the requirement of the university
review committee or external funding agency.
Finally, it is important to avoid using a discursive essay-like style, instead, you
should make plentiful use of headings and bullet points.
If it is necessary to use references in any background or literature review section or
ins… for instance the Harvard style is to be preferred.
Pay full attention to appearance and to use user friendliness.
Let’s now sketch a outline of the proposed research.
In the absence of any forms of guidelines, there are general themes that you might use
to structure your own research proposal, whether this is a postgraduate dissertation or an
application for external research funding.
However, what follows are elements of a proposal - You do not need to have each as a particular heading.
First one will the title page.
A title page should include each of the following, one, your name, the title of the proposed
project, any collaboration agency that have been involved in the preparation of the proposal,
the date of submission and if applicable, and the funding agency to which you are applying for support.
Then you will be giving a abstract.
Abstract is very important is very important because the abstract is the brief synopsis
of the planed research investigation.
It appears at the front of the proposal, but it is usually the last element to be written.
It should include two keys areas – The major objective of the proposed study, and the procedure
and general methodological strategy that are to be used in order to meet these objectives.
The abstract should be approximately one page or less in length.
The abstract is an important strategic element of the proposal, and therefore, should be
afforded considerable att… attention in the drafting of your proposal.
It serves three keys interlinked purposes- The reviewer should, usually reads it before
the fully proposal to gain a perspective of the study and of its expected significance.
The reviewer uses it as a reference to the nature of the study if the project comes up for discussion.
It will sometime be the only part of the proposal that it ee… that is read when making preliminary
selection of applicants proposals.
Now, research problems to be investigated.
Another, next, next point is, the what type of research problem is to be investigated?
There are usually four areas to be addressed in the section of the research proposal.
The purpose of the study, a justification for the project, the specific research question
that you intend to explore, and a definition of any key terms and concept that you will examine.
However, you will write only one section.
This must contain all these four aspects, you will not deal with each other under a separate heading.
Now, what is the purpose of the study that is also part of your project writing?
You will need to state what the research purpose to investigate.
The purpose should be concise statement, providing a framework to which details are laid.
Generally speaking any study should seek to clarify some aspect of the field of the interest
that is considered important, thereby, contributing both to the overall knowledge in the field
and to current practice.
The researcher must make clear, why this particular study is important to investigate?
That is the reason it it needs some kind of justification.
You must present an argument for the work of the study.
This will usually form a substantial section of your research proposal and will require
you to provide evidence that you have a, you have conducted a detailed literature review
in the area, in order to demonstrate to the reader that you have , you have studied the
field with insight and are therefore, well qualified to undertake the research.
Then, identify what is already known and by implication what is yet unknown – and therefore,
worthy of empirical study.
Key questions to ask yourself at this point are- Have I identified the specific research
problem that I wish to investigate?
Have I indicated what intend to do about this problem?
Have I put forward an argument so as to why this problem is worthy of investigation?
And have I based argument on a review and examination of key literature in the area?
Now, the research question.
A very important aspect of research proposal is having research question.
The particular research question that you intend to examine should be stated next.
These are usually but not always, a more specific form of the problem in question form.
For quantitative researchers, research hypotheses will be set out at this stage for reasons
of clarity and as a research strategy.
If a researcher has a hypothesis in mind, it should be stated as clearly and as concisely as possible.
It is unnecessarily frustrating for a reader to have to in… infer what a study hypotheses
or hypotheses might be.
For qualitative researchers especially those adopting an emergent research design, the
actual research question and hypotheses will not become clear until the research has begun.
Typically, these begin to take shape in the course of data collection and analysis.
As Punch ha… notes that- If a tightly structured qualitative study is planned, the proposal
can proceed along similar lines to the quantitative proposal.
Now, it a more emergent study is planned, where focus and structure will develop as the study proceeds.
This points should be made in the research proposal.
In the former case, there will be general and specific question.
In the latter case, there will only be general orienting and guiding research questions.
The researcher, research questions are often drafted as aims and objectives.
These are the means by which what is to be attempted and what is to be accomplished are specified.
The aims and the objectives should immediately follow your review of the existing literature
serving as a bridge between what has previously been investigated and what still needs to
be studied through your propos… proposed research.
They therefore, serve as a crucial part of the justification of your research proposal
and we suggest that you consider setting them out as a series of bullet points in order
to give them emphasis and to direct the reviewer’s attention to them.
Aims of the research proposal.
The aim is statement of intent.
It indicates the overall purpose and thrust of the research.
It is also a statement of the main association and relationship that you seek to discover or establish.
In any proposed project, the aim should be small in number.
Setting yourself too many aims indicates that you are probably embarking on more than one project.
Example might include- To determine whether or not lecturing is the most beneficial and
preferred teaching strategy in the higher education.
And to explore how health and safety legislation is applied in hospitals and to evaluate which
values tend to demonstrate management practices.
To investigate the effects of alcoholism on the family.
Notice now, how one…
none of these aim is directly answerable.
These aims will be answered by accumulating and integrating answers to a series of objectives that you set.
So, let’s understand the objectives of in a research proposal.
The objectives are specific action statements.
They can be perceived as stepping stones that eventually directs the study towards the more
comprehensive statement, stated aims.
They express in detail and in a more technical way than the aims.
What is the research intended to achieve?
It may be it may be to explore, to identify, to describe, to explain, to understand, to
discover, to predict, to measure, to evaluate, to establish, to assess, to ascertain, to
determine or simply to find out.
So, a key question to ask yourself when drafting your objective is- Is it clear which data
are required to address in each objective?
An example taken from Kumar’s book on Research Methodology- A step by step guide for beginners
provides objectives for the aim listed above concealing the study of alcoholism in the family.
The project objectives are- To ascertain the impact of alcoholism on martial relationship.
Then to determine the ways in which alcoholism affect the different aspects of children’s lives.
And then to find out the effects of alcoholism on the financial situation of the family.
So, such objectives help to define the scope of the study.
As Kumar asserts, they should be worded in such a way that the wording clearly, completely
and specifically communicates your intentions.
There is no place for ambiguity, non-specificity or incompleteness.
Either in the wording of your objective or the ideas they communicate.
Now, we have understood the objectives.
Some key question you should ask yourself when you are for… for framing the objectives.
Do the aims and the objectives adequately encapsulate the lull scope of the proposed project?
Does or do the aims clearly indicate the overarching thrust of the intended study?
Or the objectives sufficiently precise so that they indicate clearly what is to be done
in order to collect the data necessary to address the research aims?
Are the, are there logical connections between the aims and the objectives?
Or do I have any hypothesis in mind?
If so have I expressed them clearly and appropriately?
And then do I intent to investigate a relationship between difference phenomena or variable?
If so, have I indicated the variable that I think may be related?
The next stage for the development of research proposal is the review of literature.
It was noted earlier that in order to gain support for a proposal project, the researcher
will need to conduct a review of the literature.
In a research proposal the literature review is a partial summary of the previous work
related to the focus of the study.
You will need to de… demonstrate to a review committee that you are familiar with the major
trends in previous research as well as opinions on the topic and that you understand their
relevance to your planned study.
The major weakness of the many literature review is that people cite references without
indicating either their relevance or their implication for the planned study.
Within any research proposal, a literature review is design to serve the twin purpose
of explaining and justifying the decisions made about the nature of the research question,
and also the methodological strategy to be adopted.
The writer’s task is to employ the literature review artfully to support and explain the
choices made for the study, not to educate the reader concerning the state of science
in the problem area.
This is a very important point.
Many people are tempted to reference every study, every article, and every book that
they have read.
For the purpose of setting out to impress the proposal reviewer that they are experts
in the field with a comprehensive knowledge and understanding of everything written in the area.
And of course, you need to review the literature related to your research question in order
for instance to identify a research gap that will serve as a stimulus for your study.
However, the space available for you to develop this is in your research proposal will be limited.
You will therefore need to be concise in your review and refer only that work that is to,
that is of direct relevance to your research question.
The writer should set out the major concepts in an organised and lo… logical order and
then support these reference from the literature.
Remember the literature review for a research proposal is somewhat different from that which
you would do, use in a dissertation or a thesis.
It is quite obvious, more modest in scale and breadth.
It is not the place to review body of literature that bears on a problematic area or even the
place to examine all the researches that relates to the specific question raised in the proposal.
Cormack in his book ‘The Research Process in Nursing’ provides a useful overview of
the three key uses of literature review.
It will provide you with a wide range of documentary information on facts, opinion, and comments
concerning the topic o… to be investigated, help you do to discover whether the topic
has already been studied, and if so, to what extent your work will be affected, and it
helps you to decide, which research technique will be most appropriate for your study.
In the early stages, the literature review will consume much of your time and energy.
However, it should be regarded as a continuous process, with new information added as the project proceed.
You should take a structural approach to your literature search.
Ask yourself, what information are you after?
If you are going to use words searches of electronic bibliographic sources or the internet,
you should list all the possible keywords and synonyms that you consider to be relevant
for you research question.
You should also be clear about which timescale you intend to cover in your project and what
the geographic boundaries are that you intend to work within.
Finally, you should be flexible about the range of material that you consider for your
literature review, especially, if your initial searching fails to uncover a sufficient body
of literature for your study.
Key questions to ask yourself at this point are- Have I surveyed the described relevant
studies that are related to my research problem?
Have I surveyed existing expert opinion on the problem?
Have I summarised the existing state of opinion and research on the problem?
The next pra… it is methodology to be used for conducting the research.
The methodology section should include a discussion of your intended research design.
The sample you will examine, the instrument to be used to conduct the investigation, procedural
details of collecting your empirical evidences, and the data analysis techniques to be used.
This, this section should be carefully justified by linking it to the aims and objectives of
the proposed study.
In empirical research, it is necessary that data be linked to concepts and concepts be
linked to data and thus, the links between concepts and data be tight, logical and consistent.
Well developed and well-stated research question indicate what data will be necessary to answer it.
If the research question do not give clear indication of the data and needed to answer
them, we will not know how to proceed in the research, when it comes to the data collection
and analysis stage.
Punch in his book, ‘Introduction to Social Research, Qualitative and Quantitative Approaches’
say that you develop your research question, ask for que… each question, what data are
needed to answer these questions?
With these words Punch lucidly summarises one of the dis… decisive aspect upon which
a research proposal will be judged – the empirical criteria.
When deciding on the research design for your proposed project, you must ensure that it
carefully addresses all of your aims and objectives.
As, reviews, reviewers will need to be reassured that you will be able to answer all the research
questions that you have set yourself in your proposed research investigation.
A useful way of establishing this is to link your aims and objective with the proposed
approach and methods.
Let's now discuss the concept of research design.
The particular research design to be used should be identified as well as how it applies
to the present study.
You, therefore need to ensure that choice of approach is justified in this section.
Typically the basic design is fairly clear-cut and fits one of the following models, either
the comparative or the experimental or the cross-se… cross-sectional design or longitudinal
research design, case study design, action research design, evaluation research design,
all these research designs have been dealt in the earlier module as you have seen that.
Now, we come to the next step which is very important is the sampling method.
In your proposal you should indicate in considerable detail, how you will include participant,
the sample for investigation in your study.
You should indicate what the size of the sample will be?
How members will be selected, and what claims you may legitimi… legitimately make about
the representativeness of your sample.
For a quantitative research study you should aim if all, if at all possible to adopt a
random sampling technique or if this is unrealistic a quota sampling method should be used in
an attempt to maximize representativeness.
However, for small scale projects of the type likely to be undertaken by postgraduate students,
where you study may will be subject to various resources constraint.
It may be legitimate to use another less rigorous sampling methods such as convenience samples.
It is more important to complete a project with an unrepresentative sample then abandon
the study, because it fails to achieve a sample must be used, relevant demographics like gender,
ethnicity, occupation, age, housing, and any other relevant characteristics of the sample
should be described.
The legitimate population to which the results of the study may be generalized should be indicated.
For emergent qualitative research design, you are likely to use theoretical sampling
to select research participant.
Where this is the case, you are much more likely to include respondent whose presence
is designed to maximize theoretical development than to achieve representativeness.
Your reason for choosing this sample strategy should be indicated and justified within the
section of one research proposal together with an acknowledgement that the sample has
been chosen to generate insight as opposed to definite conclusion about your research
areas, and the results will be indicated rather than representative of the views of the wider population.
For a further discussion of this point, let’s see the module on sam… sampling technique,
which has already been dealt earlier The key question that are to be asked during this
point is- Have I described my sampling plan?
Have I described the relevant characteristics at my sample in detail?
If you are using a predominantly quan… quantitative research design, have I identified the population
to which the results of the study may legitimately be generalised?
If you are using a predominantly qualitative research design, have I demonstrated that
my selection at cases is reasonable typically at what might be expected if I had conducted
my research elsewhere?
And now, once you have collected the sample, what instruments to be used?
Whenever possible existing research instruments should be used in your studies since, construction
of ee… even of the most straightforward test or questionnaire for selection of questions
is often very time consuming and difficult.
Furthermore, doing so will enable you to make comparison between you finding and results
from the earlier study from which the research instrument was borrowed.
However, you cannot justify using an existing research instrument if it is not an appropriate
for your purpose.
Even though it may be more convenient, you will therefore need to assess whether existing
instruments are suited to your needs.
In the, in the event that appropriate instruments are not available, the procedure to be followed
in developing your own research instruments to be used in the study should be described
with attention to how validity and reliability will be addressed here.
It will be important to indicate within your proposal that you intend to build a pilot
stage into your project or if the research instrument has already been tested for this
purpose, include a version of these appendices. For example, if you are conducting a survey,
you should include a specimen questionnaire or some questions that you consider to be
good illustration of what you will ask.
For a more qualitative research design, you might include and observation se… schedule
or a topic guide for in-depth interview.
Key questions to ask yourself at this point are- Is the research design fit for purpose
and does it meet the empirical criterion?
That is, will it yield all the data necessary to answer each of the aims and objective?
Secondly, have I described the instruments to be used?
Thirdly, have I indicated the relevance to the present study?
Then, have I stated, how I will check the reliability and validity off my data collectively instruments?
And finally, have I built a pilot, a piloting the instrument stage into the research design?
Now, procedure and data collection.
Outline the proposed method of research, this should be presented in sufficient detail for
the reader to know whether the project is realistic, feasible and worthwhile.
You will need to describe how you intend to access your target group and con… contact
your research participant.
Is your target group one that is typically difficult to involve in research studies of your kind?
If so, what steps will you take to maximize your response rates and minimise bias?
What method of data collection will you be using?
For instance, if your proposed study involves the use of a questionnaire, you should indicate
whether you intend to use a self-completion version or implement it in a face to face
situation or via the telephone.
It is important to make your procedure of data collection clear, so that if another
researcher wants to repeat the study in exactly the same way as in the original, they are
able to replicate your procedures.
Certain procedures may change from those previewed in the proposal as the study is carried out,
but a proposal should always aim to have this level of clarity as its goal.
Explain, why you think this is the best method for investigating the research problem?
A key question to ask yourself at this point is- Have I fully described the procedure to
be followed in the study?
What will be done?
Where and when and how it will be done?
The next stage is the data analysis stage.
The researcher should indicate how the data to be collected will be organised, interpreted and analysed.
You need to show how and why the proposed researcher will yield the information and
insight that will enable you to address your research question.
You therefore, need to justify your choice of methods of data analysis.
For a quantitative based study explain which statistical procedures and tests you will
intend to use and why you are choosing to do so.
Similarly, if you are intend to conduct a qualitative research study, then you should
indicate a method of analysis you will use to analyse the data.
Perhaps, you intend to quantify the result obtained from your unstructured interviews?
If your project is more emergent in nature, you may be proposing to adopt a ground theory approach.
Now, comes the ethical consideration while making a proposal.
The review committee will have been alerted to any potential or any actual ethical problems
likely to arise from your proposed study, while reading the methodology section.
The proposal may be reviewed by a committee whose primary objective is to assess the scientific
method of a study, but also they will be aware of ethical issues.
It is important that you anticipate gaining written consent from adults or parents or
guardians when members of your target group cannot themselves give approval.
Ethical matters may also be relevant to protect these research partipi… participants from
any negative consequences of your study.
However, you will also need to demonstrate to the review committee that you have taken
adequate steps to ensure that both yourself and others associated with your intended projects
are protected from harm, particularly if the research situation is one that has the potential
to place people in position of danger.
For a data protection purpose you will also need to give due regard to how you intend
to store your data security.
At some point in the proposal, it is necessary to indicate clearly what you regarded as the
major ethical issues of the project and to state clearly how these will be handled.
Alternatively, you may state that the proposal raises no ethical issues.
In order to complete this section effectively and convincingly, you should pay close attention
to the ethical guidelines and are set out in the codes of conduct that may academic
or professional organisation have developed.
Now, time scale is another important aspect that you need to keep in mind while drafting a proposal.
The amount of time you need to devote to your study should be set out in the proposal.
It may be that this is a proposal for a full time commitment or perhaps for only a few hours in a week.
But whichever is the case, the research proposal must specify the amount of time involved.
The review committee will need to know how long the project will take when considering
whether to fund it or not, and then you also need to discuss the facilities and resources available.
Describing particular form of expertise or backup facilities can strengthen a proposal.
Good computer and library facilities fall into this category.
Where established network are integral to a project or cooperation has been obtained
from a particular agency or instruction, institutions, some indications of this, like letter of agreement
may be included as a helpful appendix.
Now budget, finally, we come to the most important aspect of its forming a budget.
Preparing a research budget is as much as skill as preparing other parts of the proposal.
Part of the skill lies in locating the other people who knows the price of all appropriate
commodities, staff time, tape recorders, photocopying, travel cost, and so on.
Preparing a budget means translating the timescale and plan of work into financial terms.
In preparing a budget use a checklist to include main heading such as research salaries, data
collection costs, purchase of equipment and other materials printing, travelling, expense,
stationery, and postage data analysis expenses, etcetera.
Once you have drafted your budget and other things.
Now, let's have a checklist which wi… will be very helpful in pre-submission.
It is likely that a research proposal will go through many drafts, indeed there would
be major cause for concern if it did not.
There are number of things to be achieved in reviewing a proposal, not least considering
its physical presentation, legibility, lucidity, and clarity of the presentations are all important.
While readers of a proposal will not be evaluating its presentation, the relatively small amount
of time it takes to ensure a layout that is easily followed will be time well spent.
Check carefully that the proposal meets all the criteria set by review committee.
Once you have checked all your list your proposal is set for submission.
So, What we have learnt in this that it has reviewed the process of constructing a research
proposal, setting out the main point that need to be considered in producing a professional
and convincing document.
As we have seen in any proposal it is paramount important that the research that is in envisaged
is clearly articulated and is of value of the body looking to support your research.
In assessing your proposal, a reviewer will also be taking in to see that you proposed
study is a feasible one.
As well as capturing a reviewer imagination with the subject of your research, you will
have to satisfy the reviewer that you are in a position to carry the research out to
a higher standard.
Having a bright idea is the starting point from which you have to construct a comp…
compelling case that your research is not only interesting bo… but also capable of execution.
Of course, all reviewers will have their own set of criteria by which they will judge the
proposal that comes before them unfortunately there is no easily applied formula that can

However, the more consideration that you have been able to give to the research you planned

Dear students, I am Doctor Manish Singh.
