What is legal research?
The idea of research puzzles us and seems to be an insurmountable task at times, but
the reality is that we do it all the time.
It’s going on around us every day.
Many of us will at some point participate in some or the other enquiry, may it be about
a recipe, a preferred brand of clothes or even as to whom one plans to vote in the elections.
Even when some may choose not to participate in the research still results outcome do have
an impact indirectly upon people.
Policy decisions, laws are based on research findings.
The research is done in the universities, policy think tanks who suggest the findings
based on a systematic process and informs the policy makers about the desirable changes.
Hence, it is out of incredible importance to people, hence, it is of incredible importance to people.
It can be easily imagined that research touches every area be it law, be it marketing, technology,
be it even food habits.
The learning outcome of this module are that the module has a primary objective of reducing
an, the audience to a broad overview what, how and why of legal research.
That highlights some characteristics with an intention of introducing legal research
to non-legal researchers and intends to serve as a first step towards an enduring enterprise
that is legal research which is rewarding, fulfilling and beneficial not only for the
researcher, but even the society at large.
In this module, we shall primarily cover the meaning of research, the purpose of research.
What is legal research?
The purpose of legal research, broad nature of legal research, various kinds of legal
research, other major methods of legal research, the process of legal research, sources of
information and the major problems in legal research and finally we shall summarize what
we have learnt so far.
Starting with the meaning of research.
A term can be best understood with reference to the purpose it seeks to achieve.
The purpose of research is either to know about or to contribute something new to the
existing state of knowledge.
The former can be described as the ‘disinterested search for knowledge and understanding for
its own sake’, while the latter is an application based approach to the problems in the real world.
The prefix re before research signifies a continuum which verifies or supplements existing knowledge.
It involves a systematic, careful, diligent and thorough investigation into a specific
question with a primary objective of contributing to the existing knowledge.
A directionless, unspecific, unsystematic and mere surface brushing would give us results
that cannot reveal realistic outcomes.
What is the purpose of research?
Apart from general understanding that is basic research or to find something new as applied
research in broader terms or research fulfils following objectives.
First, contribute to existing knowledge and a discipline.
Secondly, to inform policy making and thirdly to address a specific issue or question.
We will start with describing the first point, that is to contribute to existing knowledge
in a discipline for example, law.
Research can give us new set of perspectives at looking at things.
For example, historical events are continuously revised and reviewed on the basis of research.
Therefore, the version of history might not be the same for two different set of generations.
Given that, many of us would believe them to be unchangeable given their facts, but
still it can be argued that they can be viewed from a different lens.
This had a positive impact on existing state of knowledge in a particular discipline in
the sense that it expands its horizons.
Second, to inform policy making.
For example, policy making as to crime, as to housing policy, etcetera.
Research also informs policy questions.
For example, research can be used to address socio-economic issues, say education as to
how it can be given a direction as to ensure growth in a nation or say as to how to best
avoid food wastage and can there be a space for law to tackle these issues.
These kinds of researches inform policy making which ultimately reflects in the law and decision making.
Thirdly, to address a specific issue or question.
Say for example, substance abuse in campus.
Research findings are also used to answer a specific issue at hand.
It is stemmed from the concerns that the conventional researchers were not having much impact and
thereby new approaches that were seen as being more relevant and practical in the real world
settings were developed.
It can be action research which is both diagnose a specific issue and attempt to solve it,
thereby to improve practice in some way.
Also it may be evaluation which assesses the existing state of affairs in an era wherein
the accountability has increased, that requires a constant reassessment about the worth or
usefulness of a particular service policy or other intervention.
Describing legal research.
Taking a cue from the discussion above legal research can be understood as a systematic
finding or ascertainment of law on an identified topic or in the given area, as well as an
enquiry into law with a view of making advancement in the science of law.
This is not an easy task to find the law in a vast mass of statutes which are constantly
amended and supplemented by rules, regulations, orders, directives, ordinances, judgement
of courts and bylaws.
Also for making advancement in the science of law requires a systematic probe into the
underlying principle of and reasons for law.
Thus, legal research has a broad ambit to it.
It has to be continuously done by legislators, judges, lawyers, law students and law teachers.
Now, what is the purpose of research?
Law does not sit in a vacuum.
Instead, it operates in a complex social context.
It reflects attitudes and behavioural norms and also control and mould them.
However, as these norms are al… also temporal spatial.
However, as these norms are also temporal spatial that is changing with time and space.
It is desires that law has to adapt and be dynamic in order to cope with the changes,
thereby legal research becomes essential for ascertainment of law to point out ambiguities
and weaknesses of law, to critically examine the laws in order to ensure coherence, consistency
and stability of law and its underlying policy to conduct a social audit of the law and to
suggest reforms in the law.
Taking them one by one.
First, ascertaining the law, in a complex mass of legal statutes and coupled with allied
legal material it is not always easy to find the law on a particular point.
They are scattered and a single issue may involve application of various laws.
Judicial pronouncements adds to the complexity.
A researcher needs to locate, analyse and understand these pronouncements.
So, the process involves an intensive analysis of legal instruments and judicial pronouncements.
Now, highlighting the ambiguities and gaps.
A law is not designed to address every contingency that might arise in future because it is the
nature of law that it is reactive, it answers to problems which had arisen and seldom is
it that it is proactive.
Secondly, even in the physiology of provision may not fit with the legislative intent or
may not match with other provisions of the act.
Research highlights these gaps and inbuilt ambiguities.
Thirdly, to determine coherence, stability and consistency via a process of critical
evaluation of the law.
A researcher can exhibit the consistency, coherence and stability in the law.
This helps in future designing and development of law, legal provision or doctrine, as the
case may be.
Fourth, social auditing of law.
It is a pre-legislative step then in order to understand and appreciate the social factors
that had an impact on the making of law.
It enables one to know the stakes the law intends to protect or change and reasons for the same.
Such an audit helps to identify gap if any between the legal ideal and the social reality
and to know the reasons responsible thereof.
It also enables us to predict the future of law.
Now, fifthly, suggesting reforms.
In the light of the research reforms can be proposed in precise terms.
These outcomes can be on the basis of an analytical, historical and comparative research.
Now, what are the broad nature of the legal research?
On the basis of data collection and analysis two broad categories can be used to describe
different approaches.
First, the quantitative legal research and secondly, the qualitative legal research.
First, we will discuss the quantitative legal research.
The quantitative research is characterized with surveys, structured interviews, experiments,
tests as tools for data collection.
It produces data which can be made subject to statistical analysis.
So, the findings can be presented in numerical forms.
For example, a questionnaire asked respondents to tick the appropriate box in order to answer
the question as to whether they agree or disagree with the particular proposition.
This gives an opportunity to the researcher to quantify the data and calculate how many
people made a particular point.
Now, coming to qualitative legal research, participant observation and structured interviews
or life histories are some of the qualitative research methods.
The outcome is presented in the form of descriptions.
The reason it become important was that the feeling that quantitative research does not
take into account the differences between people and the objects of natural science.
It seems to be artificial and distant from everyday life that the findings might not
represent the reality.
These led many researchers to adopt more qualitative methods which allow researchers to get closer
to the people they are investigating.
What are the different kinds of legal research?
The basic type of research can be broadly classified in various subsets wherein they
can be understood in comparison with another kind of research.
Those are descriptive and analytical legal research, applied and pure legal research,
quantitative and qualitative legal research, conceptual and empirical legal research.
First, discussing the descriptive and analytical legal research.
The former describe the state of affairs as it exits.
It describes the phenomena, reporting what has happened and what is happening without
going into the reason or cause for the same.
The tools used are surveys, comparative and core… correlational method.
The tools used are surveys, comparative and correlational methods and fact finding enquiries,
but it does not establish any relationship between the variables.
The analytical research however, uses the fact and information available to make a critical
evaluation.
Second, applied and pure legal research.
The aim of the former is to find a solution to a present, practical problem at hand.
Researchers put it in a practical context.
The later focuses on generalisation and formulation of a theory.
Its aim is to broaden the understanding of a particular field of investigation.
The researcher does not focus upon the practical utility of the results.
In case of quantitative and qualitative legal research.
As mentioned, the former is about quantity or amount that is what can be expressed in
numerical form of results.
The later, however, aims at garnishing views and opinions to give outcomes.
It relies on reasons behind a particular behavioural aspect.
The fourth, conceptual and empirical legal research.
The conceptual research is related with an abstract notion on an idea.
Generally resorted to by the philosophers and thinkers to develop new concepts or reinterpret
the existing concepts.
The later, however, relies upon experience and observation alone.
It is databased coming up with results that can be verified by observations or experiments.
What are the major kind of legal research?
The other major methods used in legal research are doctrinal legal research, non-doctrinal
legal research, comparative legal research.
First, we will discuss what is meant by doctrinal legal research.
The central question of enquiry here is what is the law on a particular issue.
It is concerned with finding the law vigorously analysing it and coming up with a logical
reasoning behind it.
Therefore, it immensely contribute to the continuity, consistency and certainty of law.
The basic material can be found in the statutory material that is primary sources as well in
the secondary material.
However, the research has its own limitations it is subjective that is limited to the perception
of the researcher away from the actual working of the law devoid of factors that led outside
the periphery of law and fails to focus on the actual practice of the courts.
Now, what is non-doctrinal legal research?
Non-doctrinal legal research is also known as socio-legal research.
It leads into how the law and legal institutions moulds and affect the society.
It employs methods taken from other disciplines in order to generate an empirical data to
answer the questions.
It can either be answering a problem like to find the gap between idealism and social
reality, could be tracing the results of legal decisions, can also assess impact of non-legal
factors upon legal processes or decisions or may be an reform-based approach.
It is about viewing law from the perspective of a different discipline it, to keep it organic
and growing, that is to put things in a context.
Being empirical it is vital and valuable in revealing and expanding the legal practice
and procedures and their impact on range of social institutions like family, businesses,
citizens, consumers.
Thirdly, what is comparative legal research?
Comparative legal research involves a comparison of legal doctrines, legislations via the foreign laws.
It highlights the cultural and social character of law and how does it acts in different settings,
so it is useful in developing and amending and modifying the law.
But a cautious approach has to be taken in blindly accepting the law of another socio
setting as an ideal because it might not act in the same manner in a different setting.
What are the sources of information?
The various sources of information can be classified into primary and secondary sources.
Primary source is that source that contain authoritative records of law made by law making
bodies is a primary source.
They can be legislation, rules, regulations, orders, bylaws by delegated legis, authorities
and the authoritative decisions of the courts.
Source of information.
The secondary sources are the one that refer and relate to the law while not being themselves
primary sources.
For example, legal commentaries, abstracts, dictionaries, encyclopaedia and index.
What are the processes of a legal research?
Research is a process involving backward and forward movement between different stages
so they cannot be as neatly separated.
Nevertheless, they can be divided into the following for understanding the different stages.
Choosing a focal point of research, review of literature, formulation of hypothesis,
research design, data collection, data analysis, interpretation of data and finally the report.
Now, we shall discuss these points.
Choosing a focal point of research, identifying and formulating a legal problem is the first
step in the process.
If ill-defined and not properly formulated researcher is bound to lose interest in the research.
The researcher has to have a precise goal in sight, for that purpose it is necessary
for the researcher to identify an area of general interest from the field, an area of
specific interest and within that area of specific interest a particular aspect that
he would like to enquire into, that would signify the focus and direction of his enquiry
that has to be based on a study done from the secondary sources like a commentary, a
scholarly article like Blackstone’s commentaries on the laws of England.
Secondary sources would point a researcher to the primary source of the law, namely legislative
tax and judicial decisions.
Second comes the review of literature.
It is necessary because it would make the result to be both valued and valuable.
It is a survey of the existing related works in order to find out as to what has already
been discussed on the particular aspect.
It will also give an understanding as to what has not been discussed.
The researcher’s aim is to contribute something new to the existing state of knowledge, so
therefore, he has to choose from the later area.
This also justifies his research and makes it an original contribution.
It also helps in avoiding the possible pitfalls and informs areas that might have been neglected
in the research questions.
Third comes the formulation of hypothesis.
On the basis of an extensive literature survey a researcher might rephrase or reformulate
the problem that can be depending upon the nature of research, can be in the form of
a mere statement or a proposition indicating relationship between variables, the validity
of which is not known.
Such propositions are known as hypothesis.
So, it is a tentative statement the validity or invalidity of which has yet to be tested
on the basis of research.
The manner in which it is formulated gives a hint of methods required, kind of data needed,
and the method of analysis required for the research.
Then comes the research design.
Research design signifies the structure of the research.
It is characterized by a logical systematic planning of the research, a blueprint.
Though it may be tentative as the researcher cannot foresee all the contingencies that
might arise and thus he can adapt as required which would increase the efficiency and reliability
of his findings.
After this comes data collection, data collection involves decision making as to the method
to be employ to collect the data that determines the fate of the research.
For determining the appropriate method a researcher has to keep in mind the objectives of the
research and the scope of the enquiry.
Data may be primary or secondary.
Data collected by primary source is primary.
While one collected from other agency or available in some published form is secondary.
A data has to be relevant and authoritative that would primarily depend upon the scope
and focus of the research question.
After collecting data we analyse the data.
Therefore, the next task after data collection is analysis.
The raw data has to be put it to analysis so as to reflect the direction and trend.
Analysis happens before interpretation.
There is no clear cut demarcation between the two as analysis is not complete without
interpretation and interpretation cannot precede analysis.
They are thus interdependent.
In a legal research cases are also required to be analysed.
However, with the caution the two different set of facts can lead to different outcomes
or may be for the same reason that an earlier case law can be distinguished on the basis
of question of law raised.
It is the drawing inferences from the collected data that interpretation is done.
Interpretation can be inductive or deductive.
Inductive is inference from particular propositions to general propositions.
While deductive is inferences from general propositions to particular propositions.
The interpretation give the broader meaning to research findings and as well trigger new researchers.
However, caution must be exercised in interpreting the data.
It needs to be impartial and objective.
A wrong interpretation can lead to inaccurate and misleading conclusions.
After interpretation comes the report.
Thus, the last phase is report writing.
Though this, through this the researcher communicates his work to the audience.
Report contains significant facts, those are the problem, method used and the findings
arrived at by the researcher.
It has to be original and with precise clarity in communicating the results.
What are the major problems in legal research?
The major problems while undertaking a legal research are as follows.
First, cultural problems.
Secondly, structural and procedural problems.
For example, unsympathetic attitude of authorities.
Thirdly, lack of resources.
For example, access to money, access to the information, etcetera.
Incompetence, for example, inadequate planning and lack of networking and forums.
Thus, we can summarize what we have learnt so far.
Legal research is a systematic understanding of the law with a view of its advancement.
The purposes of the same are very important to the people and society because law acts
within the society and the both had an impact on each other.
Every kind of research method had its own value.
However, while undertaking a research a researcher might face some hurdles, but they can be avoided
by proper planning of the research process.
Hello everyone.
Welcome back to the Research meth…
Methodology modules.
And today we have reached to the last module that is Report Writing.
So, this is the most important aspect because this is the most important thing that you
do about your research.
As you know, I am Doctor Ritu Sharma.
We have done various modules together.
Today, I am going to discuss with you the module on Report Writing.
In this, I am going to talk about the ways in which research writing links theory with practice.
Then we are going to see the aims of research writing, and then will sentis… sensitize
the readers to the need to communicate and their research with their audience and then
to provide readers with the framework within which they can write up their research reports.
Finally, to provide a practical guidance of the management of the writing process and
enable a good reference and citation practice.
The culmination of a research project arrives when all the hard work is put to paper and
the fruits of our labor are shared with a wider audience.
This means writang… writing up for research in a way that presents not just our findings,
but the process through which we arrive at these findings.
It demands an honesty about our research design and our perspective, so that others can understand
not just the research we have produced, but something about the way in which we have produced it
The foundation for this approach writing is that research projects do not exist in isolation,
but contribute to a wider body of knowledge that is constantly developing.
In exploring the writer write-up process, it is useful to consider Denscombe’s view
that there are some common themes and shared concerns that underline formal reports of
research across the spectrum of approaches within the social sciences.
There is some general consensus that when writing up research, the aim is to explain
the purpose of the research, describe how the research was done, present the findings
from the research, discuss and analyze the findings, and reach the conclusions.
These five aims form a useful basis upon which to approach the writing of a research project.
As Denscombe suggests, this appears to be one area, at least, where there I agree of
consensus among researchers.
Qualitative and quantitative researchers may disagree on the precise layout or presentation
of reports, and we shall acknowledge this, but for our purpose, the mutual aims of writing
up provide a useful focus for our discussion.
Addressing the research question with your data is the first thing that we are going to discuss.
When presenting the outcome of our research, it is important to return to the very beginning
and ask ourselves what was the purpose of this research?
The research process can be lengthy, and time spent in the field, or mulling over the reams
data, can make the point of origin of our research seems like a dim and distant memory.
So, when it comes to writing up, the temptation can be to see the light at the end of the
tunnel and simply focus on bringing the research to a close.
But it is important to remind ourselves of the aims and objective of a research, since
it is these that we need to address in writing.
Research, by its nature, can generate lots of interesting observations.
As we journey through the process, a perception of, and ideas about our research area may
change, leading us to consider new possibilities for future research perhaps.
It is easy to see how, by becoming distracted by alternative ideas presented by our data,
we may forget what our original stance was.
These new ideas are every bit as important as our original ideas, as they represent an
advancement in knowledge.
But we must remember that at some point, some time ago, we came up with the research question
that we set out to address.
Enforcing the research question upon our write-up may appear to be a restrictive measure.
What if the data present issue outside the research question?
Well what we are suggesting is not that these issues are ignored, but that the research
question should be used to guide the primary focus of a writing.
One of the greatest barriers researcher face when it comes to writing up is tackling the
program of what to write about, and how to organize it.
The research question can be used as guidance here, since it provides us with the framework
within which we can organize the data.
Writing strategies – Of all the stages of the research process, the one that arguably
plagues researcher the most is writing up, yet writing is arguably a skill which most
of us acquire before becoming researcher.
It makes use of our experiences of expressing our ideas by putting pen to paper, something
that we start to learn from a very early age.
Perhaps, this explains why it is an activity that is regarded as undeserving the same degree
of attention as, say, statistical analysis.
They, there certainly appears to be a lack of attention to the process of writing in the literature.
Social scientist write about the methods they use to collect and analyze social data, and
about the results these methods yield.
They rarely examine the process of writing itself.
A possible reason for this, as Bingham suggest is that, ‘writing has become viewed as a
process which is unproblematic and transparent’, and that this stems from the earlier emphasis
placed on the realism in the social sciences.
In attempting to emulate the scientific community, the writing up of research was seen as an
objective process, whereby the researcher simply presented the result of an uncomplicated,
straightforward fashion.
When we are feeling creative, our arguments and discussion might flow freely and this is
when the writing process can be at most rewarding.
A word of caution, though, is getting carried away by these moments, we may forget to stop and reflect.
Similarly, in the moments when we face blocks in our writing, it is all too easy to get
frustrated because we just want the writing to keep moving.
It is the time like when we need the discipline to say stop.
It’s time to take a break and reflect on what we have done so far.
A strategy helps us to plan how to approach our writing, and work out how to deal with
barriers when we inevitably face them.
Before we look at strategies for the actual process of writing, there are a few practical
things that we can do in advance that will make the process easier.
Cuba and Cocking suggest that appraising the environment in which we do a writing can be benificail.
They suggest that a number of questions relating to where, when, and how we write need to be
addressed before we actually sit down to write.
Some of these questions are outlined below.
Is there a dedicated environment in which we can write?
If we are fortunate enough to have an office or study in which we can work, then this may
prove to be the ideal environment.
If we are going to be using a shared environment, a shared office, university computer room,
a family room, the library, then we need to access at what time the space will be exclusively available to us.
Being interrupted during a particular productive writing session can be extremely frustrating,
so it is important to plan to write at times when interruptions are least likely.
The next question that comes to our mind is, when is the best time of day to write?
If we are fit fitting in writing around other commitments, then we shall have to try to
maximize our use of the time available, but if we know that we work better at certain
times of the day, and are able to, trying to plan to write at these times can help.
This may involve reorganizing other aspects of our lives, but it is it improves productivity,
it will be worth it.
How are we going to store our writings?
Most formal writing nowadays is carried out on a word processor.
This means thinking about electronic storage and peripherals such as printers.
Saving work regularly is a habit most definitely worth getting into.
Most word processing software packages have auto save features.
By enabling these and making regular backup copies on other disk and storage devices we
can avoid any any of the heart attack of losing a days’ worth of work.
Emailing files to oneself is also a good way of producing a backup copy, which is stored
on the server of our email client, which in turn will be regularly backed up.
How familiar are we with the software?
That's another question that we need to loo… s… look into.
Word processing skills are common features of school curriculum and we often taught at
universities nowadays, but it is worth investigating the software we are using for additional features
which may make the process of writing easier.
Word processing packages come with the variety of automated features which make the organization
and production of complex document a lot more manageable.
Features such as word's auto-correct function enable abbreviations or shorthands to be used
in place of words that are going to be used frequently.
The software is told which characters to replace with other words, so as the abbreviations
are entered, they are overwritten by the corresponding full length words or phrase.
It is worth becoming familiar with these features prior to starting our writing, and also investigating
additional software that can be used to manage and organize references.
Such packages can be particularly helpful if we are producing a lengthy, heavy referenced text.
The structure and  the style of research reports.
Up till now we have tried to avoid being too perceptive when discussing the process of writing up.
We have to recognize that different approaches to writing work better with some authors than
the others, and that our audience will partly dictate the way in which we write.
However, upon reading a variety of research reports, we may notice something encouraging
about the way different authors organize their reports.
This is one area where there does appear to be some consensus.
Whether a research is quantitative or qualitative in nature, the research reports need to consist
of a number of sections which deal with the different stages of, and rationale behind
the research process.
The section we outline here are offered as a guide to structure, and should not be taken
as the final word for the matter.
Journal articles or these may have a predetermined list of headings which have to be adhered
to, but regardless of the precise wordings of the headings, the same elements will need
to be included.
What follows can be used as a checklist when writing up a research rou… projects.
The very first thing the and the most important thing for a report writing is the title of the report.
Sometimes the most obvious elements are overlooked.
The title of the research should be made to be concise but also give a flavor of the purpose
of the research.
The title does not have to be the same as the research questions.
This can be applied as a subtitle.
But sometimes when we have a whole series of research questions, even this may not be appropriate.
To try to frame all of the objectives and research questions in the title would have
been futile, so instead the instead you choose the far shorter version that appears in print.
In addition to the title, the front page should contain the name of the author, date, name
of any sponsor of the report.
After we have written the title, another thing which is very important and we should be keeping
in mind is to write an abstract.
The abstract, while appearing at the front of the report, should be written last of all.
In order to understand the purpose of an abstract it is useful to consider where we might come across them.
Earlier in the chapter, we mentioned using a database to aid with the literature searches.
These often consist of a collection of abstracts which enable the researcher to decide upon
the relevance of the sources.
With this in mind, consider what someone might be looking for in an abstract.
They would want to know the aim of the research, the methods employed, the outcomes of the
research, and any theoretical implications.
These, then, are the points which need to be covered in the abstract, but it must remain
brief, two hundred words is normally more than sufficient, and often abstract appear
as single paragraphs.
Acknowledgement – There may be occasions where the success of a research product, project
has been in part dependent on the services or guidance of certain individuals or organization.
In these instances, it is appropriate to acknowledge the ways in which your research has been helped.
It may be that, if we were carrying out a study which involved observing class activities
in school, we may wish to acknowledge the teachers who agree to let us sit in their class.
Acknowledgement should not be given at the expense of anonymity, it, if this has been
offered through, since in doing so, we would compromise ethical safeguards offered to participants.
Then, after acknowledgement, another important aspect is introduction of the report writing.
The introduction and conclusion to any form of writing can be the most difficult elements
to get right.
The introduction serves a dual purpose of providing an idea as to the content of the
report and convincing the reader that it is worth reading.
Gilbert says the introduction should, first, indicate the topic of the paper, demonstrate
why this topic is interesting and important, and show how the approach taken in the paper
is an advance on previous work.
In brief, the purpose at the Introduction is to get the reader hooked.
This means starting from the reader’s present knowledge and leading him or her on to seeing
that the topic is worth spending some time investigating.
The importance of captivating the readers cannot be overstated.
It is min… misconception to assume that research will be read simply because it is
inherent valuable.
We must convince the reader that our addition to the body of knowledge is going to further
their understanding of the topic as well as providing an interesting read along the way.
The next thi… next section is the literature review.
The introduction sets the scenes for the literature review, in that it states the objective and
any hypotheses that are to be tested.
It also provides an overview of the theoretical framework and context, social, historical,
political, cultural, economic, geographical.
The literature review then expands on this.
It provides a justification for the research as well as a critical appraisal of the theoretical
backdrop against which the data will be analyzed.
The literature review helps to make sense of the research.
It should silence any doubt about why the research has been carried out, and it should
demonstrate that we are conversant with the terminologies and theory which relate to the
phenomenon under investigation.
Once we have done the literature review, we should focus on our research design and the
methods that are used in it.
When describing our methods, it is necessary to provide sufficient detail so that the reader
could replicate our research design, if not our results.
This enables the reader to affirm the reliability of the study.
In pursuing this aim, relevant elements from the following list should be included.
First, who is involved in the research- participants, organizations, and how these have been selected.
Second, how data have been collected.
Third, how data have been analyzed.
Fourth, any practical barriers which had to be overcome, such as access to sample or potential
gap in the data.
Finally, ethical consideration arising from the research.
One of the commitment we have as a researcher is to share not just what we have learnt from
what our results tell us, but our experiences of using our chosen methods.
In order for a reader to have confidence in our study and our interpretation of the data,
he or she must be told about how the research progressed.
Once again, this requires reflection on the research process and demands that we question our methods.
No matter how carefully we design a research in advance, it is only upon completion, when
we look back over it, that we can truly scrutinize our methods.
We need to ask whether the methods we applied were appropriate to our study.
Key issues that have been addressed throughout this can be used to shape our methodological evaluation.
These include validity, reflexivity, objectivity, and ethics.
These have already been dealt in detail while while explaining the qualitative research method module.
In offering an evaluation it is important to admit to any subsequent shortcoming in the design.
If a research is being read in a critical manner by our readers, these will become evident
and we shall be expected either to defend them or to accept them and take them into
account with a discussion of data.
The possible issues to be aware of are are limitations of the sample in terms of its
size, response rate and representativeness, for example, when reliance has been placed
upon the succession of a snowballing approach to sampling which has resulted in fewer participants
being found than had been hoped, or low returns from a postal survey resulting in difficulties
when analyzing small section of data.
Reliability of measurement, example, ambiguous questions in a survey or timing of events
in an experiment by hand with a stopwatch.
Validity of indicators, for example where secondary data have been used and variables
which relate to perceived level of crime have been analyzed as a representation of actual crime.
Ethical implications, for example, where data collected in an in-depth interview could potentially
reveal the identity of the interviewee, so very few co… quotes have been included in
the analysis and discussion of the results.
Inappropriate analytical models, for example, where a causal relationship has been identified
between two variables without using multivariate analysis to exclude the possible influence
of third variable.
If textual data are quantified, this would also require justification, for these examples.
Statement of results – When writing about our data we need to decide whether to present
the data first, and then discuss them in the in the ensuing section, or combine our discussion
with the presentation of results.
The formal former option has the advantage of allowing the readers to interpret the data
by themselves and draw their ca… own conclusion about the implications of the results.
This can be favoured, as it enables us to defend a report against criticism of overly
subjective interpretations.
If we assume this approach, data should be presented in such a way as to describe the results
With quantitative data, this can be achieved with tebla... tables and graphs, and reference to figure.
Indeed, quantitative data lends themselves more readily to complete, summaries since
large quantities of data can be summarized relatively easily in tables.
Qualitative data present a rather different challenge, though.
Results can be described with reference to selected parts of the data which reflect a research question.
However, it is extremely unlikely, because of the expense of data that qualitative research
produces, that we will be able to offer a complete picture of it.
In deciding what to include and what not to, we must accept that we are introducing a degree of subjectivity.
There is no easy way around this, all we can do is try to ensure that a balanced picture
of the data is provided, by selecting data from different participants which provide
an account of the completing perspective found in the data.
Next step is the discussion.
Assuming that we have opted to provide a separate descriptive overview of the data, the discussion
provides an opportunity to reflect on the data, address a research question, and contextualize
the findings within theory from the literature.
This section should be the most enlightening.
In some respect, it is the reason for carrying out the research in the first place, since
it is here where the way in which a research enhances knowledge comes to light.
The purpose of the, a research is addressed through our interpretation of data and how
we see this fitting in what with what else is already known.
The discussion relies heavily on the ability to link a research with the theory.
As discussed earlier in this chapter, we should make our position clear in relation to any
debates or schools of thoughts in the field.
If we are using a particular model or philosophical perspective with which to interpret a data,
this should be stated.
Finally, coming to the conclusion, writing conclusion in report writing.
Apart from the introduction, the conclusion is often the most difficult part of the report writing.
It is signi… it signifies the end of a lot of hard work, so we shall want to get it right.
It is also along the, along with the introduction and abstract, often the only part of the report
that will get read.
The conclusion should draw the report to a close, by reiterating the main points, which
might seek to address all the questions.
After conclusion, we would be giving references and bibliography.
And in this throughout the write-up we will have made up reference to a number of sources.
These all will need to be included in a list of references.
This is the minimum requirement, although there will be inevitable more sources that
you have used throughout the research process, but to which you have not cited a reference
in the text.
These can still be included as a bibliography, as it provides the reader with a useful list
of relevant material.
What were the main findings of the research?
How do these findings sit with the context of theory?
What are the implications of the research?
What lessons can be learned from the experience of carrying out the research?
What can we learn from the way methods were employed?
What areas are open for future research?
Appendices – It is the, it is easy to perceive appendices as a repos… repository for all
the bits of a report that do not seem to fit else anywhere else.
However, appendices need to be carefully thought out and relevant.
Items such as copy of a questionnaire, interview schedule or observation plan are useful element
of an appendix.
Statistical tables can be gathered together in an appendix, with only a selection relevant
to the discussion dealt with the main body of the text.
The important thing to remember is that appendices should be cross-referenced in the text.
The reader should be made aware at what point during the report they need to turn to the
appendix and make use of the information.
Without such clear signposting, the appendices will just take on the form of some additional
information that has been included at the end to pad out the report.
References and citation – We have placed a good deal of emphasis on the importance
of situating our research in the context of theory in the literature, in terms of both
our topic and methods.
With this in mind, it is important to ss… understand how and when these references to
others work should be included within our writing.
Moreover, it is important to have an idea of why they should be included, and we will
turn our attention to this now.
When considering, why references are important, it is useful to consider who the practice
of citation affects and benefits, these are three interested parties with regard to referencing.
One, the reader-citing references directs the reader to the original source, therefore,
enabling a more thorough understanding of our research and development of ideas.
Second, our writing may contain assumptions based on established theory.
It is not sufficient, however, merely to assume that the reader is familiar with with a particular
theory and so it is necessary to provide readers with enough information to understand the
topic.
Third, this can be done through the literature review, and by offering clues as to where
they can pursue the topic in more depth throughout our references.
The cited authors we are showing our recognition of another individuals work, whether we are
supporting it or criticizing it.
This can enable constructive dialogue between writers.
In addition, sometimes an idea may have already been voiced so fluently that it would seem
pointless to try to phrase it differently.
In these instances, it is useful to quote an author directly.
Ourselves not only does citing reference add credibility to our work, but it can also help
to avoid legal complications brought about by wrongfully passing of another's work as our own.
Finally, the polishing up and finishing off in report writing.
Having planned, organized, structured, drafted, referred and rewritten our research, we are now
finally nearing the end of the writing-up process.
By this stage in our writing we should have something that could almost be called a finished product.
The structure and content will have been established through redrafting.
So at this point we can turn our attention to the finer points, such as presentation,
formatting, and small refinements in our use of language.
Once we have checked all the points that we discussed in our report writing, with the
our, our report is in the final stage.
So, this is how we can write a report and finally give our results in a systematic manner. S…
To conclude, the writing-up process should be an enjoyable one since it enables us to
bring together all the other stages of the research process into an end product.
It should not be seen as an easy process, though it requires planning, motivation, organization and reflection.
It handled poorly, if it handled poorly, it can prove to be the undoing of a lot of hard work.
The writing up process needs to be treated with respect to view writing as unproblematic
and transparent, as merely a simple way of reporting our research is a terrible mistake.
It is necessary to remember the objectives of writing up research that we have discussed
and these are to address our research questions, to discuss our findings, to conceptualize
our research within a broad theoretical framework, and to reflect on the research process, to
share our experiences, and to contribute to methodological debates.
Finally, we have seen the importance of some of the convention of academic writing, references,
presentation, structure and format.
Writing up research is a different process from the that involved in other forms of writing.
We must recognize this, and not assume that because we have spent our whole life writing
in other forms that writing up research will come easily to us.
As with many skills, the key to successful and enjoyable writing is the practice.
Thus, I hope the this will help you in writing your report successfully.

Hope you you are able to write up your data in a very beautiful and nice manner.
