Welcome back to a new module of Research Methodology that is Quantitative Research.
As of now we have done various modules on Research Methodology, but whenever we talk
about research, this is one thing that comes to our mind is quantitative research and qualitative research.
Today, I, Doctor Ritu Sharma would be dealing with this quantitative research module with
you under the MOOCs program.
So, while dealing with the quantitative module, we will be discussing an overview of the characteristics
of quantitative research.
We’ll be investigating the difference stages of the research processes in experimental
and sample survey methods.
Then we will examine the process for drawing on accurate and representative sample at the population.
Then we’ll provide an appraisal of the different questions type, measures and indicators which
are used in designing the questionnaire.
Finally, we’ll highlight the main issues confronting social researchers when using
quantitative approach and methods in the research product, projects.
The term quantitative method refers in large part of the adoption of the natural sciences
experiment as the model for scientific research.
Its key feature being quantitative measurement of the phenomenon studied and systematically
control of the theoretical variables influi… influencing those phenomena.
Thus, the logic of such reaso… research is to first collect data using standardized
approaches on a range of variables. S…
Second, search for patterns of causal relationship between these variables and third, test given
theory by confirming or denying the precise hypothesis.
The method employed in this type of quantitative social research are most typically the sample
survey and the experimental method.
A method that is particularly popular in social sciences research.
The sample survey is the most commonly used technique for gathering information whether
by quantitative or qualitative.
Surveys are based on using statistical sampling method by taking a representative sample from
a given population and applying a standard research instrument in the form of a structured
questionnaire surveys enable descriptive and explanatory generalization to be made about
the population in question.
Quantitative approach differ from qualitative approach in a number of ways.
And, ee… most importantly there is a relatively high degree of pre-conceptualization associated
with quantitative-based research.
Adapting the theory then research approach, researcher working within this tradition will
have certain a priori assumption about exactly what research questions to address and how
these should be formulated.
How the study should be designed including which research tools to use?
How data collec… is collected and how it is organized and the intended methods of analysis.
The range of likely fingling… findings to be expected.
This approach contrast saa… sharply with qualitative approach which as we have seen
are typically involved in exploratory research, in which the objective is to open up a research question.
Here, the research strategy is guided by the reality of conducting a research project.
Decisions about how a qualitative-based research study is to progress often takes place during
the course of the research itself, rather than before it has begun.
In this module, we’ll try to understand use of both experiment and sample surveys,
some of their advantage and disadvantage, the issues that arise by their use.
Design issues and techniques in experiments and sample survey will be reviewed, like types
of method used, different sampling strategies and so on.
Together with an overview of the debate concerning the legitimacy of these quantitative method
within the social sciences.
Experimental research – Experiments are most commonly used in psychological research
and in the broad field of business studies, particularly in organizational research.
Experimental research is based on researcher manipulating certain controlled conditions
in order to identify the relationship between particular variables that it is hoped will
explain cause-and-effect relationship.
In seeking to measure the impact that one factor has on another by controlling all the
other factor that might have an effect, experimental research build on the principle of a positivist
approach to science more than any other research techniques.
Experiments can be carried out in either a laboratory or a field setting.
Laboratory experimentation is most closely regulated method of experiment, involving
the introduction of certain conditions into a controlled environment that stimulates key
characteristic of a natural environment.
An example might be to the examining the extent to which the responses of a group of voters
to question about political attitude after exposure to a series of party election broadcast
might be different from another yet identical groups response when it has not been confronted
with such images.
Such experiments allow for very considerable control on behalf of the researcher, who is
able to effect change and observe research participant’s subsequent behavior.
Experiments conducted outside the laboratory take place in a natural environment under
as carefully controlled condition as possible.
An example might be a situation in which researcher stage a physical attack in a public place
to examine people's response to the incident as an investigation of a bystander apathy.
Field experiments are somewhat different.
Here, experiment principles are applied to live social events and therefore permits the
study of phenomenon, which ethical or practical consideration would normally rule out.
Essentially, the researcher measure the effect of an intervention which is occurring naturally.
Such projects, which measure variables without manipulating them are often called quasi-experiment
or non-experimental designs.
An example might be a comparison of voter turnout for local election in two different
areas, one where a new initiative has been introduced by a local authority, voting by
telephone and one where it has not.
The role of the researcher will be to measure any change in the voting levels that allow
from the initiative, to examine whether there is a cause-and-effect relationship between
the two variables which is in that case are voting methods and voter turnout rate.
Establishing causality – Experimental research is based on testing a hypothesis stating a
relationship between a dependentable variable and an independent variable.
A dependable variable is the variable that the researcher wishes to explain.
And an ind… independent variable is the variable, the variable that researcher expects
to explain the change in the dependable variable.
If we can determine that the two variables or phenomenon vary, then we can say that we
have established a ka… co-variation.
For example, we may be able to establish co-variation between personal income and political conservatism.
However, simply being also able to say that a change in the level of income is associated
with the change in conservatism is rather limited in terms of scientific explanation.
In the majority of cases, researchers will want to go beyond co-variation to demo…
demonstrate causality that a change in the independent variable causes a change in the
dependent variable.
To be able to establish causality, it must be possible to establish the time order of
event, that the effect follows the cause.
In the natural sciences where the experiments are carried out under highly controlled condition,
the verification of causality is not particularly problematic.
For example, it is relatively straightforward to determine that the application of heat
to water causes it to boil.
However, in the social world we are often faced with co-varying relationship where causality
is far from clear-cut.
To return to our example of income and political conservatism, it is possible to argue that
either of the variable may cause the other.
As person's income increases, they become more conservatives in both outlook and behavior.
If a person adopts conservative values and lifestyle, they are likely to see an increase
in their income.
The chain of causality in the example is difficult to establish, even though covariation is relatively
easy to identify.
Even where we can demonstrate a clear covariation between two variables and we are capable of
asserting that one predates the other, we do not necessarily have sufficient condition
in which to infer causality.
Other variable must first be ruled out for this to be the case.
For example, it would be a weak explanation of the relationship between these two phenomena
that did not take into account age.
It may be that a person's age is a major determinant factor in relation to both people’s political
views and the level of personal income that they are able to earn.
Where a causal relationship between two variables could possibly be explained by a third variable,
we can say that relationship is a spurious one.
Thus, researcher seeks to establish non-spuriousness that causality is not violated by the existence
of another variable.
The steps to be taken when conducting in a, an experiment are, one, determine the dependent
variable and independent variable in your research.
Choose the level of treatment to be adapted that is what test to use and how often it
is to be conducted.
Then, third, draw a representative sample from your target population.
Fourth, impose as many controls as are possible on other parameters that could affect the
conditions of the experiment.
Divide the research participants into an experimental group and a controlled group.
Protest both the experimental group and the control group using an appropriate instrument.
Expose the experimental group to the treatment.
Measure both the experimental and control group again using the same instrument.
Collect data from both the pre-testing and post-testing of both groups.
Analyze data to determine the effects of the treatment on the experimental group.
Now, let’s discuss the issues in conducting the experimental research.
All experiments are subject to threat to their validity in ways that may severely detract
from the findings.
These are expressed in terms of threats to an experiment's internal validity that is
those things that may affect whether a true measurement has been obtained using the measuring
instrument and threats to external validity that is concerning the generalizability of
the findings to the intended population.
Internal Validity – History events that may occur in society between the first and
the second measurements which could explain the change in the dependable variable.
For example, in carrying out an experiment on workplace morale something may happen in
the experimental group’s workplace and not in the control group’s workplace.
Even outside influence such as particular good or bad whether most definitely outside
the control of the experimenter may impact on, have a impact on the experiment.
The next point that needs to be taken care of is the maturation.
Other processes that may be influenced by the passage of time between the two tests.
The obviously dependent on the time that elapse between the pre-test and the post-test.
Where the gap is a considerable one, a variety of factors including personal life events
may need to be taken into account.
Third is the mortality.
This happens when some of the experimental or control group leave the experiment thus
affecting the two groups comparability.
Again, this will be a function of the length of the experiment and will be more of an issue
where the experiment takes place over a longer period.
Forth one is the instrumentation.
Any variation in the test whether between the two groups or over the two tests.
It will be very important to ensure that the same instrument is used for both the pre-test
and the post-test.
If this is not the case, then the observed difference could be the result of variation
in a measurement process.
Testing the final point, the possibility that the test itself may explain the change in
the dependable variability.
For example, in the course of carrying out an experiment on the extent to which exposure
to a party election broadcast might affect the level of people's political knowledge.
The very act of actually taking part in the experiment itself might affect people's test score.
It might get them into the mode of being tested perhaps by relieving any pre-test nerves and
increasing their general pre-test level of confidence.
If this is the case, it is possible that any changed record may actually be the result
of your conducting the research, not of showing them the party election broadcast.
Next is external validity.
The main threat to external validity is that the knowledge that people are participating
in a study is likely to impact on the behavior of the researcher participants.
If, for example, the people in the study know that you are observing them to see whether
their morale has improved after the introduction of a new management initiative, they may deliberately
act in a particular way.
This is known as the problem of reactivity.
They may display marked positive or negative reaction depending on the disposition towards their employer.
This phenomenon has become known as the Hawthorn Effect, after a research product project that
was carried out by Hawthorne works in Chicago in the nineteen twenties, where the workers
in question acted up for the benefit of the researcher.
Reactivity is used as a methodological justification for using a level of deception in experimental research.
Ethical issues in the experimental research.
Experimental research raises a number of ethical dilemmas concerning the manner in which researchers treat people.
For example, some researcher may consider it inappropriate to manipulate human beings
in the same way as laboratory animals such as mice and guinea pigs are treated.
An additional ethical consideration in relation to experimental research is the question of
including or excluding people from a study in which some way, some may benefit.
For example, an experiment may be designed to measure the effect that the introduction
of CCTV has in reducing crime in certain residential neighborhoods.
In this instance, it may be argued that researchers occupy a too powerful position in being able
to decide which area and therefore, which residence will benefit from the experiment
and which will not benefit.
One way around such a charge of unethical abuse of power by the researcher is to take
a change that is occurring any way and collect or obtain statistics from before the change,
during it and after it.
This is known as quasi experiment.
As we have discussed earlier, there are two types of quantitative research, experimental
method and survey method.
We have already seen the experimental method.
Now, we are going to discuss the survey method.
We have already discussed sample survey in detail in another module on survey method
and sampling methods, we will try to understand very briefly here.
Sample surveys are conducted in order to provide the researcher or the sponsor of the research
with statistical information, either on a particular issue or problem that needs resolving
or to test the robustness or not of an existing theory.
This involves measuring various phenomena and drawing conclusion about any relationship
between them to establish patterns of cause-and-effect.
For instance, in a study of industrial relations we might compare different workplace in terms
of a number of variable that we hypothise are likely to be associated with the industrial dissent.
These might be the size of the firm or organization, the type of industry, the inclusiveness of
the decision making process, whether the organization is unionized or not, the skill level of the
employees, the gender mixing within the organization, the balance between part-time and the full-time
employees, the unemployment rate in the local area and so on. S…
To analyze such relationship and draw widespread conclusion requires the researcher to generate
large amount of data, so that conclusions can be generalized from the sample survey
to the wider population from which the survey respondents were drawn.
In order to have confidence in the results generated from a sample survey and to any
eliminate or minimize bias, the researcher should aim to maximize the response rate and
in doing so, ensure that the study is representative of the population group.
Sample surveys are a method of gathering information by means of personal interviews or questionnaire.
They are sometimes referred as mass interviews, because they are a way of collecting similar
information from a large number of people at the same time.
Sample surveys are based on standardized approaches, using standardized instruments such as questionnaire.
These research instruments employ fixed question and answer formats so that there is a consistency
of data collection approach, regardless of who is actually asking the question.
The sample surveys therefore akin to a structured dialogue between usually two people, in which
the researcher ask a series of pre-planned standardized questions and the respondent’s
answer are recorded precisely on a form, and ultimately turned into numbers for statistical analysis.
In this way, the studies are said to be quantitative in nature.
Let us now understand the uses of the survey research, which is a very important part of
the quantitative research.
Academic researchers conduct surveys to test out various research hypothesis.
For example, they may want to explore the relationship between age and political conservatism
or why is it that some children play truants from school or under what circumstances people
become addicted to gambling.
By gathering statistical evidences, survey research may help to support a particular
theory by shedding light on the connection and association that exist between such variables.
In this way, researchers look for patterns that may explain social phenomena.
Academics are not the only people who use survey method as research method.
Other users of surveys can be broadly categorized as follows.
One, government and its agencies, voluntary sector organizations and campaign groups use
survey research to inform the influence of the political, economic and social policy-making process.
Then, business of all sizes carry out surveys in their quest for gaining a lead in the market
for their product by differentiating their product against those of their competitors.
Third, the media and the political parties carry out public opinion polls on voting intentions,
partly political leaders and their polity policies.
Survey research can be used to obtain multifaceted data from an individual.
On the behavior, straight forward questions on what the respondent has done or is doing
or may doing the future.
For example, it is possible to ask people if they use public transport for certain journeys
or if they are vegetarian.
Then there are questions on belief like what people think will happen.
What do they believe is true or false?
Do people believe that the National Health Service is safer in the hands of the current
government than it was under the previous administration?
Then there are questions of attitudes, how people think and feel about certain things.
For example, whether people consider that women with per-school children should participate
in the workforce.
Question on attributes.
These are the personal question that concern the characteristics of the respondent, such
as his or her age, sex, ethnicity, religion and employment status.
As such, these questions have the potential to be viewed as a sensitive question.
They are often referred to as classification questions.
By employing a combination of such question in a survey, the skillful researchers open
up the possibility of describing and explaining complex social phenomena.
Now, let us understand the Method of Data Collection in a Quantitative Research.
There are four main types of data collection method for a social survey.
First one, the face-to-face interview, where the respondent is questioned in person by an interviewer.
The main advantage of this method is that it usually results in a relatively high response rate.
Second, however, such interview commonly incurs high cost due to the number of interviewers
that need to be employed, and it is also argued that the personal interaction between the
interviewer and the respondent can lead to a biased response.
Then in a study that considers questions of child discipline and punishment, it may be
that respondent will offer the socially acceptable response, the answer that they believe the
interviewer wants to hear.
Second is the Postal Questionnaire.
Postal Questionnaire are widely used because they are relatively cheap to administer and
they enable coverage of a wide geographical area.
Also given that they avoid direct personal contact, they have the advantage at assuring
a degree of privacy for the respondent.
The main disadvantage associated with the Postal Questionnaire is that they perform
poorly in relation to response rate.
Telephonic interview – They have become more common in the past decade as technologically
advances have allowed researcher to draw samples with great accuracy.
They are very quick to administer.
However, they are limited to researchers who have access to the relevant technology such
as random digital dialing technology to carry them out.
Online surveys which are delivered by email or make use of web based form in place of
a questionnaire are now widely used.
They share some of the characteristics of postal surveys in that they are inexpensive
to administer, but may have lower response rate than interviewer-administrator surveys.
Access to data – The instant response is sent and being able to draw samples on a global
scales are also attractive benefits, but the difference between the characteristic as internet
users and non-user can result in internet based samples which are not representative
at the general population.
Once the data have been collected, the researcher have to codified and process the data in a
manner that is becomes presentable in tabular form and charts.
It should also become accessible for use for statistical treatment that would tell us about
the different qualities of data.
Each of these methods of data collection has its own strength and weaknesses in relation
to design, cost, and so on, and in crude terms one`s weakness are often the other’s strength.
The method that is selected will depend on the type of population you aim to research,
the nater… nature of the research question and the resources at your disposal.
Sampling – A very important part of survey method is sampling.
Surveys are often referred to as sample surveys because the information that the researcher
wishes to gather is usually collected from a selected group of people, a sample.
It is very unusual for researcher to question all of the people that they wish to study
owing to both times and cos… cost considerations.
Sampling has been dealt as a separate module.
Here we will have a basic idea about the sampling survey.
Sampling is a method that identifies a representative number from a given universe population.
There are two basic properties of sample.
It should be adequate and it should be representative of the universe.
The most crucial point in sampling is to make sure that one's personal values do not influence
the selection process.
In order to keep out the researcher’s bias, various techniques or procedures of selecting
a sample have been suggested.
To take an often used analogy, one does not need to eat an entire fruit cake to gain an
idea of its taste a single slice will do that, although the larger the slice, the better it is.
The same is the case with the sampling method.
The researcher will not need to include all members of the target group of his or her study.
A subset will do, providing it has been selected carefully.
However, the usual rule is that the larger the subset selected, the higher the level
of accuracy to be expected in the findings from the sample survey.
Thus, in survey sampling, the margin of difference between the results from the sample and the
population values referred to as a sampling error is attributed primarily to the method
of sample selection and secondly, the size of the sample.
Methods of sample selection – As we have already discussed sampling methods, here
I am just going to tell you the names of various sampling methods or techniques.
The details of it can be studied in the module on sampling methods.
First, Probability Sampling Methods, second Simple Random Sampling Method, third is Systematic
Sampling, fourth is Stratified Random Sampling Method.
Then, in Non-Probability Sampling Methods we have Quota Sampling, Convenience Sampling
and Snowball Sampling.
The next process of survey research is the design of questionnaire.
A good questionnaire should include a mix of closed, open and scaled questions.
Furthermore, it will take into account the type of data to be collected and the resources,
time and money that are available for the study.
A good question is also one in which the questions that have been asked are well crafted and
are the product of careful consideration.
In designing the questionnaire, researcher should do their utmost to avoid the many pitfalls
that present themselves, including the use of ambiguous language, a language that is
not appropriate for the targeted audience, a prejudice language, a questions which lead
respondent to answer in the way that could result in biased data.
Of equal importance is the need to structure the questionnaire so that it aids the progression
of the interview.
Asking the question in a relatively logical order enables sensible flow to develop.
It should also be borne in mind that overly lengthy questionnaire are likely to put many
people off from the participating in a study.
It is important, therefore, to be concise and economic and the subject areas in a survey
as well as the language used in the actual questions.
Issues in conducting the sample surveys.
While the sample survey is the most commonly used research method within the social sciences,
it has been criticized on a number of level.
The first one, the logic of the sample survey.
Critics argue that the logic of the sample survey in attempting to isolate causal explanation
between different variables is in itself deficient.
Given the complexity of human consciousness and behavior, critics hold that survey researchers
will not be able to gain access to the process through which people adopt particular views
or act in a particular ways by simply posing a series of highly structured questionnaire.
Thus, collecting numerous items of information about the world of, for example, industrial
relation, and subjecting these two various statistical test in order to identify which
variable appears to have the highest degree of association with the key variable, industrial
dissent, fails to uncover.
The history of industrial relation in a particular organization.
What the working conditions are likely for employees, and how these experience may have
shaped the outlook and attitude of employees to new work practices that are being ont…
introduced by the management of the organization.
It may be that it is these very processes that have had the most significant effect
on industrial relation within an organization, but they may not be revealed in a questionnaire
survey that actively avoids two-way dialogue.
Second point is the value content of the surveys.
Another major criticism levelled at survey research is that, far from being an objective
method for dispassionately collecting `social facts`, it employs techniques which both reflect
and reproduce assumptions, that the researcher hold about the social world, and in particular
the phenomenon under investigation.
Thus, the structured format of the questionnaire-based study suggest that the researcher has made
certain choices about the overall research design, the issues which should and by implication
should not, be raised, and the format of the model of delivery, self-completion forms or interviews.
In this way, critics of the sample survey claim that the study, and its conclusion is
largely a function of the value and presupposition of the researcher.
Those who criticize survey from this perspective may advocate that the use of qualitative research
as an alternative in that such method are more likely to let the respondents speak for themselves.
Then, there is a lack of depth or cont… context.
Furthermore, because the question-and-answer employed are highly structured, respondents
are denied the opportunities to elaborate on issues especially those of a complex nature
or to qualify the answer given.
Thus, critics would claim that this failure to gain an holistic appreciation of a respondent’s
views concerning an issue or phenomenon inevitably results in only partial data, and fails to
tap into the reality which exists within the inner consciousness of the respondent.
The understanding and interpretation of questions.
At an epistemological level, the highly structured approach employed in questionnaire based studies
under undermines a researcher’s ability to ensure that the respondent’s understanding
and interpretation of the questionnaire is the is as intended by the researcher.
Obviously, if there is no correspondence between the researcher and the respondent in terms
of the meaning given to the questions posed, the researcher will be, the research will be invalidated.
Finally, conducting online surveys.
There are number of immediate advantage to adopting web-based surveys over postal service.
Perhaps the most obvious of which is the automation of the data collection.
As soon as the respondent submit their answer, the data are ready to be analyze.
This saves time and money, but also enables sample characteristics to be monitored as
as responses are received in a, in real time.
Every speculative analysis may also be carried out.
Completing an online form does, however, requires a certain amount of technical proficiency,
which might impact upon a respondent’s ability to… of willingness to participate.
Some researcher highlight the lack of conclusive evidence on studies which have attempted to
compare the response rate of online and traditional surveys, but others say that online survey
produce more complete data and fewer dropouts, and claim to be contradicts previous evidence
to the contrary.
Whether online surveys do indeed produce better response rate is difficult to gauge, but it
would seem that all of the standard issues already addressed in relation to respondent
raise such as questionnaire design, salience of the topic, and sending of reminder letters,
hold on hold for online survey as well.
In summary, online survey provide useful means of generating a large amount of data at relative
little cost, but special attention must be paid to the design of online forms and potential
bias in samples.
That said, online research does, through special discussion forum and social networking sites,
open up an opportunity to access global samples large enough for meaningful analysis, which
might not otherwise be possible.
Coming to the last type of survey method is Political Opinion Polls.
Opinion polls are the form of a social survey that differ only in terms of the subject areas
upon which they focus.
While social surveys are concerned with issues which might broadly be defined as `social
polls` investigating people's political beliefs, attitudes, opinions and behavior.
In terms of the method employed and general approach followed, opinion polls and social
surveys are broadly identical.
Generally, the performance of p… opinion polls in forecasting the share of voters achieved
by the different political parties general election is considered to be good.
Finally, I would like to conclude by saying that in this module we have discussed all
main quantitative method that are used in research, sample survey and experiment.
In particular, we have consider the usefulness and application at sample survey research.
We have seen that the logic of the quantitative research is to explain social phenomena, why
people behave in the way they do or hold certain views and values by reference to underlying causes.
This, this emphasis on the search for causal connections between different phenomena or
variables tends to steer researcher’s working within this tradition towards favoring highly
structured research approach and techniques such as experiments and questionnaire-based sample survey.
Quantitative approach, while comparatively dominant within the social sciences have attracted
significant criticism at both epistemological and technical level.
Largely, this criticism is levelled at the very structured nature of such methods, which
is claimed to prevent any opportunity for respondent to seek clarification over the
meanings of question that are asked and in turn to communicate their responses fully and clearly.
This is said to threaten seriously the validity of any such research product project.
Such critics would therefore dispute the extent to which survey research can provide an accurate
asme… assessment of people's view and behavior.
Hope now, the both the method that is quantitative method and qualitative method are clear to
you and you can go for your research and if you have any doubts, you can always write
us back and get your doubts clear.
Thank you so much.

After cases study, the last method that is commonly used is survey method. Survey method
is commonly used in social science and socio-legal research, where the objective of gathering
information is to seek the opinion, experience and feelings of the public at large as to

The term survey constitutes from two terms, one is ‘Sur’ which means over and ‘Veeir’

After that survey, the new method which is commonly used that is the scaling method.

This scaling technique is commonly used in the quantitative research. There is in qualitative research,

But the social scientists have evolved the technique by converting the qualitative data

After analyzing all methods involved in the data collection, we can say the pivotal of

data and appropriate techniques and tools requisite for that data in the light of objectives
and purposes of research. And the researcher should also be skilled and experienced as

I am Deepika Prakash from National Law University, Delhi and this presentation is about Report
In every research, in any field, there are certain basic steps that every researcher
has to take. First step that a researcher takes is defining a research problem.
Once he defines a research problem he goes on to review the available literature on the topic.
After reviewing the literature he goes on to formulate the hypothesis or the research
question as the case may be. Subsequently, he goes on to create a research design for
the entire research to be taken forward.
On the basis of this research design, he goes on to collect the data. This data once collected
Once the interpretation of data done, generalizations are drawn, the final step in the entire research
process is taken, which is making the report on the research.
the formal, logical presentation of the research conducted. No research is complete without
a research report. As the culmination of the research investigation, the report contains
within itself a logical and coherent explanation of the various stages of the research and
how the conclusion was arrived at.
Now it is made to convey to the interested per… persons the whole result of the study
in sufficient detail and to determine himself the validity of the conclusions that are drawn.
The ability to write an effective report is one of the most useful skills a researcher
can acquire. The arrangement of ideas and interpretation of the findings is of utmost
importance equivalent to the entire research process itself.
Now, what are the significance of a report? The first significance of a report is that
it conveys knowledge to the concerned persons in the field of research. Second, it properly
presents the findings for further utilization as well as recommendations. The report further
gives impetus to further research in a concerned knowledge area and it helps to reexamine the
validity of the generalization drawn by the researcher after the report has been submitted.
Now there are various kinds of reports depending upon the object of the report and the area.
There are business reports, project reports, there are dissertations, thesis, there are
various enquiry reports. There are also legal research reports. This presentation deals
with how a legal research report is written.
Now, what is a legal research report? It is a report which deals specifically with a legal
problem. Such a report is not a complete description of the work done by the researcher.
It is only a brief statement of the most significant facts that are necessary for the understanding
the generalizations drawn by the investigator.
Now, there are some basic guidelines for every report writing. First guideline that a report
writer must keep in mind is the knowledge of the research material. The writer must
have the comprehensive and adequate knowledge of the research area. It forms the backbone
of the entire research process and is of vital importance at the time of analysis and interpretation
of report writing.
Second guideline is organizing of the research material. The material collected must be organized
and the notes made on them manageable and properly arranged with sufficient information
which may be required. The research information must be logically analyzed and represented
in the correct sequence of time or occurrence.
Another guideline for the researcher is that he should do a continuous report reflective
thinking. Researcher constantly reflects on the material and the data collected for a
more comprehensive legal report. He should make rough drafts, which will help him with
research interpretation and generalization in a more accurate and relevant form and will
also help him test the research questions and the hypothesis.
Another guideline that a researcher must follow is to rewrite and polish rough drafts.
Careful revision of the drafts helps in checking the development of the arguments in the report,
representation of the material as well as the cohesiveness of the entire report.
Preparation of the final bibliography- It is essential that from the very beginning
of the research the researcher must maintain a blib… bibliography of the literature read,
consulted, and incorporated in the research process. This bibliography is generally appended
to the research project. It should be arranged alphabetically and be divided into various
parts like names of the books, articles, reports, and legislations consulted.
Another guideline that the researcher must follow is footnoting and headnotes. The researcher
must wherever citing another author’s work make due footnotes or end notes to add authenticity
and reference to the report. There are various methods of writing bibliography and footnotes
like the Bluebook method which is basically from the Harvard School and the Oscola method
which is of the Oxford School.
Now coming to the structure of a report, the following discussion is a of the structure
is a general discussion of any report not specifically a legal report. Pauline V Young
summarize the contents of a good report as following. First- introduction, the introduction
must be clear cut statements as to the nature of the study, aims, source of information
must be mentioned, scope of the study must be mentioned in the introduction and this
altogether will make an introduction of a report.
Second- Brief statement of the working hypothesis which guided the study. Third- Explicit definitions
of the units of study. Fourth- Brief statement of techniques used in the study, for example,
types of observations used and conditions under which observations were made, types
of schedules formulated and conditions under which information was secured, types of case
history data secured, their sources, manner of presentation, and preliminary analysis
Statistical procedure, sources of statistical data conditions under which they were obtained
and types of scaling techniques used. Fifth- Brief description of experimental treatment
of data and techniques in experiments.
Sixth- The major finding. Seventh- Major conclusions reached about findings. Eight- Special remarks,
for example, problems encountered in gathering the data, classifying them, analyzing them,
possible discrepancies in the data collected, then suggestions to subsequent investigators
on the same topic in the same context, bibliographical references found useful in the study with
annotations. Appendices might includes sample questions, transcriptions, sheets, sample
interviews, and the likes.
Now coming to a structure of a legal report, which is a topic of our presentation.
A sound legal report contains the following parts. First, there should be a preliminary part,
second, there should be the main body of the report, and third, the references.
Following is a brief description on all three of them.
Preliminary title- Here is an example of how the title page should be. The title page is
the cover of the report and the first thing that the targeted readers come in contact
with. It indicates the main theme or the title of the study. The title should always be appropriate
and attractive. The title page may also contain the name of the researcher and the date.
Then comes the preface or the acknowledgment. This contains the acknowledgment to all the
people whom the writer is indebted to for guidance and assistance.
Subsequently comes the table of cases which contains the list of cases cited within the
report. Then under preliminary comes the list of abbreviations. These are embodying all
the abbreviations used in the report subsequently with their full forms, then comes in the preliminary
part of the report the table of contents.
The table of content mentions the major division of the report and their respective page number
and finally comes the table of maps, diagrams, figures, etcetera, if they have been used
in the report.
Moving on to the main body of the report – The main text provides the complete outline of
the research report along with all details. Title of the research study is repeated at
the top of the first page of the main text and then follows the other details on the
pages numbered consecutively, beginning with the second page. Each main section of the
report should begin on a new page. The main text of the report should have the following sections.
Firstly, in the main body, there should be an introduction. The purpose of an introduction
is to give a background so as to make clear to the readers why the problem, the research
problem here was considered worth investigating. Then the main body should contain the methodology.
This represents the research design and method used in carrying out the research.
It should give exact meaning of the measurements or terms or variables used, selection of sampling,
universe selected tools of data collection, hypothesis, etcetera.
Next part of the main body is the review of literature. Here, the report writer assesses
the important and relevant already existing literature on the problem. The rationale of
the review is to develop upon the conceptual framework in the background of the research
which will become the source of formulation of the hypothesis subsequently.
Next part of the main body is a analysis and interpretation. This is the most crucial part
of the report. In it, the data which has been collected is processed, analyzed, and interpreted
and various generalizations and inferences are drawn. There must be clarity and continuity
in the presentation of the text and the result that follows in the main body.
The next part of the main body of the report is the findings and recommendations.
Under findings and recommendations, a detailed presentation of the findings of the study with supporting
data in the form of tables and charts together with the validation of result is the next
step in the writing of the main text of the report.
This generally comprises the main body of the report extending over several chapters.
All relevant results must find a place in this report. Towards the end of the main text,
the researcher should aim to put down the research, the results of his research clearly
and precisely. He should state the implication that flow from the result of the study.
It should then state the recommendations.
The next part of the main body of a legal research report is the conclusion or the summary.
The main text of the report must end with a summary of the report or the conclusions
drawn from the findings.
The final part is the references. References have appendices. Appendices should also be
enlisted in respect of old technical data such as questionnaire, sample information,
mathematical derivations, and the like ones. A simple appendix should be headed, appendix
in bold and centered on the page in capitals without punctuation and three lines space
below the heading. Each appendix is numbered and stated on a new page. Appendices should
be listed in the table of content together with page numbers. Appendices may be placed
between the final chapter and the bibliography or immediately after bibliography.
At the end of a legal research report all the consulted sources of data whether preliminary
or secondary, references, books, articles, reports, unpublished material, etcetera, must
be listed in a bibliography. The purpose of a bibliography is to provide cross-reference
as well as authenticity to the report. It should always be in an alphabetical order.
Now the style of writing bibliography depends upon whether there is already a prescribed
form as in the case of a dissertation or the thesis under a university or the researcher
can adopt any style. Some of the common ones are the Bluebook which is the Harvard form
of citation and the Oscola which is the Oxford University prescribed citation.
Now let’s go on to see how to cite legal material. Now in case of an authored book
by a single author, the citation must always be in this sequence, first the name of the
author, then the tile of the book, the page number, if referring to a specific page or
pages and then the publisher, along with the publisher, the name of publication, the edition
or the year of publication. Here is an example of it like M.P.Jain’s Indian Constitutional
Law has been cited here.
Coming to citation made of a book written by two authors. Now in this, the sequence
must be that the names of the authors are first mentioned, then the title of the book
along with the page number, if referring to a specific page or pages, then the publisher,
name of publication, the edition, the year of publication. Here is an example of it.
Now what happens when the multiple authors, let’s say more than two authors book is
being cited, under it the use of term ‘at all.’ is used, the name of the first author
is only mentioned and after his name the term ‘at all.’ is written, then the title of
the book, the page number if referring to a specific page or pages, and then the publisher,
place of publication, edition, year of publication. Here is an example of it.
Now, how to cite an edited book? When a book is edited by a single author then the name
of the editor is mentioned first along with it in bracket ‘ed.’ is mentioned, then
the title of the book, the page number if referring to a specific pages or page, then
the publisher, the place of publication, the edition, and the year. Following is an example
of such an edited book being cited.
Coming to case laws – Now, how one cites a case law. In India, we have number of journals
which report cases in various courts in India. The citation of case laws vary accordingly.
However, the broad citation idea is firstly the name of the case is mentioned, then the
journal name, for example, AIR Supreme Court cases, then the volume number, the year, the
court, and the page number. Following is the example of a case cited in the AIR and in SCC.
Now, how do we cite an act? The act is written in a research report aft… in its full form.
That is for example, if we are citing the Competition Act two thousand two, then we
mention it as the Competition Act two thousand two along with the serial number of the year
in which it was enacted that is Act twelve of the year two thousand three.
Now, when we are citing a report then we mention the authority whose report it is, number of
report, name and the year of publication. Like here in the example we have cited a report
of Law Commission, so we have written it as Law Commission of India, then the report number
which is one forty fourth report on conflicting judicial decisions pertaining to the code
of civil procedure, the year, and the page number.
Now, how do we cite an article or an essay? In a report, an article or an essay published
in a journal or a periodical is cited in such a form. First, the name of the author of the
article is mentioned, then the title of the essay within inverted commas, then volume
number of the journal, then name of the journal in abbreviations and then finally the page
number and in the bracket the year of publication. Here is an example of this.
Coming to citation of an editorial from a newspaper- How do we cite an editorial from a newspaper?
These are cited by firstly mentioning the title of the editorial within inverted
comma, the name of the newspaper and the date. Now, here is an example we have written “Short-circuited”
Times of India, August two is the date and the year of publication.
Now, how does one cite an unpublished work? For example, a thesis of a person, under it
the citation is written in such a form that firstly the name of the researcher is written,
then the title of dissertation or the thesis as the case may be along with the year in
which the thi… the thesis was written, then the unpublished Ph.D. thesis needs to write
the name of the university or the organization. Following is an example of it.
Now, how do we cite a website? If the website gives the information as to when it was last
modified then it must be cited. If not one must cite the date of the visiting of the
library. Here is the example of it, in case it has been modified then in the end of the
citation in the bracket we write last modified on such and such date and in case it has not
been modified or it is not mentioned then in the bracket we write visited on the date.
Now, there are certain precautions that one has to keep in mind while writing a report.
Following are these, first is the length of a report. The length of a report varies depending
on the nature and type of report. However, the researcher must keep in mind that the
report must not be too long otherwise the researcher, the readers of the research may
lose interest in it.
Second precaution that one should keep in mind while writing the report is that the
report must be interesting and engaging. The style and language of the report must be simple
yet able to maintain the interest of the readers.
Next precaution is the diagrammatic representation. The researcher must add graphs, charts, tables
or the various findings so that reader is able to quickly discern them. Another precaution
that must be kept in mind by the researcher while writing a report is preplanning of the
report. Keep the objectives of the research in mind. The researcher must preplan the layout
and the structure of the report for it to be in accordance with the nature, scope, and
finding of the research.
Next, it should be grammatically sound. The report must be free from grammatical and punctuational
errors. All footnotes, abbreviations, etcetera, must be clearly mentioned. The sixth precaution
that one should bear in mind while writing a report is maintaining logical flow throughout
the report. It is necessary for the clarity and better communication of the report that
there must be logical flow of the subject matter in the report without which it will
be difficult for the readers to decipher it.
Another precaution that must always be kept in mind by the researcher is that the report
must be under all cost original. Every report must strive to be as original in its research
findings, styles of presentation, and knowledge building. This contributes greatly to the
future legal research work in the same field.
Another precaution that is to be kept in mind is mentioned further implications of the report.
Towards the end of the report, the researcher must mention the further implications of the
said work like in the policy implementation or let’s say jurisprudential contribution, etcetera.
Another important precaution to be kept in mind at the time of writing a report is bibliography
must be comprehensive. Exhaustive bibliography must be mentioned at the end of the report.
Another objective, another precaution that must be kept in mind while writing a report
is the objectives, nature, technique, and limitations be stated.
In the introduction part of the report, the researcher must mention the objectives, scope,
nature, technique, tools as well as limitations of the research conducted. This makes the
report more wholesome as well as accurate.
In the conclusion of the report writing presentation, I would like to say that report writing is
the most important part of research. It is the end product of the entire research activity.
It communicates to the reader the research that has been communi…that has been conducted.
The report that has been prepared by him therefore must be always simple and coherent to justify
the findings and explain the research substantively. Hence, in this presentation we saw how to
write an effective report. Thank you.

Types of Resources – Law library primary acquires two types of sources of law, named
primary sources of law and secondary sources of law.
Primary sources of law – First, I will explain about primary sources of law. They are authoritative
publications of law produced by law making bodies. The most important component of primary
Primary sources of law legislation – Legislation is the act or laws or statutes made of parliaments.
They are basically Bills – A bill is a draft of law that parliament proposes to make.
Acts – An act is a statement of law approved by parliament.
Judgements – Judgements cases or decisions of the court, apex court, state courts, special
courts, tribunals and other subordinate courts are often published in law reports.
Under section three of Indian Law Reports Act eighteen seventy five, only the law reports
published under the authority of states are to be cited in courts. Some important law
reports are Supreme Court Reports, All India Reporter, Judgement Today and Supreme Court
cases for Indian Judgements. All England law reports for House of Lords and UK Supreme
Court judgements. Commonwealth Law Reports for High Courts of Australia Judgements.
These are some of the examples of law reports published in different countries.
Other important primary sources contains government departments, statutory authority committees,
agencies, tribunals and special enquires, publications, reports and information.
Government departments also issue annual reports which are useful in advanced legal research.
Law reform reports – Law reform agencies report on a number of areas which the aim
of improving and updating current legislation. The law commission of India under the ministry
of justice and law has been established for reforming the law for maximizing justice in
society and promoting good governance under the rule of law. Till date law commission
of India has produced two fifty one reports on various legal issues.
Now, we will discuss the secondary sources of law – Secondary sources provides commentaries
on law, though they are not binding on courts, but they help to find mandatory or persuasive
primary authority on a subjects. Some imo… important secondary sources are commentaries
on law, textbooks and treatises, legal periodicals, encyclopedias, digests and legal dictionaries.
by lawyers, academicians in which they describe the law arranged in orderly system, evaluate
and criticize it and suggest reforms. There are two main classes of materials of this
type textbook, treatises and legal periodicals.
Textbook and treatises – Textbook and treatises are comprehensive studies of a particular area of law.
Author will refer to the most important primary material on the subject,
leading cases, statutes and regulations. These work are the best means of acquiring a general
view of law before starting a major piece of research.
Legal periodicals – Legal periodicals contain collection of varied writings on the law published
at regular interval like monthly, quarterly, yearly, etcetera.
into major legal subject headings, covering either the entire field of law or a broad area.
For example, American Jurisprudence, Corpus Juries Scundum, fri… Forms and Presidents
abstracts of cases. For each case it provides a brief summary of the facts. The decision
of the court and perhaps a quotation from the reasons for judgement.
For example, All India Reporter yearly digests, Supreme Court cases yearly digests, common
Criminal Law digests and Labour Law digest.
Legal dictionaries – Legal dictionaries define both technical legal terms and common
authoritative definition of a particular important word or phrase has been given by the court.
Example, there are multivolume dictionaries of words and phrases specifically designed
to point out cases where particular word and phrase has been discussed.
Now, for the law library beginners, reference librarian encounters variety of information
queries when a new legal researcher enter in a law library, like how to start research?
How to find primary and secondary sources of law? What type of e-resources subscribe
by library and how to access them? Types of reference tool available in the library.
What is computer assisted legal research? What type of services are provided by a library?
To provide all the answers to relevant queries a law library design user education program.

Taxmann Online is leading publisher on taxes and corporate laws, accounting and auditing,

Now, we will discuss the citation of legal documents. A citation is referred to references
of published and unpublished sources for the purpose of uphold the intellectual honesty
and avoid plagiarism. There are many forms of citation system a researcher can adopt
for writing law subject material.
The most common are a Bluebook. A Bluebook is a uniform system of citation, a style guide
prescribed the most widely used legal citation system in United States. The Bluebook is compiled
by Harvard Law Review Association, the Columbia Law Review, the University of Pennsylvania,
the Law Review and Yale Law Journal. Currently it is in its nineteenth edition.
Another form of legal citation is Chicago Style, was developed and its guide is the
Chicago Manual of Style. It is the most widely used in history economics, as well as in social science subject.
MLA style was developed by Modern Language Association and is most often used in arts
and humanities, particularly in English studies, other literary studies including com… comparative
literature and literary in language other than English.
Equivalent citation is also known as parallel citation. It is a useful tool
to know the citation of same cases published in other reporting journal like AIR, SSC,
judgment Today, Supreme Court Reporter, Supreme Court Journal, etcetera.

Today we are going to learn about literature review under Research Methodology Module.
The topic of this unit is review of literature.
In this module we will learn about importance of literature review in research, features
of literature review, why literature review is included in a research or purpose of literature
review in research, various type of methods of collections of literature and presentation
of literature review, keep key aspects of literature review various steps to be considered
while doing literature review.
So, a literature is written record involved already settled theories of research in-depth
information about a topic, finding of experimental research, coordination of previous written
statements with the current findings and original set of thoughts of scholars, scientists and researchers.
Literature too include ancient manuscripts, religious and political writings and social
and economical statistics.
Research is based on a searching of new facts based on already established theories and
intellectual findings.
Literature in specific sense is set of information pertaining to research area or topic.
It may be original or first reshears, research published in a research academic journals,
research papers published in conference and seminars, historical documents and creative
or innovation literature pertaining to research topic.
Literature are too referred from secondary sources like reviews, commentaries, cri…
critical analysis, and evaluation report, digest, directories, encyclopedia and handbooks.
Tertiary sources like indexes and dic, directories are referral sources of literature which the
researchers have to refer at initial stage of research.
Research involves explanation of previous research to bridge the current research with
already established records.
The bridging of gap in research is performed through summarizing previous literature in
According to Hart, he elaborates literature review as a process where detailed summary
or critical evaluation or previous research and non-research literature pertaining to
current research problem is being studied and mentioned in the study.
Another thinker, Cornwell and Daly, they explained literature review has its primary goal to
update with current literature on the topic of research with historical evidence and to
justify future based on already established facts.
They further explain that a good literature review involves related studies from various
past and present source about a particular area of study with clear search and selection strategy.
The primary purpose of literature review is to facilitate detailed background of the previous
studies to the readers on a topic of research.
Literature review consist of several features like literature review facilitates new interpretations
of already established facts or correlate current with a previous interpretations.
Literature review helps in tracking intelli… int… intellectual continuance of the subject field.
Literature review knots evalu… evaluative and critic comments on literature on the subject
field which are very useful for future researchers.
Literature review in its concluding part involves comments for bridging the gap explaining how
