And today, I am going to discuss a new topic called Survey Method.
Survey Method is a very simple and common technique of data collection or research methodology.
So the learning objective in this module would be to understand this concept of Survey Methods
and then to see how many types of Survey Methods are there, what is the history behind it and
what kind of steps have been taken in conducting a survey.
Then there are various data collection techniques as well which are part of survey.
And finally, we are going to understand the advantages and disadvantages of this survey method.
So let us start with the concept of Survey Method.
There are a lot of ways of conducting a research and collecting information, but one of the
best ways I can tell you is the Survey Method.
A survey is defined as a brief interview or discussion with individuals about a specific topic.
The term survey is unfortunately a little vague, so we need to define it better.
The term survey is often used to mean ‘collect information’.
For instance, you might imagine a researcher or television scientist saying that we need to do a survey.
So, besides a definition above, survey also means to collect information.
We have our first definition of a brief interview and we have a second definition of collecting data.
The survey method is the technique of gathering data by asking questions to people who are
thought to have desired information.
A formal list of questionnaire is prepared.
Generally, a non-disguised approach is used.
The respondents are asked questions on their demographic interest opinion.
There is a difference between survey and a survey research.
Survey research is popularly identified by opinion polls and market research.
Whereas surveys, on the other hand, are also a defining feature of sociological research
and they form a part of anthropological inquiry too.
A numerical survey of some kind at some stage of social science research is quite a usual practice.
Often, the researchers map the physical universe before interpreting the universe.
They establish the typicality of what has been reported or observed and judge the authenticity
of correlation made during the course of research.
The reason for favoring the survey method and other quantitative technique is that survey
provides researcher a way to manage obtaining the data from large and complex societies.
Those studying social issues pertaining to urban areas, for example, the subject of migration
of rural population to industrial cities would carry out large scale social surveys of migration patterns.
They would use questionnaire as a research tool and process their data on computers.
The usefulness of survey is judged in the context of their purpose.
Generally, surveys serve the purpose of counting and classifying sets of events, opinions or other forms.
Quantification is involved in surveys which lends more reliability and accuracy to a large
quantity of information.
You can measure the usefulness of a survey in terms of objectiveness of your research.
We need to remember that you cannot gather all types of information by one method alone.
Further, different methods, for example, direct face-to-face questioning, inferring by observation
and counting heads through surveys offer different outcomes and quite often complement each other
to provide a more integrated set of data for interpretation and analysis.
Mitchell observed that quantitative methods are subordinate to qualitative research and
obtaining quantified data is only a means to reaching the understanding that is not
possible for statistics to capture.
All the same there has been a growing engagement in quantitative method.
As pointed out by Ellen, we need to make a distinction between what one is able to survey
and collect as facts and survey of facts as reported by respondents.
The first is a simple counting of items and the second is a counting of statement about items.
As opinions of respondents also are social fact, it is important to take note of them.
Placing such data the data the social context that taking the account of other kinds of
data, one can expect to achieve the objectives of obtaining scientifically reliable and accurate
information for further interpretation and analysis.
By other kinds of data, we mean “hard facts” provided, for example, by census material
and government surveys.
In all surveys, we need to look carefully at the way of information gathering as well
as the way of its interpretation.
Most useful surveys employ the strategy of first knowing the field from the close quarters
through intensive fieldwork that offers the opportunity of close contact with people.
Only then it becomes possible to frame relevant questions to go in the questionnaire.
For getting the respondents to cooperate in filling the questionnaire, it is important
to publicize the survey and establish prior contact with the respondent.
So, social science research techniques are often classified into two categories, namely
quantitative and qualitative.
Qualitative research enables us to understand the subtle aspects of social relations.
They are particularly useful when one is interested in probing a specific question in depth, its
meaning and the different interpretation.
However, qualitative method also have their limitation.
They are, for example, most suitable when research is being carried out in a small setting
or in a focused or a specific group or community.
Qualitative research methods are not very useful when we need to know about macro phenomena,
such as the demographic structure of a population or the extent and nature of poverty, disease.
Quantitative method or survey research enables us to study these questions in a more comprehensive manner.
Depending upon the requirement, survey research can be extended to a large an area of population
as a whole nation or even the entire world.
Thus, when the universe of study is large and the researchers are looking for broad
trends or patterns in a given population, they often resort to survey methods.
In other words, qualitative and quantitative research methods are not oppo… opposite to each other.
They are complementary.
The two can be combined one enriching the other.
Data collection through surveys involves persuasion of respondents and then on some level social
interaction between the respondents and the research interviews.
A team of efforts or many people having diverse skills is required.
Surveys are now used in all areas of life.
For example, business, politics, agriculture, industry, education, and media.
So, when did actually this survey came as a technique?
Let us go back to the history of the survey method.
Though systematically carried out surveys have a short history, rulers in the past have
always been interested in finding out what was going on in their states and the conditions of their subjects.
There are umpteen stories of rulers or their representatives going to meet the public,
sometimes incognito, within the explicit intent of enquiring about their welfare and any seeds of discontent.
This was considered extremely important for proper rule.
In ancient times, roman empire polled surveys of the citizens.
The Victorian social reforms understood surveys and interviewed ten to twenty thousand persons
for seeking an adequate representation of opinion.
These early social researchers quantified the income, hours and conditioning of work,
housing, standard of living, size of family and dwelling, frequency of sickness, leisure
activities and club and union membership of Britain's poor.
However, survey research in its systematic form began after the Industrial Revolution
and urbanization of Europe.
Karl Marx was perhaps the first social scientist to collect information from some key informants
about the condition of industrial workers and tried to relate it to the theory of class
society and class struggle.
On the basis of such data, he also tried to quantify worker’s exploitation in terms
of working hours and wages.
An important development in the evolution of sample survey method was the introduction
of public opinion polls.
The Gallup Organization introduced public opinion polling into Britain in nineteen thirty-seven,
and nineteen forty six saw the formation of the Market Research Society in Britain.
The impetus for social-survey-style research after the Second World War was maintained
by the increased role of government with the advent of the welfare state and by the expansion
of the social sciences in further and higher education.
Sample survey played an important role in academic circle by providing social science
researcher with the means for collecting large scale data about different aspects of social life.
Now, as we have understood the history of survey method, let us go back and understand
that why there is a need for survey method.
So, survey method can be used to provide someone with information to describe the situation
or to explain the situation or to, or in identifying the problems and solving them.
It also helps in measuring the change.
It not only studies the attitude but also the behavior and habits of the people.
It examines the cause and effect relationship.
It studies the characteristics of a phenomena, formulates a hypothesis, tests a hypothesis
and then helps in decision making.
Sample surveys are conducted in order to provide the researcher or the sponsor of the researcher
with statistical information, either on a particular issue or problem that needs to be resolved.
This involves me… measuring various phenomena and drawing conclusion about any relationship
between them to establish pattern of cause and effect.
For instance, in a study of industrial relations, we might compare different workplace in terms
of a number of variables that that we hypothesize are likely to be associated with the industrial dissent.
This might be the size of the firm or organization, the type of industry, the inclusiveness of
the decision making or whether the organization is unionized or not, the skill level of the
employees, the gender mix within the organization, the balance between part-time and full-time
employees and the employ… unemployment rate in the local area and so on.
To analyze such relationship and draw widespread conclusion requires the researcher to generate
large amount of data so that conclusions can be generalized from the sample surveys to
the wider population from which the survey respondents were drawn.
In order to have confidence in the results generated from a sample survey and to eliminate
or minimise bias, the researcher should aim to maximize the response rate and in doing
so ensure that the study is representative of the population group.
Now let us understand the various types of surveys.
The first one is the Descriptive Survey.
A descriptive survey attempts to picture or document current conditions or attitude that
is to describe what exists at the moment.
Examples are Audience survey to determine the program program taste.
To study the changes, values, lifestyles and the effect of some special type of program.
Then, there is Analytical survey.
An analytical survey attempts to describe and explain why certain situation exist.
There we examine two or more variable to test or research hypothesis.
Example could be how lifestyle affects the TV viewing habits imp… or impact of war
games on teenagers.
Some more type of surveys are factual surveys, that is respondents act as reporters.
Then, opinion surveys where respondents express his views, point of opinion.
Then there are interpretative surveys where the interpretations are done.
For example, why do you read newspaper?
Then, there are steps in the process of survey.
The very first step is the Research Step and the in research step we develop hypothesis,
we decide on type of surveys like whether it is going to be mail, interview, telephone, etcetera.
Write survey questionnaires, decide on response category and design the layout.
Then, there is the step two, that is plan how to record the data.
In this, we will pilot test survey instrument.
We will revise the instrument.
And then there will be third step that is deciding on the target population under which
we will get the sample frame, decide on sampling size and sele… select a sample.
Then, we enter the data into computer where we will be rechecking all the data, perform statistical analysis.
Then, we have the step four, where we will locate the respondents, conduct interviews,
carefully record the data.
And after that, we enter into the, data into the computers, recheck all the datas, perform
statistical analysis of the data.
Step six would be describing methods and findings in research reports.
We will be presenting findings to others for critique and evaluation.
Sample surveys are a method of gathering information by means of personal interviews or questionnaire.
They are sometimes referred to as ‘mass interviews’ because they are a way of collecting
similar information from a large number of people at the same time.
Sample surveys are based on standardized approaches using standardized instruments, such as questionnaire.
These research instruments employ fixed question-and-answer format so that there is a consistency of data
collection approach regardless of who is actually asking the questions.
The sample survey is therefore akin to a structured dialogue between usually two people, in which
the researcher ask a series of pre-planned standard questions and the respondent’s
answer are recorded precisely on a form and ultimately turn into a number for statistical analysis.
In this way, the studies are said to be quantitative.
The uses of survey.
Academic researcher conduct surveys to test out various research hypothesis.
For example, they may want to explore the relationship between age and political conver…
conservatism or why is it some of the children play truant from schools or under what circumstances
people become addicted to gambling.
By gathering statistical evidence, survey research may help to support a particular
theory by shedding light on the connections and association that exist between such variables.
In this way, researchers look for patterns that may explain social phenomena.
Academians are not the only ones who use survey research.
Other uses of surveys can be broadly categorized as follows- First, government and its agencies,
voluntary sector’s organizations and campaigning groups use survey research to inform and influence
the political, economic and social policies making processes.
Business of all sizes carry out surveys in their quest for gaining a lead in the market
for their products by differentiating their product against those of their competitors.
The media and political parties carry out public opinion polls on voting intentions,
partly political leaders and their politics.
Survey research can be used to obtain multifaceted data from an individual.
For example, behavior, straightforward questions on what the respondent has done, is doing
and may do it in the future.
For example, is it possible to ask people if they use public transport for certain journeys
or if they are vegetarian?
Survey research can be used in understanding the belief system, that is what people think will happen.
What do they believe is true or false?
Do people believe that the National Health Service is safer in the hands of the current
government than it was under the previous administration?
Then survey also helps in understanding the attitudes of the people, how people think
and feel about certain things.
For example, whether people con… consider that women with pre-school children should
participate in their workforce.
And survey also helps in understanding the attributes, these are the personal questions
that concern the characteristics of the respondents, such as her her or his age, sex, ethnicity,
religion and employment status.
As such, these questions have the potential to be viewed as sensitive questions.
They are often referred to as classification questions.
By employing a combination of such questions in a survey, the skillful researcher opens
up the possibility of describing and explaining complexities of social phenomena.
A very important part of survey is sampling method.
Sampling has been dealt as a separate module.
Here we will have a basic idea of sampling in survey.
Sampling is a method that identifies a representative number from a given universe population.
There are two basic properties of a sample.
One is it should be adequate.
The second is it should be representative of the universe, that is the entire population.
The most crucial point on a sampling is to make sure that one's personal values do not
influence the selection procedure.
In order to keep out the researcher’s bias, various techniques or procedure of seeking
a sample have been suggested.
Then let us understand the various methods of data collection under the survey method.
There are four main types of the data collection method for a social survey.
The face-to-face interview where the respondent is questioned in person by an in… interviewer.
The main advantage of this method is that it is usually, it usually results in a ret…
relatively high response rate.
However, such interviews commonly incurs high cost due to the number of interviews that
need to be employed, and it is also argued that the personal interaction between the
interviewer and the res… respondent can lead to a biased responses.
In a study that considers questions of child discipline and punishment, it may be that
respondent will offer the socially acceptable responses, the answer and the answers that
they believe the interviewer wants to hear.
Postal questionnaires are widely used because they are relatively cheaper to administer
and they enable coverage of a wide geographical area.
Also, given that they avoid direct personal contact, they have the advantage at ensuring
a degree of privacy for the respondent.
The main disadvantage associated with postal questionnaire is that they that they perform
poorly in relation to response rate.
Telephonic interviews is the another technique.
They have become more common in the past decades as technological advances have allowed researcher
to draw sample with greater accuracy.
They are also very quickly quick to administer.
However, they are limited to researchers who have access to the relevant technology such
as random digital dialing technology to carry them out.
Online surveys which are delivered by email or make use of web based form in place of
a questionnaire are now widely used.
They share some of the characteristics of the postal surveys, in that they are inexpensive
to administer, but they may have lower response rate than interviewer administrating the surveys.
Access to data, the instant responses is sent and being able to draw sample on a global
scale are also attractive benefits, but the difference between the characteristics at
internet users and non-user can result in Internet-based samples which are not representative
at the general population.
Once the data have been collected, the researcher have to codify and proc… process the data
in a manner that it becomes presentable in the tabular form and charts.
It should also become accessible for use of statistical treatment that would tell us about
the different qualities of the data.
Each of these methods of data collection has its own strengths and weaknesses in relation
to design, cost, and so on, and in crude terms one`s weaknesses are often the other’s strength.
The method that is selected will depend on the type of population you aim to research,
the nature of the research question and the resources at your disposal.
The advantages of survey method, as compared to the other methods, direct observation,
experimentation, survey yields a broader range of information.
Surveys are effective to produce information on socio-economic characteristics, attitudes,
opinions, motives etcetera and to gather information for planning, product feature, advertising
media, sales promotion, channels of distributing and other marketing variables.
Questioning is usually faster and cheaper than the observation.
Question… questions are simple to administer and data is reliable.
The variability of result is reduced.
It is relatively simple to analyze, quote and interrelate the data obtained by survey method.
Survey research is useful in describing the characteristics of a large population, demographic
structure of a population and its emerging trends and patterns.
Survey research can be administered from remote locations using mails, emails or telephones.
Consequently, very large samples are feasible, making the results statistically significant
even when analysis analyzing multiple variables.
In survey research, one can ask many questions about a given topic, which gives considerable
flexibility to the analysis.
We can choose different ways of administering surveys.
From face-to-face interview to telephone and e-mails one can use any mode of collection
of data depending on one’s requirement and limitations.
Unlike the qualitative methods, survey method is carried out through standardized questions,
which make measures more precise by enforcing uniform definition upon the participants.
Standardizations ensure that similar kind of data are collected from groups and then
interpreted comparatively implying more objectively and higher reliability.
We have discussed the advantages of survey method.
Let’s now also look at the disadvantages of this method.
The first disadvantage is unwillingness of respondent to provide information.
This requires salesmanship on the part of the interviewer.
The interviewers may assure that the information will be kept secret or apply the technique
of offering some presence.
Inability of the respondent to provide information.
This may be due to lack of knowledge, lapse of memory, inability to identify their motives
and provide reason, why? for their actions.
Human bias of the respondents are there.
For example, “Ego”.
Symantec difficulties are there.
It is difficult if not impossible to state a given question in such a way that it will
mean exactly same thing to each respondent.
Similarly, two different wordings of the same question will frequently produce quite different results.
A preoccupation with standardization result in designing questions in every general term
to make them minimally appropriate for all respondent.
This could lead to simplification and one may end up missing what may be most appropriate
to many respondent.
Survey research is inflexible in the sense that it requires a precise study design.
Everything must be worked out in advance, the tools to be used and the method of administering the tools.
In order to make survey method logically sound, it should remain unchanged throughout the
period of data collection.
In order to make a survey viable and meaningful, the researcher has to make sure that a large
po… proportion of selected respondent agree to respond.
This, however may not always be an easy task to achieve.
In such a situation, carrying out a survey becomes very difficult.
Surveys also demand a great deal of attention and honesty on the part of the respondent,
particularly when a questionnaire is being used and the survey is self-administered.
Respondents may not always be willing to give such attention to filling the questionnaire.
Sometimes, it may be hard for participant to recall certain information or to take clear
position of, on controversial issues.
Another problem with the survey research is that it is invariably context-blind.
However, in the social world, context and the environment in which questions are being
asked and answers give given is very important.
For example, the response of a female respondent being asked questions about gender equality
in their home, in the presence of her husband and other family members may be very different
from the same question asked at her workplace where she is employed.
Survey research can rarely see the question of context.
As we have seen the advantage and disadvantage of survey method, let us also see how we can
overcome these limitations.
So, the, to overcome survey limitation, we have to carefully frame and phrase the questions.
Careful control of data gathering by employing specially trained investigators who will observe
carefully report on subtle reactions of the persons interviewed.
Cautious interpretation by a clear recognition of the limitations of the data and understating
of what exactly the data represents.
This is especially true for responses to questions like, what price would you be willing to pay for this product?
Looking at the facts in relative rather than absolute terms, for example, a survey by a
dentist team showed that the number of families in the middle income group used toothpaste
taken by itself in the absolute sense, the result of the survey are in some doubt.
Even though the individual group readings shall differ, say for example, for upper income
group families it could be ninety percent.
Hence, we should look at the facts in relevance rather than in absolute terms.
So, to conclude the survey method, we can say that the survey is a type of research
to collect the data and facts and some certain situation or issues from the target population
existing in surroundings having relevance to the nature of study.
A survey research is the research strategy to study the relationship and characteristics.
They are based on the desire to collect information usually by questionnaire about a well-defined
issue or situation like a hypothesis from the well-defined population.
Surveys are the method of data collection from which information is gathered through
oral or written questioning.
No matter which approach is chosen to collect data, it is impossible to get hundred percent response rate.
All types of surveys have advantage and disadvantage.
In some of them, the researcher have more control over the situation.
For example, the respondents can be influenced or get clues from interviews to respond in certain ways.
In other cases, respondents try to act smart and mislead the researcher.
Though survey method suffers some drawbacks, still it is considered to be one of the best
method of data collection.
And thus, it is the most popular method of data collection.
So, students, hope this concept is clear to you.
And if you have any doubts or any questions, you can write back to me and have a good study time.

Dear Students, I am Doctor Ritu Sharma, I’m an Assistant Professor at National Law University,Delhi.
Today we are going to discuss an important module from Research Methodology - Hypothesis.
While discussing the module we’ll be talking about the meaning and definition of
hypothesis, the nature of hypothesis, the importance and use of hypothesis in research methodology.
We’ll also look into the sources of hypothesis, the relationship between variables and hypothesis,
the types of hypothesis and ending the presentation with characteristics of a good hypothesis,
hypothesis testing and errors in hypothesis testing.
So, while we discuss what is hypothesis, we should start with the meaning of it.
Hypothesis is usually considered as an important mechanism in research.
Hypothesis is a tentative assumption made in order to test its logic or empirical consequences.
If we go by the origin of the word, it is derived from the Greek word Hypotithenai,
meaning to ‘put under’, or ‘to suppose’.
Etymologically hypothesis is made up two words ‘Hypo’ and ‘Thesis’ which means less
than or less certain than a thesis.
It is presumptive statement of a proposition or reasonable guess based upon the available
evidence which the researcher seeks to prove through his study.
A hypothesis will give a plausible explanation that will be tested.
A hypothesis may seem contrary to the real situation, it may prove to be correct or incorrect.
Hypothesis is needed to be clear and precise and capable of being tested.
It is to be limited in scope and consistent with known or established fact and should
be ameable to testing within the stipulated time.
It needs to explain what it claims to explain and should have empirical reference.
Goode and Hatt have defined it as ‘a proposition which can be put to test to determine its
validity’ and Lundberg says ‘A hypothesis is a tentative generalization, the validity
of which remains to be tested’.
In most elementary stage, the hypothesis may be any hunch, guess, imaginative idea
which becomes the basis for action or investigation.
Hence, a hypothesis is a hunch, assumption, suspicion, assertion or an idea about a phenomenon,
relationship or situation, the reality of or truth of which you do not know.
So, a researcher calls these assumptions or hunches hypotheses and they become the basis
of an enquiry.
In most studies, the hypothesis will be based upon your own or someone else observation.
Hypothesis brings clarity and specificity to a research problem.
But it is not essential for all kinds of research.
So, the formul… the formulation of the hypothesis provide a study with the focus.
It also tells you what specific aspect of a research problem to investigate.
A hypothesis tells you what data to collect and what not to collect thereby providing
focus to the study.  41 00:03:38,180 -->  00:03:44,890 As it provides a focus, the construction of a hypothesis enhances objectivity in a study.
A hypothesis may enable you to add to the formulation of a theory.
It enables you to specifically conclude what is true or what is false.
Lundberg observes, quite often a researcher hypothesis is a predictive statement, capable
of being tested by scientific methods, that relates an independent variable to some dependent variable.
So, once we know what actually hypothesis mean, we should also understand the nature of hypothesis.
The hypothesis is a clear statement of what is intended to be investigated.
It should be specified before research is conducted and openly stated in reporting the results.
This allows to, One, identify the research objectives.
Second, to identify the key abstract concepts involved in the research.
Three, to identify its relationship to both the problem statement and the literature review,
and a problem cannot be scientifically solved unless it is reduced to hypothesis form.
It is powerful tool to of advancement of knowledge consistent with existing knowledge and conducive
to further enquiry.
It can be tested, verifiable or falsifiable.
Hypothesis are not moral or ethical questions.
It is neither too specific nor too general.
It is a prediction of consequences.
It is considered valuable even it proven false.
Once we have understood the hypothesis, the nature of hypothesis.
Why is it so important in a research?
So, toda… now we are going to discuss the importance of hypothesis.
So, hypothesis though an important part of research may not be required in all
types of research.
The research which are based on fact finding like historical or descriptive do not need hypothesis.
Hillway says that, “When fact finding alone is the aim of the study, a hypothesis is not required.”
Whenever possible, a hypothesis is recommended for all major studies to explain observed
facts, conditions or behavior and to serve as a guide in the research process.
Hypothesis facilitates the extension of knowledge in an area.
They provide tentative explanations of facts and phenomena and can be tested and validated.
It sensitize the inv… investigator to certain aspects of the situations which are relevant
from the standpoint of the problem in hand.
Hypothesis provide the researcher with rational statement consisting of elements expressed
in a logical order or relationship which seeks to describe or to explain conditions or events
that have not yet been confirmed by the facts.
The hypothesis enable the researcher to relate logically known facts to inlletual… intelligible
guess about unknown conditions, it is a guide to the thinking process and the process of discovery.
Hypothesis provide direction to the research, it defines what is relevant and what is irrelevant,
the hypothesis tells the researcher what he needs to do and find out in his studies.
Thus, it prevents the review of irrelevant literature and provides a basis for selecting
the sample and the research procedures to be studied in the study.
Hypothesis implies the statistical techniques needed in the analysis of data and the relationship
between the variables to be tested.
It also helps to delimit researchers study in scope so that it does not become broad or unwieldy.
Hypothesis provides the basis for reporting the conclusion of the study, it serves as
a framework for drawing conclusions.
In other words, we can say that it provides the outline for setting conclusion in a meaningful way.
So, hypothesis has very important place in research although it occupies a very small
place in the body of a thesis.
So, once we are done the importance of hypothesis, we should also be seeing that how we can actually derived hypothesis.
A good hypothesis can only be derived from experience and research.
Though hypothesis should precede the co… collection of data, but some degree of data
collection, literature review or a pilot study will help in the development and gradual refinement of the hypothesis.
A researcher should have quality of an alert mind to derive a hypothesis and quality of
critical mind of rejecting faulty hypothesis.
The following sources can help the researcher in coming up with a good hypothesis.
One, review of literature.
Review of literature is very important in forming a hypothesis because you get an idea
of what type of hypothesis you need to achieve your objectives and discussion with the experts
in the given field to understand the problem, its origin and objective in seeking a solution
will also help you in forming a very good hypothesis.
Intuitions of the researcher also sometimes help in forming a good hypothesis because
you always have an idea what you are looking for in your research and that actually helps
in forming a good hypothesis.
Previous empirical studies done on the given area also gi… become a very good source
for hypothesis when you go through the previous researchers that actually gives an idea what
you have to look into when you are conducting your own research.
Once we know the sources of hypothesis and we have formulated the hypothesis we should
also understand what all types of hypothesis are there in research.
So research problems are too general by themselves to enable us to carry out meaningful analysis,
they need to be specified in a more focused way.
Hypothesis are specific statement that relate to the problem, the answer to which are likely
to be yes or no depending upon what is uncovered from the research, like suicide is related
to general level of religiosity or secularization of society.
Another example could be alienation and political participation are negatively related.
Such statements specify links between different phenomena, in order to explain different pattern
of behavior that appear to occur, such statement specify links between different phenomena
in order to explain different pattern or behavior that appear to occur.
However, such pattern or association do not necessarily demonstrate that a causal relationship exist.
We cannot for an instance say ‘socio economic deprivation causes suicide.’
If that was the case then all those who defined by various yardstick as living in a state
of relative poverty would inevitably commit suicide.
This is very unlikely to happen.
So, we if we have to understand types of hypothesis, we do need to understand what are the variables
that actually affect these types of hypothesis.
So, to understand the type of hypothesis, we need to understand the concept of variable first.
The variables are empirical properties that take two or more values or in other words
a variable is any entity that can take on different values.
Its, in simple terms, anything that can vary or that is not constant can be considered a variable.
For instance age can be considered a variable because age can take different values for
different people or for the same person at different times.
Similarly, country can be considered a variable because person’s country can be assigned a value.
A variable is a concept or abstract idea that can be described in measurable term.
In research this term refers to the measurable characteristics, qualities, traits or attributes
of a particular individual object or situation being studied.
Variables differ in many respects, most notably in the role that they are given in our research
and in the type of measure that can be applied to them.
The restatement of problem usually provides only general direction for the research study.
It does not include all the specific information.
There is some basic terminology that is extremely important in how we communicate specific information
about research problem and research in general.
So, weight, height, income all are examples of variables.
In research there is a need to make distinction between various kinds of variables.
There are many classifications given for variables.
We’ll try to understand only the dependent variables and independent variables.
Independent variables - The variables which are manipulated or controlled or changed,
these are also known as manipulated variables.
Researchers often mistake independent variable and assume that it is independent of any manipulation.
It is called independent because variable is isolated from any other factor.
In research we try to determine whether there is a cause and effect relationship.
In fact, when you are looking for some kind of relationship between variables you are
trying to say if the independent variable causes some kind of change in the other variable
or dependent variable.
And now we are going to discuss what is dependent variable.
Dependent variables are the outcome variables and are the variables for which we calculate statistics.
The variables which change on account of independent variable is known as dependent variables.
It is something that depends on the other factors.
For example, a test score could be dependent variable because it could change depending
on the several factor such as how much you studied, how much sleep you got the night
before you took the test or even how hungry your were when you took it.
Usually when you are looking for relationship between the two things you are trying to find
out what makes the dependent variable change the way it does.
As we have discussed that a variable is an image, perception or concept that can be measured,
hence, capable of taking on different values.
The variables that you wish to explain are regarded as dependent variable or criterion variables.
The other variables expected to explain the change in the dependent variable is referred
to as an independent variable or predictor variable.
The dependent variable is the expected outcome of the independent variable and independent
variable produces dependent variable.
So variables can have three types of relationships among themselves.
A positive relationship is one where an increase in one would lead to increase in the other.
For example, more you study higher your score would be.
A negative relationship is one where an increase in one variable leads to decrease in the other.
More you watch TV, less marks you are going to get.
A zero relationship is one which shows no significant relationship between the two variables.
For example, having any kind of food will not fetch you marks.
These are the type of relationship which variables have.
So, once we have understood variables we can discuss the various type of hypothesis.
One, first one is the research hypothesis.
The research hypothesis could be understood in terms of simple research hypothesis and
complex research hypothesis.
A simple research hypothesis predicts the relationship between a single independent
variable and a single dependent variable where as a complex hypothesis predicts the relationship
between two or more independent variable and two or more dependent variable.
A research hypothesis must be stated in a testable form for its proper evaluation and
it should indicate a relationship between variables in clear, concise and understandable language.
Research hypothesis are classified as being directional or non-directional.
A directional hypothesis are usually derived from theory.
They may imply that the researcher is intellectually committed to a particularly outcome.
They specify the expected direction of the relationship between variables that is the
researcher predicts not only the existence of a relation but also its nature.
Non-directional hypothesis on the other hand are used when there is little or no theory
or when findings of previous studies are contradictory.
They may imply impartiality.
Do not stipulate the direction of the relationship.
another types of association are associative hypothesis and causal hypothesis.
Associative hypothesis propose relationship between variables, when one variable changes
the other changes, they do not indicate cause and effect, whereas the causal hypothesis
proposes a cause and effect interaction between two or more variables.
The independent variable is manipulated to cause effect on the dependent variable.
Then there is a statistical hypothesis to test whether the data support or refute the research hypothesis.
It needs to be translated into a statistical hypothesis.
It is given in statistical terms.
In the context of inferential statistics, it is statement about one or more parameters
that are measures of the population understudy.
Now, we need to understand what is this inferential statistics?
Inferential statistics is used for drawing conclusions about population values.
To use inferential statistics we need to translate the research hypothesis into a testable form,
which is called the null hypothesis.
A testable hypothesis contains variables that are measurable or able to be manipulated.
They need to predict a relationship that can be supported or not supported based on the
data collection and analysis.
So, now we come to a very important types of hypothesis which is called as null hypothesis
and alternative hypothesis.
Null hypothesis are used when the researcher believes that there is no relationship between
two variables or when there is inadequate theoretical or empirical information to state
a research hypothesis.
The null hypothesis represents a theory that has been put forward either because it is
believed to be true or because it is to be used as a basis for argument but has not been proved.
This has serious outcome if incorrect decision is made and null hypothesis are designed
by either HO or HN.
A null hypothesis can be simple or complex or associative or causal, which we have already seen.
The alternative hypothesis is a statement of what a hypothesis test is setup to establish.
It is designated by H one or HA.
It is opposite of null hypothesis, it is only reached if HO is rejected.
Frequently alternative is actual desired conclusion of the researcher, they give special consideration
to the null hypothesis.
This is due to the fact that a null hypothesis relates to the statement being tested, whereas
the alternative hypothesis relates to the statement to be accepted if when the null
is hypothesis is rejected.
The final conclusion – Once the test has been carried out is always given in terms
of the null hypothesis.
We either reject null hypothesis in favor of the alternative hypothesis or do not reject null hypothesis.
We never conclude reject alternative hypothesis or even accept alternative hypothesis.
If we conclude do not reject null hypothesis, this does not necessarily mean that the null
hypothesis is true, it is only suggest, it only suggest that there is not sufficient
evidence against null hypothesis in favour of alternative hypothesis.
Rejecting the null hypothesis then suggest that alternative hypothesis maybe true.
For example, alternative hypothesis – the males visited cinema more than females and
the null hypothesis – the males and females do not differ in respect of the frequency
of seeing the cinema.
So, alternative hypothesis is usually the one which one wishes to prove and the null
hypothesis is the one with one wishes to disapprove.
And now once we are done with the types of hypothesis.
Let's understand how hypothesis is formulated because that is the most important concept in research.
There are no precise rules for formulating hypothesis and deducing consequences but there
are some difficulties that arise in formulating the hypothesis.
However, there are certain necessary conditions that are conducive to the formation.
They are for example, richness of background knowledge, in the absence of knowledge concerning
a subject matter, one can make know well founded judgment of relevant hypothesis.
Background knowledge is essential for perceiving relationship among the variables and to determine
what finding other researcher have reported on the problem under study.
New knowledge, new discoveries and new inventions should always form continuity with the already
existing corpus of knowledge and therefore it becomes all the more essential to be well
versed with the already existing knowledge.
Hypothesis can be formulated correctly by person who have rich experience and academic
background but they can never be formulated by those who have poor background knowledge.
There is another point which is very important in formulating hypothesis, logical and scientific approach.
Formulation of proper hypothesis depends on one's experience and logical insights.
Hypothesis does not have a clear cut and definite theoretical background.
Partly it is a matter of lifting upon an idea on some problem and it is not always possible
to have complete information of an acquaintance with the scientific method for formulating hypothesis.
This lack of scientific knowledge presents difficulty in formulation of hypothesis.
A researcher may begin a study by selecting one of the theories in his own areas of interest
and deduce a hypothesis from this theory through logic which is possible only when the researcher
has a proper understanding of the scientific method and has a versatile intellect.
At times, conversations and consultations with colleagues and experts from different
fields are also helpful in formulating important and useful hypothesis.
And now once we know how to formulate a hypothesis there are few things that need to be kept
in mind in forming a hypothesis, and tha… they are called as the characteristics of good hypothesis.
Hulley says a good hypothesis must be based on a good research question.
It should be simple, specific and stated in advance.
So, a hypothesis could be called as a good hypothesis if it possesses the following characteristics.
One, hypothesis should be simple so that it is easily understood by everyone.
Two, hypothesis should be clear, specific and precise.
If the hypothesis is not clear and precise, the inference drawn on its basis cannot be
taken as reliable.
Hypothesis should be capable of being tested.
Hypothesis should state relationship between variables.
Hypothesis should be consistent with most known facts that is it must be consistent
with substantial body of essential facts.
The hypothesis must explain the facts that gave rise to the need of explanation.
It must actually explain what it claims to explain and once if we keep these points in
mind we are going to formulate a very good hypothesis.
So, a very important thing, when we are forming a hypothesis we should also know how to test a hypothesis.
When the purpose of the research is to test a research hypothesis, it is termed as hypothesis
testing research.
It can be of experimental design or non-experimental design.
Research in which the independent variable is manipulated is termed as experimental hypothesis
testing research and a research in which an independent variable is not manipulated is
called as non-experimental hypothesis testing research.
As we have discussed then null hypothesis and alternative hypothesis earlier, so while
testing the hypothesis we generally proceed on the basis of null hypothesis, keeping the
alternative hypothesis in view.
We do so because on the assumption that null hypothesis is true one can assign the probabilities
to different possible sample results but this cannot be done if we proceed with the alternative
hypothesis.
Hence, the use of null hypothesis is quite frequent.
While testing the hypothesis the following things have to be kept in mind.
First, the level of significance.
This is a very important concept in the context of hypothesis testing.
It is always some percentage usually five percent which should be chosen with great
care and thought and reason.
In case we take the significance level at five percent then this implies that null hypothesis
will be rejected when the sampling result has a less than zero point zero five probability of occurring.
In other words these five percent level of significance means that researcher is willing
to take as much as of five percent risk of rejecting the null hypothesis when it happens
to be true.
Thus, the significance level is the maximum value of the probability of rejecting null
hypothesis when it is true and is usually determine in advance before testing the hypothesis.
The criteria for rejecting the null hypothesis may differ.
Sometimes the null hypothesis is rejected only when the quantity of the outcome is so
large that the probability of its having occurred by mere chance is one times out of hundred.
We consider the probability of its having occurred by a chance to be too little and
we reject the chance theory of the null hypothesis and take the occurrence to be due to genuine tendency.
On the other occasions we may reject the null hypothesis even when the quantity of the reported
outcome is likely to occur by chance five times out of hundred.
Statistically the former is known as the rejection of null hypothesis at zero point one level
and the latter is known as the rejection and zero point five level.
It may be pointed out that if the researcher is able to reject the null hypothesis he cannot
directly uphold the declarative hypothesis.
If an outcome is not held to be due to chance, it does not mean that it is due to the very
cause-and-effect relationship asserted in the particular declarative statement.
It may be due to something else which the researcher may have failed to control.
Declaration of a rule or test of hypothesis in other point we need to keep in mind.
Given a null hypothesis and alternative hypothesis we make a rule which is known as decisive
rule according to which we accept null hypothesis or reject null hypothesis.
For instance, if we, if null hypothesis that a certain lot is good, then there are very
few defective items in it against alternative hypothesis that the lot is not good, where
there are many, there are too many defective items in it, then we must decide the number
of items to be tested and the criteria for accepting or rejecting the hypothesis.
We might test ten times in the lot and plan our decision saying that if there are none
or only one defective items among the ten, we will accept null hypothesis otherwise we
will reject null hypothesis and accept the alternative hypothesis.
This sort of basis is known as decision rule.
When we are discussing the testing of hypothesis, the important thing that need to be discussed
is the two-tailed and one-tailed test, in the context of hypothesis testing these two
terms are quite important and must be clearly understood.
A two-tailed test rejects the null hypothesis if say the sample mean is significantly higher
or lower than the hypothesized value of the mean of the population.
Such a test is appropriate when the null hypothesis is some specific specified value and the alternative
hypothesis is a value not equal to the specified value of null hypothesis.
In a two-tailed test there are two rejection reasons, one on each tail of the curve which
can be illustrated as if the significance level is five percent and the two-tailed test
is to be applied, the probability of the rejection area will be zero point zero zero five equally
divided on both tails of the curve is zero point zero zero two five and that of the acceptance
reason will be zero point nine five.
But there are situations when only one-tailed test is considered appropriate.
A one-tailed test would be used when we are to test say whether the population mean is
either lower than or higher than some hypothesized value.
We should always remember that accepting null hypothesis on the basis of sample information
does not constitute the proof that null hypothesis, is true.
The only mean that there is no statistical ev… evidence to rejected.
And finally we come to the last part of it which is the errors in testing the hypothesis.
There are basically two types of errors we make in the context of testing of hypothesis.
These are called as Type one and Type two error.
In Type one error we may reject null hypothesis when null hypothesis is true.
In Type two error when we accept null hypothesis, when the null hypothesis is not true.
In other word Type one error means rejection of hypothesis which should have been accepted
and Type two error means accepting the hypothesis which should have been rejected.
Type one error is denoted by alpha known as alpha error also called the level of significance
of test and Type two error is denoted by Beta known as beta error.
The probability of Type one error is usually determined in advance and is understood as
the level of significance of testing the hypothesis.
If Type one error is fixed at five percent it means that means that there are about five
chances in hundred that we will reject null hypothesis when null hypothesis is true.
We cannot control Type one error just by fixing at a lower level.
For instance if we fix it at one percent we will say that the maximum probability of committing
Type one error would be zero point zero one but with the fixed sample size when we try
to reduce Type one error, the probability of committing Type two error increases.
Both types of error cannot be reduced simultaneously.
There is a tradeoff between two types of error which means that the probability of making
one type of error can only be reduced if we are willing to increase the probability of
making the other type of error.
One must set a very high level of Type one error in one’s testing technique of a given hypothesis.
Hence, in the testing of hypothesis one must make all possible effort to strike an adequate
balance between Type one and Type two errors.
And this brings to a conclusion of the module and in this module what we have done is we
have discussed the definition and types of hypothesis.
We have also seen the testing of hypothesis, the errors that are there in hypothesis.
How do we formulate a good hypothesis and what are the characteristics of good hypothesis?
I hope this module will be of a great help to you, thank you.
