Hello everyone.
Today, we are going to discuss a new chapter of Research Methodology – that is Qualitative Research.
As you must have heard about the term ‘research’, it is divided into two parts - One is quantitative
and the other is qualitative research.
Hope you are having a better understanding by learning all other modules of what is quantitative
and qualitative research.
So, to make your concepts more clear, today, I’ll focus only on qualitative research in this module.
So, I am back again with a new module and I am Ritu Sharma.
I will be discussing here about the qualitative research and in this we will try to see the
possibilities for using qualitative approaches and methods in research product, projects.
We’ll also try to provide an overview of the logic of qualitative research and its
origin within an imp… interpretative tradition within the social sciences.
And then we will try to define the qualitative research approach and cro… contrast this
with the quantitative research approach.
To review the main methods for conducting qualitative research project in depth, one
to one focus group, interview and participant observation.
Then finally, we’ll highlight the main issues confronting social researchers when using
qualitative approach and method in research projects.
Now, the qualitative research style is more often than not associated with an interpretative
perspective in social research, in which the logic of research is not so much to test out
given theories about what guides human behaviour, but instead to develop an appreciation of
the underlying motivation that people have for doing what they do.
Now, to underly… the underlying the quantitative research style, then is the assumption that
in order to understand human behaviour, a researcher must first understand the meaning
that people have of the world around them, because these meanings tend to govern their actions.
The emphasis given by qualitative researcher to their studies is therefore involves an
examination of the perspectives of the people or groups that are of interest to them, their
ideas, attitude, motives and intentions.
Qualitative research methods such as in depth interviews and participant observation shares
some of the following characteristics.
First, research is carried out in real life settings.
In order to build up the understanding of how people experience the world around them,
and to identify what informs their behaviour, the researcher attempts to study actions and
talk as it naturally occurs, with as little disruption to people’s life as possible.
The second point is, quantitative methods, such as questionnaires, surveys and experiments
are scheduled as leading to creation of relatively artificial research situation, in which it
is possible to study real views and real behaviour.
The objective is to take detailed description of people’s behaviour and thoughts to illuminate
their social meanings.
This implies adopting an insider’s perspective in research, in which there is likely to be
a closeness between the researcher and the people to be studied, rather than an impersonal
and distanced relationship.
For instance, an organization based study of absenteeism made, entail a researcher spending
considerable time at the workplace, observing how work is organized, the relationship between
actors and developing a non-threating presence.
From this vantage point, the researcher will aim to develop a rapport with the employee
to gain their trust and confidence, in order to encourage them to speak fully and frankly
about issues that may be associated with the absentees.
The researcher is likely to adopt an approach in which there is no precise initial specification
of research issue and concepts.
The focus of the research may change during the course of collecting data as ideas develop
and particular issues become important.
The qualitative approach involves theory construction rather than theory testing.
Theoretical ideas developed from initial data collection and then go on to influence further
data collection, there is a cumulative spiral theory developed and data collection is there.
Now, defining the qualitative research.
What actually we mean by this qualitative research?
There is some disagreement about how to define a qualitative style of research.
Perhaps, the easiest way to begin with is what researchers do, and how this distinguishes
them from researchers using other approaches from this point of view.
Qualitative research has several important features.
It involves, first, the study of one or small number of cases, often over a lengthy period of time.
Second, in organizational research, for instance, studies frequently focus on a single agency
or in small numbers of department or employees within the agency.
In educational research, the focus may be a single school or perhaps a number of classroom,
teachers and or pupils within or particular sch… school.
In this context, the data collection process is characterized as being intensive.
Very detailed study involves the collection of large quantities of data from a small number
of information and settings.
Researcher’s sites and participants are typically selected using theoretical sampling
or snowball sampling.
With snowball sampling, researchers aim for typicality rather than generalizalibit…
generalizability through their sampling strategy.
However, while the principle of representativeness and generalizability, which are generally
applied in quantitative research, are not appropriate for the qualitative research.
Theoretical sampling, in which research participants and research sites are selected based on the
relevance of the theoretical focus of the research, does allow a degree of generalisation.
While the quantitative researcher’s concern lies with the obtaining a statistical representative
sample, a qualitative researcher employs theoretical sampling is focused on the representativeness
of the concept in the research.
And of being able to assess the social processes in which he or she is interested in that theoretical
sampling leads to the selection of respondents where the phenomena in which the researcher
is interested are most likely to occur.
Generalization also follows a theoretical logic, with generalizability of a case to
the theoretical proposal rather than to the population or universe.
Indeed, Mason has argued that good qualitative research always ends to achieve wider reason…
resonance rather than be content with the finding that are idiosyncratic or particularly
to the limited empirical parameters of the study.
This approaches in stark contrast with the quantitative research studies using questionnaire,
for instance, these are designed to investigate much larger number of cases, but which collect
data for more shorter periods of time on each case.
Hakim says that he has, Hakim has provided an interesting way to distinguish these two approaches.
One, if survey offers the bird’s eye view, qualitative research offers the worm’s eye view.
The adoption of a wide initial focus at the outset, rather than testing of a narrowly defined hypotheses.
Qualitative research tend to begin with no more than a rather general interest in some
type of social phenomena or issue.
It is only during the course of data collection and analysis that researchers narrow down
their research problem and begin to formulate and test hypotheses.
A commonly used approach is the method of grounded theory developed by Glaser and Strauss
in nineteen sixty seven.
Essentially, the researcher begins with a general problem that she or he would like
to explore, conduct the field work, examine this by looking for relationships and patterns
in the data, and then turns to theory to try to explain any patterns.
In this way, theory emerges from the data.
The general strategy might be defined as a research-then theory strategy.
It adopts an alliterative process, in which analysis takes place while the data is being
collected, rather than the, after it has been gathered.
A range of types of data is employed not just one.
Results from observation and or from unstructured interviews are usually the main source of
data, but use may be, made of public and private documents and even of official statistics
and questionnaire data.
For instance, an int… investigation into declining employee morale at a particular
workplace may involve the researcher conducting observation, in-depth interview, questionnaire,
analysing internal memoranda and examining minutes of the meeting.
The guiding principle here is that utilising such an apparently eclectic set of methods
and data places the researcher in a relatively strong position to develop a holistic account of the issue.
In combination, these methods might enable the researcher to- Monitor the extent of declining
workplace morale, identifying the range of possible situation and contextual factor that
may play a part in the trend, observe the relationship that exist between employees,
develop an understanding of how employees experience work, then examine how the organisation
has previously approach the issue, and what step it has taken in the past to resolve it,
and the impact of these approaches.
Such a research strategy contrast with quantitative research work, which tend to rely on only
a single source of data.
Minimal pre-structuring of the data that is collected.
It is for this reason that the observation and interviews used by qualitative researcher
are often referred to as ‘unstructured’.
On the basis of their observations, qualitative researcher usually writes field notes in which
they are, try to describe what they have seen and heard in detail, rather than entering
with the list of categories and ticking those off which when they observe instances.
Similarly, the question that researcher ask in an interview will usually be open ended.
They will try to note how down exactly what information say, rather than interpreting
the responses in terms of the predefined answers.
In addition, observation and interviews are often audio or even video recorded.
In summary, categorisation for structuring and analysing the data are developed in the
course of data collection and analysis, rather than beforehand.
The reporting of qualitative research data generally in terms of verbal description and
explanation with quantification and statistical analysis taking a subordinate role at a most.
Now, how is a qualitative research conducted?
Now, qualitative research as a style of inquiry uses a va… wide variety of methods of data collection.
As we have seen, the two most commonly used qualitative method in social research are
in-depth interviews and participant observation.
In-depth interviewing – There are essentially two types of qualitative in-depth interviews.
The first approach involves one-to-one interview, in which individual response are questioned
at length about a particular issue, experience or event.
The second method uses group discussion or focus group, which are designed to allow you
to see how people interact in discussing topics and how they react to disagreement.
There are two broadly different approaches to the way in which data are quali… qualitative
interviews may be read.
The first, which Silverman referred to as a ‘realist’ approach, treats ‘respondents’
answers describing some external reality, example, facts, events or internal experience,
example, feeling, meanings, as if such data provides factual accounts of people's life.
An alternative ‘narrative’ approach ‘treats interview data as accessing various stories
or narratives through which people describe their world, where interviewers and interviewees,
in concert, generate plausible accounts of the world’.
What is central to in-depth interviews, regardless of how the emerging data is perceived, is
that they provide qualitative depth by allowing interviews to talk about the subject in terms
of their own frames of reference.
In so doing, the method enables the interviewer to maximize her or his understanding of the
respondent’s point of view.
Critics of the qualitative approach would argue that the closeness between the interviewer
and interviewee that occurs in such interviews implies that the method is inevitably a subjective
one that lacks scientific rigour.
The informal conversational process, it is argued, provides too much scope of the interviewer
to influence the interviewee’s response, in terms of, one, revealing their own views
on the matter, second, the question style used, third, the body language displayed,
fourth, the body the behaviour and conduct throughout the interview, fifth, however,
researcher conducting qualitative based studies can make use of procedure to increase scientific
rigour and systematically their general approaches.
Issues such as observing over multiple sites and the recording of interviews are dealt in detail.
There are equally well-established methods for rigorously analysing data that are considered.
Many qualitative research would also counter the criticism mentioned above by asserting
that it is not possible to achieve absolute objectivity in research.
To condemn qualitative in-depth interview in this way is to ignore the reality that
all research is subjective.
Indeed, quantitative research design are influenced by the values and assumptions of those who
commission and conduct the research in terms of the questions asked and by implication,
those that are not asked, the target groups and settings of the selected for the study,
the research methods used, the method of analysis that are used, the emphasis that is given
to certain aspects of the data in the analysis of finding and by implication and downgrading of the data.
The interpretation given to the data, the reporting of the research, in terms of focus,
selection and weighting given to the different elements of the findings.
Now, what is in-depth one to one interviewing?
Unlike, structured interview, qualitative in-depth one to one interviews are open-ended
using interview schedule or aid memoires, rather than carefully crafted pro-structured questionnaire.
The intention is therefore, to capture the point of view of the respondent rather than
the concern of the researcher.
Such in-depth one to one interviews are designed to explore issues in detail with the interviewee,
using probes, prompts and flexible questioning style, both in terms of the ways in which
questions are asked and the order in which they are delivered.
In many respect, qualitative semi-structured or unstructured interviews are conducted in
situations where the researcher’s intention is to share control of the data-gathering
exercise with the respondent, to allow the respondent to craft her or his own account
of matter in the question, rather than to highli… highly structured data, which can
be directly compared to the results from the interview held with other members.
The use of probes and prompts in qualitative interviews enable the researcher and the respondent
to enter into a dialogue about the topic in question.
This can be helpful in that the researcher and the respondents are given the opportunity
to query questions and answer and to verify that they have a shared understanding of meaning.
Significant latitude is given to the respondent in the shaping of the interview agenda, and
she or he provides with the opportunity to discuss the topic using the respondent’s
own frame of reference, own language and own concept.
This is important as one of the major concerns of researchers conducting exploratory research
is to uncover issues and concerns that they themselves had perhaps, not previously thought
of or had little knowledge of or understanding about.
These interviews therefore, allow respondent to lead the researcher into exploring relatively uncharted terrain.
Using this method, respondents are also encouraged to provide examples in order to ground their narrative.
A related feature of this approach is that interviewer will aim to develop some form
of social rapport with the respondent.
In any project involving unstructured interviews, the relationship between the researcher and
those who are researched is crucial.
This is considered an essential requirement for this method.
First, without such a rapport, it is difficult to convince respondent to participate in the
interview, and to talk fully and frankly about the issue addressed.
Secondly, many researcher and in particular feminist researcher, would argue that developing
such a relationship as a part of wider humanist interviewing approach, assist in reducing
unequal power relations in the research.
Here, interviews are less formal and less structured, and invite the interviewee to
take part in setting the agendas.
There is also a shared exchange of information, rather than the one-way expression of data
implied according to critics, by the highly structured and hierarchical survey type qua…
qualitative interviewing method.
Wherever possible, qualitative interviewers will tend to aim to reach agreement with responded
to record the exchange.
This serves several purpose.
It enables the researcher to capture a full transcript of the interview, which is considerably
more difficult when reliant on note-taking.
This also frees the researcher to reflect more carefully on the course of the interview,
to think about the responses given, and to plan the next line of questioning, and also
to take reflective notes and comments about the issues raised in the interview that might
foo… fruitfully be returned to a later stage.
Researchers should also take notes on any interesting non-verbal data, such as body
language and any particular episode or events that occur during the course of the interview
that may have a hearing on, how the data should be contextualized and understood.
Data from tape recordings can also be open to public inspection by others providing opportunity
for interested peers to scrutinize and either validate or challenge reported findings and interpretations.
This will also significantly increase data reliability.
Making recordings and full transcripts publicly available also enables others to check that
interviews have been conducted in a professional manner, with data that faithfully represents
the voice of respondents, rather than reflecting the values and bias of a manipulative researcher.
Then other technique of data collection is the focus groups.
Qualitative interviews that are held with the group of participants, a focus groups
are done, so with a different purpose in mind, from those held with just one respondent.
The central purpose for both is to collect data that accurately reflects the thoughts,
feelings and opinion of the respondents.
However, in focus group the intention is to stimulate discussion among people and bring
to the surface responses that otherwise might lay dormant.
Such discussions may enable participants to clarify their views and opinion positions
or, on the basis of engagement with others to articulate more clearly than they o… otherwise might.
The interactive dynamic therefore considered to be a crucial element of the focus group approach.
The interviewer or moderator will use a variety of techniques to encourage respondent to debate
topics and issues, to challenge opinions expressed by others, to identify the areas of consensus
and disagreement, and to collect examples with which to el… illuminate the concept.
The membership of a focus group is usually determined by some shared attributes among participants.
This might be an experience, a known opinion position, a socio-demographic characteristics,
or some other variable.
Thus, sum form of the theoretical sampling method is used in the selection of focus group
membership, so that a degree of homogeneity is evident.
This is very important.
Too much difference and heterogeneity and the focus group may become unwielded and unmanageable.
By contrast, where participants in a particular focus group share an important attribute,
it is or for the researcher to identify shared position and areas of disagreement or potential
discrepancies and contrast broad group opinion with those emerging from other focus group
whose membership is based upon the alternative attributes.
Ethnography and observation is another method, which is very important for qualitative research.
Apart from in-depth interviewing and focus group, the other major method that is used
by qualitative researcher is ethnography study.
Through the observation of institutions, cultures, and customs, the researcher will aim to investigate
an institution, group or settings that is relatively under-ris… researched and about
which relatively little is known.
The ethnographic approach used for this purpose to enquire systematically about the world
people see and to develop theories about the social world.
This is an important point to note.
Researcher undertake ethnographic studies to see the world in a new way from the point
of view of the people under investigation, not just to confirm their preconception about
a particular issue or group that they are studying.
This involves looking hard to all aspects of what is going on, not picking out one or
two events and using them to confirm taken-for-granted views about the nature of the social world.
Thus, the ethnographer does not just observe and record the unusual extreme behaviour,
but joins in the everyday activities and life of those who are being studied.
The researcher observes social interaction and talks informally with group members, aiming
to acquire cultural knowledge and identify and make sense of patterns of social interaction
in people's natural environment.
This style of research is often referred as naturalistic, and assumed that the study of
people's behaviour can only be conducted in situation where people do not feel under surveillance.
The task of the researcher, therefore, is to observe people in a sensitive and unobtrusive fashion.
Usually, this involves spending time in the field so that the researcher gains acceptance
among the community that he or she is investigating.
Ethnography refers to more than just the process of observing, it includes holding interviews,
chats or in-depth interviews with individuals or in group situations whenever and wherever
appropriate, and may include, for instance, the analysis of documents such as organisational
memoranda or personal documents.
The Ethnographic approach may also involve the use of quantitative methods such as questionnaire.
The main research method associated with ethnography, however, is participant observation.
Participant observation involves the researcher in becoming part of a group or situation that
is being studied, although not necessarily as a member of that group.
When conducting ethnographic studies using participant observation, the researcher is
confronted by several practical question.
One of the most important decision open to the researcher is selection of a site for a study.
Owing to the time and resources constraint, observations are often limited to only one
or small number of research sites, and as such the researcher should consider taking
steps to ensure that this or these are typical of the many such settings available for the study.
The research will often find several possibilities and the decision should be driven largely
by the anticipated richness of the data that particular sites others.
Beyond this, as an ethnographer you should choose a setting that is relatively easier
than the others to gain access to, although preferably one that is not familiar, where
you have no particular knowledge or expertise and where you are most open to record the unexpected.
Having selected a site for study, the researcher needs to gain physical and social access.
Physical access refers to the process through which the researcher is able actually to enter the site.
This may involve the participant observation seeking permission from a gatekeeper to enter
a particular setting, such as a school or a hospital, and may require some negotiation.
Inevitably, there are political consequences in any such negotiation, and the researcher
may have to code some power and control over the research processes, and may be required
to compromise some aspect of the proposed research strategy.
Social access requires the researcher to gain a vantage point through which he or she can
view the world as it is seen from the perspective of the people being studied.
Having physical access to a site is one thing, but if particular aspect of the life world
under investigation are kept secret from the researcher by a suspicion community, then
the data acquired will be at best represent only a partial account of the real world of
the culture of organisation.
Finally, there is a stage of recording the behaviour and events that form the basis of
the research data.
The ethnographer will aim to record data from her or his observation in the form of field notes.
These will be descriptive accounts of what has been seen and heard, reflective analytical
notes that focus on then… the themes and patterns that emerge from data, and also methodological
observation such as ethical issues and field strategies.
In general, researcher should aim to take full field notes immediately after an observation
session has been completed.
Such notes should include details about the settings perhaps, maps or diagrams or rooms,
where the action has been observed.
Events, people’s behaviour, and talk notes will usually be recorded chronologically and
full details about the date and time of the observed actions.
They may also include initial impressions and thoughts about the field work sessions
as well as interpretation and analytical observation.
Conducting qualitative research online – As techno… technology develops, video conferencing
hardware and software in becoming more widely available and this would seem like the best
way to overcoming problems associated with typing speed and the technical difficulties.
However, this still requires that participants have the requisite set-up at the, at their
end in order for it to work successfully.
At present, there appears to be a more talk of the future possibilities that video conferencing
might offer than its actual use in qualitative research.
There may even be a preference for sticking with text based communication, since one of
the great advantage is that it cuts on the need to transcribe after the events.
There is also a large debate around the additional anonymity afforded by text based communication.
First though, we shall turn to a method, which raises a number of questions about whether,
what happens online constitutes ‘real’ behaviour that of online observation.
Observing ‘virtual’ behaviour – From an ethnographic point of view, social networking
sites and virtual communities of offer us insights into how people shapes their identities,
how they interact with one another and importantly how they shape their environment.
Space, just like a space, lacks meaning or connection until people makes it their own.
A space then becomes a ‘place’.
The ways in which users can define their place in virtual world, by customising layouts or
even selecting furniture or a virtual house, tells us something about how people construct
meaningful lived experiences.
For the qualitative researcher, new technology offer both useful tai… tools and in also
intriguing topics for investigation.
When using online researcher techniques, all the issues that are discussed in the following
section apply, but issues of communication, meaning and identifi… identity must also
be given additional consideration.
The practical issue of access to a large pool of data, reduction in transcript time and
increase participation by excluding groups, offer very attractive advantages.
However, conducting qualitative research online is not merely a matter of transporting conventional
techniques to the online world, it requires the exploration of a whole new set of methodological
and ontological issues.
Issues in conducting qualitative research studies – There is a issue of validity,
reliability, which we have already done in the other module, so we will straight away
go to the access.
Often the researcher will have to negotiate the access to the settings or people to be
researched with the number of gatekeepers.
For instance, a study on bullying at school may involve the researchers engaging in lengthy
discussion and negotiation with the particular local education author… authority, the school,
governors, the head teachers, the heads of the departments, school teachers, parents
and the pupils themselves.
The likelihood that the researcher may need to compromise the research questions and or
general methodological approach in order to gain permission from these actors to conduct
the research.
However, the issue of political constraint is that of the confront both qualitative,
as well as quantitative research studies.
Then comes the question of ethics.
This is a particularly important issue in qualitative research where there is a significant
potential for misleading people, pretending to be genuinely interested, using contacts
to gain confidential information, betraying confidence and consequentiality.
While physical harm may not be intended within a research design, psychological harm may
arise at any time through the investigation of sensitive issue that may induce stress or anxiety.
The researcher must take whatever steps necessary to ensure that ethical conventions are not
broken, respecting both those who participate in the study, as well as new generations of
ris… researchers whose tasks maybe, made all the more arduous, if earlier researchers
have damaged relationship in the field through in inses… insensitive and ethical unsound practices.
Reflexivity is another thing that we need to keep in mind.
One way of addressing these issues is to keep rolling ‘critical log’ or reflex… reflexive
diary for all aspects of the research process including your value and assumption and the
way in which you observe that they may be impacting upon the researcher.
The choices you make in the research, the strategy you develop in the course of the
research, the various roles that you adopt, the relationship with the people you observe,

that you think may affect the data gather gathered.
The processes of gaining access to the research field, the negotiations you make along the

Finally, after understanding the all the processes of qualitative research, and the issues that

The method that qualitative research tend to use are varied in character, ranging from

The defining characteristics of these and other qualitative research method is that
when compared to quantitative methods, they are methods, they are relatively unstructured.
Perhaps, just an importantly in understanding, what is meant by qualitative research approach

So, while the methods mentioned above are those that are arguably most commonly used

There are a number of issue that researcher must consider when using a broadly qualitative

Chiefly, these concern issue to do with validity, access, ethics, and reflexivity.

Dear students, I am Doctor. Manish Singh.
I am from Doctor. Ram Manohar Lohiya National Law University, Lucknow.
I’ll discuss the module on ‘Quantitative Research’.
When one thinks of quantitative methods, he or she probably have specific things in mind.
He or she will probably be thinking of statistics, numbers and may be feeling somewhat apprehensive
because one think that quantitative methods are difficult.
Apart from the last one all these thoughts capture some of the essence of quantitative methods.
The aim is to understand the quantitative method of research, its meaning, its role,
The present module helps you understand the meaning and nature of quantitative research.
It also helps you understand its relationship with the qualitative research.
The module will also expose differences between qualitative and quantitative research.
It also let you understand the importance and meaning of it by way of an illustrative
What is quantitative research?
Quantitative research is a systematic investigation of quantitative properties.
Their observable occurrence and relationship, it involves the use of methodological techniques
that represent the human experience in numerical categories, sometimes referred to as statistics.
Personal abilities and personality traits can be quantitative property.
In quantitative research, relationship between an independent and dependent variable in a
population is determined.
Quantitative research method can be descriptive or experimental.
In former quantitative research, subjects are usually measured once.
A descriptive study establishes only associations between variables.
In experimental quantitative research subjects are measured before and after a treatment.
An experimental research establishes causality.
Quantitative research is designed to test hypothesis.
Factors to be considered in assessing quantitative research designs include external validity,
the construction of the sample, the presence of confounding factors, the appropriateness
of the pool from which the sample is drawn, selection effects that may arise in forming
a sample, the generalizability of the findings, the falsifiability of the hypothesis to be
tested and the replicability of the study.
These factors center on whether or not the test conditions whether experimental, a survey
or an aggregate dataset accurately mirror broader reality.
This analysis will only produce valid results if the data are of high quality in the first place.
Now, we will dissect the definition of quantitative research to understand it more clearly.
Quantitative research is explaining phenomena by collecting numerical data that are analyzed
using mathematically based methods.
The first part of the definition is about explaining phenomena.
This is the key essence of every research, be it quantitative or qualitative.
We seek answers to phenomenas.
In law there could be questions like what factors influence people to commit theft,
whether our present system is reforming the prisoners or not and so on.
The specificity of quantitative research lies in the second part of the definition.
In quantitative research we collect numerical data.
This is closely connected to the last part of the definition, analysis using mathematically
based methods.
In order to be able to use mathematically based methods, our data has to be in numerical form.
This is not the case for qualitative research, therefore as quantitative research is essentially
about collecting numerical data to explain a particular phenomena, particular questions
seem immediately suited to being answered using quantitative methods.
How many prisoners didn't display recidivist tendency after serving their imprisonment?
What was the timeline in disposal of cases relating to rape against women?
Now to answer the question, when do we use quantitative methods, there are four main
types of research questions that quantitative research is particularly suited to finding
an answer to.
First, one that demands a quantitative answer.
Examples are, “How many patents were granted to Indian multinational companies post two
thousand five amendment in The Patent Act of nineteen seventy?” or “How many under
trials are languishing in jail for more than ten years?”
That we need to use quantitative research to answer this question is obvious.
Qualitative non-numerical methods will obviously not provide the researcher with the numerical
answer we want.
Secondly, numerical change can likewise accurately be studied only by using quantitative methods.
Are the numbers of students joining the school has improved due to education policy and legal reforms?
The researcher needs to undertake a qualitative study to find out.
Thirdly, in order to find out about the state of something or other, the researcher often
wants to explain phenomena.
What factors predict the judicial outcomes?
What factors are related to pendency of cases in the courts?
These kinds of question can only be studied successfully by quantitative methods.
Fourthly, quantitative research is specially suited in the testing of hypothesis.
We might want to explain something, for example, whether there is a relationship between convicts
and their self-esteem and social background?
We could look at the theory and come up with the hypothesis that weaker, social, economic
background leads to low self-esteem which would in turn be related to the tendency to
commit crime.
What is the relationship between quantitative and qualitative research?
Conversely, qualitative research provides detailed description and analysis of the quality
or the substance of the human experience.
They share some commonalities both in theory and practice.
They cannot be called exactly diametrically opposite, both quantitative and qualitative
research is both built on the empirical methods to decipher the workings of social, cultural
and legal processes.
They differ however in how they go about this deciphering.
Regardless of methodological experiences and theoretical differences both agree that social
research would be based on the real world.
Interviews, interactions, documents, observations etcetera, in the social world.
Where philosophy givers may contemplate the very existence of world, researchers would
accept that there is a social reality worthy of investigation.
They also share the belief that the scientific enquiry shall be logical and consistent.
Then what are the differences in qualitative and quantitative methods?
There are differences in sampling, differences in manner how the data is recorded, differences
in data analysis, differences in their views and significance.
First, we will discuss the difference in sampling.
In quantitative research one of the first steps in conducting a quantitative research
is a selection of respondents or participants.
The precondition of a statistical analysis requires that respondents be selected randomly.
This process is referred to as sampling.
The people and objects selected from a specified population is known as a sample.
The sample should be large and representative, reason being that small size increases the
probability of biased result or error.
In qualitative research it is less technical and more about theoretical considerations.
Sampling techniques in qualitative research are purposive, meaning that the theoretical
purpose of the research mandates the selection process and not the strict methodological mandate.
While studying about drug peddlers, random sampling is impossible.
Purposive approach therefore is the only option.
Now we will discuss the difference in the manner how the data is recorded.
Quantitative researchers quantify their observations using a pre-coded form referred to as a survey.
However, not every study can be done that way because it can have many complexities.
Say, for example, if we have to study motor accidents, it might be the case that the cause
of an accident might be intoxication, which was pre-coded as one or maybe driver, or maybe
driver was minor, which was pre-coded as two.
Now, what if it is both the causes would be marked as just one or just two or both.
That is the problem a researcher might face, so it becomes necessary to narrate a brief
description of the accident on the basis of the count of the victim,
onlookers, police reports, and so on.
So, therein might be a case where it has to be further described using qualitative methods.
The difference in data analysis- The data analysis in quantitative research is based
on statistics using a formula based approach.
It is an ever expanding and diverse field and can involve analyzing one variable at
a time, exploring relationship between two variables or testing relationships among various variables.
In comparison, qualitative approach is less formula based but rather more emphasis is
laid on the context, social or cultural.
Now, the differences in the views and significance of the two methods- The quantitative research
is by and large detached from methods.
It introduces a theory initially in order to establish the rational of the research
and returns to it at the end of the research in order to advance the policy implication.
The concerns are phrased in statistical or numerical terms.
The qualitative differs in the sense that it tends to focus upon the quid pro quo of
the theory and methods.
Quantitative formulation can be explained by way of an example.
The example is entirely hypothetical and does not intend to reflect the true state of law.
There can be factors which the court shall consider in order to decide a case.
Like, for example, in a dispute concerning copyright infringement the defense of fair
use is taken, then the court has to consider the nature and scope of the copyright work,
the originality of the work, the amount of copying and economic injury to the copyright owner.
Assuming these are the only four controlling circumstances, assume furthermore that four
cases already have been decided.
In case one, all four circumstances were present and the decision was in favour of the party seeking redress.
In case two, circumstances one and two were present and the decision again was in favour
of the aggrieved party, but in case three, circumstances one and three were present and
the decision was against the party seeking redress.
In case four, where circumstances two and three were present was decided in the favour
of party seeking redress.
What decision can be extended , what decision can be expected on that basis in a case in
which circumstances three and four are present?
Neither the stated rule of law that circumstances one, two, three, and four shall be controlling
for the decision nor any of the decisions which already have been reached offers an
answer to this question.
If it can be assumed however that available decisions as well as future decisions form
a consistent pattern of judicial action, a mathematical model can be designed which provides
an answer to this very question.
In the proposed model, each case will be treated as an equation in which the decision is a
function of the combination of the controlling circumstances in the case.
Accordingly, the circumstances of the case are the independent variables in the question
and the decision is the dependent variable.
In this fashion, the cases which already have been decided provide a set of simultaneous
equations in which the weights of the controlling circumstances are the unknowns.
By solving these equations a weight is found for each of the controlling circumstances
and by substituting these weights in the equation, which represent represents a new case, a numerical
index for the particular combination of circumstances and for the corresponding decision is obtained.
Moreover, since the weights of the controlling circumstances now are known, a numerical index
for any combination of circumstances and for its corresponding decision can be determined.
Now we shall discuss something about analyzing the data.
The data can assume many shapes and forms.
The role of analysis is to bring data together in a meaningful way and enable the researcher
and the audience to interpret it.
The steps are as follows- the first step is to classify the data, the second step is to
The fourth is to find the standard deviation.
The fifth step is associating the data and sixth step is to draw inferential analysis.
First, we will discuss the classifying of the data.
Before analyzing the data, it is essential to classify or codify it.
Before analyzing the data, it is essential to classify or codify it in some way.
This is the method of preparing the data for analysis.
It is organizing the data to analyze it.
For example, converting the responses in a questionnaire form and coding them in numeric forms.
The analysis depends on the data type.
For example, the number of juvenile offenders involved in violent crimes every year in relation
to a particular offence would be a qualitative data.
The coding frame is dependent on the amount of data researcher is having and the requirement
of the audience.
If it is concerned with details, more categories are required and if it is a broad overview,
lesser categories would be needed.
The second step is about analyzing the data.
The data can be analyzed on a descriptive basis, that is to describe the data.
It may also be an analysis that questions the data or tests hypothesis.
It is inferential analysis and involves subjecting the data to a statistical analysis.
As far as descriptive analysis is concerned, a researcher shall be mindful about the knowledge
of their audience.
Variables are one of the factors in the data, for example, age, gender, etcetera.
They might be variables.
A variable can either be dependent or independent.
A dependent variable is one that would change following an increase or decrease in an independent
variable.
For example, the exam results can be a dependent variable, in contrast with the number of lectures
attended, which is an independent variable.
The data can be presented in numbers on a graph or in the form of percentages.
This type of analysis provides a description of the data which can be easily read as it
is reduced from the mass and have been split upon the basis of various factors.
It can be a tally chart.
However, it can further be conveniently reduced to groups.
Say, age groups that uses a five-year category.
For example, figure one presents the age of offenders in auto burglary in the year two
thousand thirteen.
Figure two is in the form of tally representing the age of the offenders in one row and the
numbers of offenders of that age in another row below the first one whereas figure three
is on the basis of age groups representing the number of offenders that fall in a particular age group.
Looking at these figures, one can safely suggest that figure three is more informative in answering
as to which age group was found to be most involved in auto theft as compared to figure
one and figure two.
The third step is finding the mode, median and mean of the quantitative data.
The mode of a group of data is the most frequently occurring value.
The median is the value that separates the upper half of a list of values from the lower half.
The mean is the average that is sum of total values divided by the number of values.
They are all measures of what is known as central tendency.
One, which best describes the group.
The fourth step is to find the standard deviation.
Standard deviation is a tool to measure dispersion.
It shows the relation, a set of value has to the mean.
Fifth step is of associating data.
Some of the researchers’ data would require him to explore relationship between two different
sets of variables.
This is also known as correlation research.
There are numerous methods for doing that, but the two most popular methods are Spearman’s
rank order correlation coefficient and Pearson’s product movement correlation coefficient.
And the last step is to draw inferential analysis.
It assists the researcher in making conclusions about the data by performing certain operations on it.
With inferential analysis, the researcher is inferring from his sample data what the
population’s scores are, sample is a selection taken from a group, it can be called to be
the representation of that group.
As a result, the findings of the sample can be generalized back to the group.
The population is a group who share the same characteristics.
The major difference between differential analysis and inferential analysis is that
the researcher in the former aims to describe the data while in the later he aims at making
conclusions about it.
Let us now summarize what we have learned in the present module.
In this module, we discussed the meaning and nature of quantitative research and its relationship
with qualitative research.
We have also learnt the similarities and differences between the two.
We have also appreciated the importance of the qualitative method of research by way
of illustrative examples.
To conclude, the qualitative research as explained above can give meaningful insights and suggestions
to the information that is scattered everywhere.
It gives us concrete results and indications by performing statistical analysis by converting
the information into numerical formulas.
The quantitative research has its own merits vis-à-vis qualitative research.
Thank you!
Welcome! This is the module on  ‘Sampling’ in research methodology - course law.
So, we are studying research methodology in which we are going to study legal research.
Law, as we all know, affects a society. Law emanates from the society. Therefore, law cannot be
and should not be studied in isolation from the society. In such terms, we also can say
legal research cannot be conducted in isolation from the society. Now, society is composed
of a large number of people in diverse forms, so there are many, many people who are included
in the society.
They compose the society and they are all diversified. Legal research is coupled with
sociology to give rise to socio-legal research. In socio-legal research, we study the doctrinal
principles of law as it affects the society and the sociological dynamics or societal
dynamics as we might like to call it. Now, where there are a large number of people and
we need to conduct the study on them, we cannot be restricted to just books, we have to go
out into the field, we have to interact with the people, we have to observe their behavior, etcetera.
So in some ways, we can say that we have to have a interdisciplinary approach for legal research.
Here is where sampling comes into play. Sampling is the process of drawing out
a sample from a large population. So a population is composed of a certain number of people
and from that certain number of people we draw out a smaller proportion and we call
that a sample. So, if we have to study the whole population, it may take a lot of time,
plus it is going to be very cumbersome and not to mention it is also going to be expensive.
If we take a sample and we follow a particular technique, the laid-down techniques to draw
out that sample, we will be able to come up with a representational sample which will
be a, we can say a mini mirror image of the whole population. Therefore, sampling is a
very important tool in legal research and we cannot do without it especially in socio-legal
research where we have to deal with population which is as I said large number of people.
Now there are various terms which are associated with sampling. The first and foremost as I
keep saying is population. Population also is conterminously used as universe, that is,
it is synonymously used as universe. Universe is the entire body of people or the entire
body of population that is sought to be studied. So, if we are taking up a social legal research
and we have, we are wanting to study a particular trait in a particular group of people, we
would call that group of people, let it be ten in number, hundred in number, thousand
or a lac, we will call that group of people as universe.
We have to choose our universe very proficiently according to what is our objective of research.
So our objective of research basically steers our universe, the selection of our universe.
Now, universe may be of different kinds. One kind is based upon the size of the universe.
There are two classifications, one classification is upon the size of the universe, the other
classification is upon the consistency or the homogeneity of the universe.
So, let's take up the first classification. In the first classification, we see that universe
may be of two kinds. One is finite universe, another is infinite universe. Finite universe
is that universe in which the number of people is countable, it can be calculated or it can
at least be seen, we can make a list of how many people are there in that particular universe.
In infinite universe, we will not be able to, it is unfathomable, so we will not be
able to calculate or compute how many people are included in that universe.
Now to explain that, I would like to take an example, infinite universe would be if
we are conducting a study on a whole country. So, let’s say a researcher wants to conduct
a study in the whole of India and let us say the researcher wants to conduct the study
on teenagers living in India. Now just imagine there are so many teenagers living in India,
some of them might be going to school, some of them might not be going to school, some
others may be physically challenged, there may be others who may be mentally challenged,
and some others may be who are involved in some kind of labour.
So there are so many categories in teenagers itself and it is unfathomable to keep a count
of how many people, how many teenagers are there in India. In such a scenario, we would
say that the researcher is researching on an infinite universe. The other kind is finite
universe, as I said, in that the number of people is limited, so we can calculate it.
For example, the same researcher wants to conduct a study on teenagers studying in the
schools and in a particular city, so he has limited the number of people that he wants to study.
Now, another classification that we were talking about is on the basis of homogeneity or the
consistency of the elements in the universe. Universe is composed of certain units and
every unit has certain features, every unit may have diverse features from each other.
So, where the units are displaying similar cha… characteristics or similar features,
we say that the universe is homogenous and where the characteristics displayed by the
units are not similar to each other, we say that the universe is heterogeneous.
Homogeneity and heterogeneity of universe does not necessarily depend upon the qualitative
features, it may also be in numbers. For example, a researcher wants to conduct a study in the
state of Delhi and in the state of Delhi he has identified certain pockets of areas, so
he has taken district one, district two, district three. For example, in district one he sees
that there are fifty families living, in district two there are only twenty five families living,
let’s say because it is more of a commercial area and in district three, there might be
hundred and fifty families living.
So, he has taken three different pockets and those three different pockets are having different
number of people, so we kil… we would call it a heterogeneous universe because the number
of people is diverse. In short, homogeneity and heterogeneity of a universe depends not
only upon the characteristics displayed by the units, but also upon the number in which
the units are present. We would discuss all this in detail in the sampling techniques.
Now, another important aspect of sampling is the sampling unit, which I just mentioned.
A unit is the most primary or the most basic part of the universe. It is the thing which
is composing the universe, so let us say a person wants to conduct a study in a school
on the students, so the students would be the units in the universe and why we call
it a sampling unit? Is because ultimately the units are supposed to be included in a
sampling, I am sorry, in a sample and that is why they are called as a sampling unit.
So now we know that the universe is there and we have to conduct a study on the universe
and we know now that the universe is composed of sampling units, but how do we decide which
of these units will become a part of the sample? For that, we need to identify what is known
as a sampling trait. So, now let us come to understand what do you mean by a trait.
Every researcher, every socio-legal researcher when he is beginning his research, he has certain
research questions in his mind or he may have some hypothesis in his research proposal.
He needs to identify what are the parameters which he wants to study in the population
and all those parameters or characteristics as we make call it or features of the population
will be the sampling traits. So, for example, a researcher wants to study about drug abuse
among teenage students in a school. So, what would be his sampling trait? His sampling
trait would obviously be those children or those parents whose children are into drug
abuse or have been in the past into drug abuse.
So, the sampling trait is the feature which the researcher wants to study in the universe.
And the sampling trait is what defines whether a sampling unit or rather a unit of the universe
would become a part of the sample or not. Although there are more technicalities involved
which you will see further but for now we need to understand that a sampling trait is
one of the primary things that a researcher needs to identify in the universe.
Now, the next thing that the researcher needs to see is called as target population.
What is target pop… population? Let us understand that. As I already told you that the units
of the universe may not all be same. Some of the uni… units of the universe may be
displaying what we are calling as sampling traits and others may not be displaying the
sampling traits. So in case the units that are displaying the sampling traits are a fixed
number, we say that that particular part of the universe becomes the target population.
So, in other words, the target population is what we are going to get once we filter
out those units that are not required by us, that wou… that are wasteful for us as a
researcher. So, once we have the target population, we know that this is the universe that we
want to study. Let me again elaborate this point about target population by taking the
example of the study on drug abuse. So, this researcher, for example, has a study proposed
for drug abuse among teenage children in schools.
Let us take, for example, that he wants to conduct the study in the Delhi region, in
the N C R region of Noida. So, obviously, he will be talking to students who are studying
in the Noida schools, number one. Number two, those students must be or must have been in
the past, they must have been facing drug abuse. Now another question to be taken into
mind is that these children or these students may not be very honest with the responses
that the researcher is wanting to ask.
So in that case the researcher would like to talk to the parents of such children and
and the school authorities where such children are studying. Next, the researcher can also
talk to counselors who are attached with such schools. So now what do we get? We get the
target population that are showing the sampling trait. So, the universe basically is not only
composed or it cannot be demarcated by a geographical area. There are certain questions, there are
certain considerations that are to be kept in mind when we are demarcating universe universe
and when we are trying to figure out which is our target population in the universe.
Now an important thing that next comes to our mind is the sample size. The sample size
as the name suggests is the size of the sample that we are actually trying to draw out from
the universe. There there might be a possibility that the sample may be biased sample. In such
at all. How can we assure that? We can assure that by following the techniques that we have
formed for our sampling.
Now, let us try to understand what kind of errors can be there when we are doing samplings.
Obviously, no human action is without an error, so is sampling. In sampling, there might be
errors that are caused due to sampling or not due to sampling. The errors that are associated
with sampling itself are called as sampling errors, and those errors that are not associated
with sampling are called obviously as non-sampling errors.
Sampling errors are caused due to inappropriate use of technique or using a technique which
is not suitable for that particular problem. As I have already told you that when we are
drawing out a sample from the universe, we need to see that the sampling technique that
we have employed is according to the research objective of our research. So, if we follow
that sincerely, we will not get a biased sample, I am sorry, we will not have a sampling error.
But in case we do not and we randomly select any sampling technique without understanding
what is our objective of research and what kind of sample size do we want from the universe,
we might end up with a sampling error. Non-sampling errors are those errors that are associated
not with sampling. For example, these are the errors that may occur during data analysis
or data collection or even while the formation of research design, so one has to take care.
But all in all, sampling errors as well as non-sampling errors, they all cumulatively
affect the study results. So, what is the need of sampling? We have been studying, we
have been reading sampling, what is the need of sampling? The first and foremost need of
sampling is that it gives us accuracy of results. Now you may wonder that we have a universe
to study which is a huge amount of people, a particular group of population and we have
taken only a small amount of population from it to study in lieu of the universe, then
how can the results be accurate?
Well, the answer is very simple. The larger the amount of data to be calculated or computed,
the more are the chances of some mistakes happening because as I already said it is
only human to make mistakes. Accuracy of results is obtained because we have taken a representative
sample from the entire body of population or the entire body of universe.
While doing that we have made sure, we have applied the techniques in such a way that
we have made sure that the sample is displaying the characteristics of the universe and it
is displaying the number of people in a proportionate manner. In such a way, we can deduce the results
from the sample itself and we can generalize those results to the universe. So, obviously
this is one important aspect of doing sampling so that we do not have to conduct the study
on the whole universe.
The second important thing is it is time efficient because imagine that you have to conduct a
study on the whole of the India, so that would obviously be very time consuming and it would
take a lot of efforts. Conducting a study on a sample reduces time by a lot of times.
Thirdly, it is cost effective. Conducting a study on the universe as compared to conducting
a study on a sample is but logically more expensive.
So, when we have to conduct a study on a huge group of population, we will obviously prefer
that we spend some more time and we understand the technicalities of sampling and therefore,
we reduce our cost. After all, research work is to be sponsored by our own self if we are
not going to a research institute for it. Most importantly, the need of sampling is
because it is convenient to do sampling.
When we apply the techniques of sampling, we are able to come up with a sample, which
is a mini representation of the universe. While doing that, we are basically studying
the universe but in a more convenient manner. We will still have a large number of people
to study, yet it will be lesser as compared to the whole of the population. Now, let us
understand what is the next step in sampling, which is sampling design.
Just as you all must have known when we are conducting research, the very first step is
to make a research design. Research design is nothing but the guiding path, the guiding
light for our research, in a similar way sampling design is nothing but a pathfinder for our
sampling processes. So, what all things are there in the sampling design? The first and
foremost thing that is there is the objective of study. The objective of our research is
the thing that guides us right from the time of formulation of research problem to the
time we are writing our research report.
So, objective of study has to be kept in mind while making the sampling design, when we
are beginning with sampling, just prior to that we should sit at one place and try to
figure out what exactly is the objective of our study or what are the objectives of our
study because that will as you will further see, that will be very important in understanding
or in finding out which is the appropriate sampling technique for our study.
The second thing is about universe, we have to clearly define our universe. We have to
clearly know what all traits do we want in the universe, so we should know what are our
sampling units and what all sampling units are composed, I am sorry included in the universe.
So, next step is to define the universe very clearly. Third step would be to have a sample
size. Now, once we have the universe we can easily come to know or we can easily decide
what kind of sample size do we want.
Now, how can that be done? Sample size is something which has to be proportional to
the universe. We cannot have a sample size which is which is just fifty percent of the
universe or we cannot have a sample size which is just two percent of the universe.
In other words, a sample should not be too big nor should it be too small. It has to be sufficient
in number so that it represents all the characteristics present in the universe proportionately.
Next thing that we need to note down are the population parameters which are nothing but
the vital statistics of the population. For example, census figures or gender ratio, etcetera.
These parameters will help us to understand what kind of universe are we working on and
these parameters will also help us to understand what kind of sample size will we be getting.
Next thing which according to me is a very important step in individual researches is
budgetary and time constraints. Budgetary constraints means we need to plan out our
expenses, we have to predict what kind of expenditure would we be incurring in the sampling,
while doing sampling as well as after the sampling is done and we have a sample in our hand.
We have to predict those expenditure and we need to also time our whole schedule,
so we need to have a timeframe within which we must focus and we must stick to that time schedule.
So budgetary and time constraints or budgetary and time schedules are something that we need
to plan ahead so that we do not go out of bound neither in terms of money nor in terms
of time. Next thing which is the thing that we are going to study next is the sampling technique.
So what do you mean by a sampling technique? Sampling techniques are those techniques
that are used to carve out a sample from the universe.
Universe is composed of many units as I have already told you and we need to carve out
a sample from it in such a manner that it becomes a mini mirror image of the whole universe.
Now, what kind of sampling technique is to be used depends upon the sampling technique
as well as the universe. That is to say, we need to first and foremost find out what kind
of universe are we working on, that is what is the nature of the units in our universe.
On the basis of that we need to see what kind of sampling technique would we be using. Every
technique has its own salient features, every technique has its disadvantages, advantages,
as well as every technique has its suitability to a particular kind of universe or to a particular
kind of study. Now, these sampling techniques basically are the method by which we are able
to carve out a sample from the whole universe.
Every unit does not stand a chance of becoming a part of the sample, there are only few units
which stand a chance of becoming part of the universe. Now, depending upon the likelihood
of a unit to be included in the sample, sampling techniques are classified into three kinds.
One is probability sampling, another is non-probability sampling, third is mixed sampling. Probability
sampling as the name suggests is full of probabilities, well, it is not full of probabilities as much
as it gives a lot of probability to each and every unit in the universe.
In other words, all the units in the universe stand an equal chance of being included in
the sample when we are doing probability sampling. So, probability sampling is not a sampling
technique in itself, it is only a classification, but whichever techniques come under the head
of probability sampling will be, will be sampling from the universe in such a way that all the
uni… units in the universe will stand at an equal chance of being included in the sample.
So, obviously it is a very unbiased kind of sampling.
Second is non-probability sampling which is the kind of sampling technique in which all
the units do not stand an equal chance of being represented in the sample or being included
in the sample. In fact, in some techniques none of the units stand a chance of being
included in the sample. We would look at that very soon. Third is mixed sampling, well,
there are some sampling techniques which are neither purely probability sampling nor purely
non-probability sampling.
In such cases or such sampling techniques are basically then kept under the third head
which is the mixed sampling. A lot of sampling techniques that we are going to see will form
under a head of mixed sampling. Now, let us have a look at the sampling techniques. First
and foremost, we will see the easiest sampling technique which is called as simple random sampling.
Simple random sampling, as the name suggests, is doing of or conducting of sampling in a
very random fashion and it is very simple because it has no technicalities.
Simple random sampling has only one prerequisite, you need to have a list of all the units in the universe.
So, let's say you are conducting a study on some number of houses or some number of families
in a particular locality, you need to have a list of all the houses in the locality.
Now simple random sampling is nothing but the choice of the researcher. The researcher
can randomly pick up any loca… any house or family that he wants to study and he can
include it in the sample. Simple random sampling is completely the researcher’s choice that
the researcher wants to randomly select or he wants to use a particular system in selecting
or he wants to blindly do it or he may ask a child to do it or he may ask his own supervisor to do it.
So it is completely the choice of the researcher what kind of method does he
want to use for doing the simple random sampling.
The most popular methods of simple random sampling are Lottery and Tippet’s Table.
Lottery, as the name suggest, is a blind method of doing simple random sampling. So all you
need to do for doing the, using the lottery method is to make a list of all the units
present in the universe as I already said. You name them or you give them a number and
you write all the numbers on small chits of paper.
You put the chits away, you put them together and probably shake them and either you yourself
pick out the number of the, requisite number of units that you want because you have already
decided the sample size or you can ask anyone else to do that for you. So whatever units
you will have in your hand will be your sample. Now, this has no technicality. However, there
is a disadvantage because it may not be representing the universe proportionately or adequately.
So, it is the researcher’s choice what is a sample size that he wants to do and what
kind of units will he be picking up is completely the luck of the researcher I would say.
Another popular method that came up after the use of lottery method was Tippet’s Table.
Now researchers had realized during, using the lottery method that it was a method which
required a lot of time. It was a time when they were no computers, so manually listing
all the units in the universe and then putting them away in a blind lottery would be a lot of work.
So, lot many research scholars and researches came up with some tables of random numbers,
Tippet was one of them. He came up with a table of ten thousand four hundred numbers.
These all all of these numbers are numbers of four digits, so he just put them in a table
and what we need to do when we use the Tippet’s Table is this. We assign all our units of
the universe four digits number, so let’s say a researcher wants to conduct a study
on nine hundred units and he needs a sample size of let’s say five hundred people.
So, what he will do is to these, because nine hundred is a three digit number, so what he
will do is all these nine hundred people will be assigned a four digit number from let’s
say three thousand to three thousand nine hundred and then he will randomly in the Tippet’s
Table pick up any four digit number, any four digit number which falls between three thousand
to three thousand nine hundred and then onwards he will simply take up those numbers that
are given in the table and he will go ahead and keep selecting the units in the universe.
This way, he will not, the researcher will not have to use any technicality in selecting
the units and it will not be, there will not be any personal bias of the researcher in
selecting the units, plus there will not be, it will, it is a very simple method of doing sampling.
However, it is very random and again just like in lottery method there is the disadvantage
that the sample that is collected may not be adequately representing the universe.
So, now let us look at other sampling techniques. One of them is interval sampling, which is
a higher form of simple random sampling, why? Because it is again random, but it is more
systematic. Interval sampling is nothing but selecting units from the universe in an interval
or after a particular interval. What that interval will be is completely to the researcher’s
choice. So, let’s say the researcher wants to select a sample size of twenty people and
he has a universe of two hundred people.
So, let’s say the research says that my interval is going to be ten and he makes a
list of all the units in the universe and he randomly picks up any number.
Let's say he has picked up the number eleven, after that he is going to, after interval of ten
people he is going to select the units. So, he will have a sample size, the desired sample
size that he wants and he will not have to use any technicality. Plus there will be no
personal bias of the researcher.
However, this kind of sampling is not very useful in heterogeneous universe because in
heterogeneous universe different characteristics, diverse characteristics are are present in
the universe. So, let us look at another sampling, another kind of sampling that we can see or
we can conduct is stratified sampling. Stratified sampling as the name suggests is a sampling
in which the population or the universe is divided into strata. It is a method which
is very useful for those population which are heterogeneous in quality.
These kind of universe which are heterogeneous in quality and which can be divided into homogeneous
strata, so there might be a population which can be divided into different strata and each
strata should have homogeneous quality with each other. Now, what the researcher will
do? He will draw out samples from each of the strata using any of the other sampling
techniques that he may like. The final sample which is composed of all the samples from
the, from each of the strata will be the one that he will be studying finally.
Stratified sampling can be conducted in two ways- one is proportional, another is simple.
In simple stratified sampling, as we see, as I have already told you, the researcher
simply selects from the, simply selects sampling units from the strata, each of the stratum
and in proportional stratified sampling, the researcher makes sure that the proportion
in which the stratum is present in the universe is the same in which the units from that particular
stratum are present in the sample, so that is what is called as proportional stratified sampling.
It is more technical. However, it ensures that the researcher will get a more proportionate sample.
Now, next is purposive sampling. Purposive sampling, also known as judgment sampling,
is entirely the researcher’s choice. The researcher is at complete free will to select
any of the units that stand a chance of being included in the sample. None of the units
which are in the sample or none of the units which are in the universe stand a chance of
being included in the sample because it is completely the researcher’s choice.
Researcher out of his convenience or within his convenience may choose any unit that he
he likes. It is very useful in those researches in which qualitative investigations are to be done.
It is not very useful in empirical analysis. Why? Because it may not be representative
in character, the sample that you finally get may not be very representative of the entire universe.
Another one is convenient sampling which should not be confused with purposive sampling because
in convenient sampling also the researcher himself chooses which kind of units he wants
to select as sample. However, there is a major difference in purposive and convenient sampling.
In purposive sampling, it does not matter whether the the unit is convenient for the
researcher to use or not. But in convenient sampling, the researcher accesses or uses
any of the units that are convenient or that are in front of him to be included in the sample.
Now all the units that are convenient to access may be included in the sample, but one advantage
of this sampling is that there is no need to have a prior list of all the units in the
universe. It is a very inexpensive method which makes it very popular among the researchers.
However, convenient sampling cannot be used in empirical researches, it could be used
in qualitative researches.
Let's take for example, a company which has launched a new product in the market wants
to know what is the response of the public for that particular product. So, that company
will access any of the people that it wants to or it is coming across any place where
the product is being sold, the company will take the responses or will take the feedback
from those people. Another important kind of sampling that is done is cluster sampling.
Cluster sampling means that kind of sampling in which the universe is divided into clusters.
Now, we studied stratified sampling and we saw that the universe was divided into strata,
but in stratified sampling the researcher himself was dividing the universe into different
stratum. In cluster sampling, the clusters are already available or they are already
made in the universe. To take a very simple example, let's say a researcher wants to conduct
a study in an educational institution or a university.
Now, there are various departments that are existing in the university. So, those departments
will have various employees. Let's say the researcher wants to conduct a study on the
women employees, so each of the department will form a cluster. Now the researcher will
take into consideration all the clusters and he will draw out the samples from each of
the clusters, that is one way of doing it.
Another way of doing it is that sampling may be done in multiple phases, that is to say,
the researcher has already, the researcher has already taken out the samples from each
of the cluster and he has studied them, then he further goes into the sample, into the
cluster and takes out or draws out sample from them to conduct the study. Another kind
of sampling which is very important is sequential sampling.
It is a very convenient form of sampling which is also called as snowball sampling. So, sequential
sampling and snowball sampling may be used synonymously. What is snowball sampling? It
means that kind of sampling in which you just simply go on processing or go on collecting
the data and as you go on collecting the data, you are forming the sample. So, sequential
