not be getting punished.
So, then question number one, how will we ensure that research ethics are followed?
And question number two, why should we follow research ethics? The answers to these questions
are, we need to follow research ethics for the sake of saving grace of the whole research
fraternity. It sets a bad precedent to do an eth… an unethical research and the blot
of being an unethical research is something that will never leave the research report
even if the researcher, the unethical researcher himself wants to make amendments later on.
Secondly, as far as the question of if there is no law or if there is no punishment then
how can we ensure that the ethics are followed? It goes like this, in life we have many laws
that are passed by the parliament, well do these laws, let us take for example, criminal
laws, do these criminal laws stop crime from happening?
The answer is no, in the same way having research ethics or having a certain policy for research
ethics does not mean that research ethics will be followed. It only means that we have
a certain standard of to be followed when we are doing research.
Now, what are these code of ethics and there any code of ethics that have been laid down?
The truth is that every research institution might have their own code of ethics, might
have their own policy and regulations with respect to it.
And for that matter every individual researcher also might be having his own set of ideas
to be followed as in in terms of doing an ethical research. But American Sociological
Association, in particular, has come up with a set of code of ethics. These, what are these
code of ethics? Let us have a look at them.
First and foremost is professional competence. What is professional competence? Does it only
mean competence in terms of degree? Like for example, in India we talk about having a master’s
degree to be the minimal to conduct a research. Is it sufficient? Does a master’s degree
ensure that a person is intellectually capable to conduct the research?
The answer may be ‘no’ because even though educational institutions that have research
as part of their curriculum have mandated that a course on Research Methodology has
to be there and have also mandated a man… a compulsory research work, yet the things
that a person carries or thing that a person learns in the, during the education may not
be carried forward to his professional time as well.
So, in terms of this when a researcher proposes a particular research it is not only the duty
but also obligation of the supervisor as well as the research institutes or the sponsoring
institutes to ensure that the person is professionally competent to conduct the research.
It is also desirable that the person himself understands it that what does it mean to be professionally
competent to conduct research and is honest about it and does the research accordingly.
Second thing that has been laid down by the American Sociological Association is integrity.
Now, the research that is to be conducted has to be honest. The research problems that
have been emanated by the or that have been created by the researcher should be genuine.
And most importantly the work that is being done or that is proposed to be done by the
researcher should be it should be sincere. He should be sincere towards his efforts for the research.
The third thing that has been laid down is the professional and scientific responsibility.
Now, the society as such is the thing that gave the researcher the research problem in
the first place. The society is the one from where the researcher is going to collect his
data and then analyze and interpret his results.
So, the society is the one to whom the researcher owes a lot. In fact, it is the researcher’s
po… researcher’s responsibility to take care that whatever research he is conducting
in whichever filed he is conducting a research, he should be able to professionally conduct
the research and follow the technicalities of the research.
For example, there are various tools that are available for data collection.
There are various techniques for data analysis. There various techniques done for sampling.
There are various techniques at every step of the research and it is the responsibility as well
as it is ethically desirable that the researcher follows all these technicalities in all sincerity.
This is the responsibility that the researcher holds not only towards the society but towards
the research as such.
The next thing is respect for people’s rights, dignity and diversity. Well the researcher
is bound to collect certain data from the society. This collection of data from the
society is not the researcher’s right, it is his privilege because he is requesting
the people or he is requesting the society to respond to certain questions and queries
that he might be having so that he he makes conclusions accordingly.
Now, in all this there might be some times when the researcher may gain access to certain
confidential information of any person or any organization or institution or a community,
etcetera and there also might be a situation where that per… that particular confidential
information may be very critical or very useful for the research report. In such cases it
is ethically desirable that the researcher, is ethically desirable that the researcher
uses the information with the prior permission of the particular person whose confidential
information is there.
It is not only ethics that is there, but also social responsibility and a person might not
be even aware of is right to privacy but it is again the responsibility and obligation
of the researcher to first and foremost take prior permission from from the person concerned
whose confidential information he might have gained access to and then and only then use
that particular information in the module.
Next thing is social responsibility, as I have already mentioned and emphasized that
the researcher owes a responsibility to the society not only because of his research but
also because the so… society is what gave him the research problem. The researcher must
at all times know that his research is going to pave way for further research in the same
topic or in the same field and also it is going to help, to ameliorate certain problems
in the society. After all the researcher came up with the research problem because there
were certain problems in the society because of societal dynamics.
So, after understanding these code of ethics that have been laid down, let us understand
what are the various checkpoints in research. These checkpoints in research as we call them
are the places or are the points during the research when the researcher has to be very
careful of following ethics. So, all these checkpoints have to be kept in mind all the
time by the researcher so that he does not he does not digress from the path of ethical research.
First and foremost is the authorization to research. Authorization to research has to
be had from two main actors, one is the organization or the institution which is sponsoring the
research, second is the participants of the research. Now, the a researcher may have approached
any organization or institution to conduct the research, he may also have approached
a particular institution for sponsoring the research.
In both the cases he has to make sure that he has achieved or he has obtained the requisite
authorization to conduct this particular research. Even in cases where the research may be publicly
little explosive as in the content of the research or the content that is proposed to
be researched maybe little complicated or conflicting, it care has to be taken on part
of the institution that the research has to be given authorization and a green signal
and then and only then the researcher can go ahead with the researcher.
Secondly, the researcher has to obtain authorization from the participants in the research.
Now, participants may be individuals, they may be families, they may be organizations or institutions.
In all these cases the researcher has to make sure that he has obtained the
requisite permission to be a part of their lives and observe them or collect data from them etcetera.
It is especially very important in cases of participatory observation in which the researcher
is actually living with the people whom he wants to study, so he may not be asking any
questions to them but he will be observing and taking down some notes, according to what he is observing.
So, he might be interfering with their lives and he has to make sure that he tells those
people and prior in gives them prior information as to how much interruption will they be having
in their lives. So, all this is very important to gain authorization to research. Another
very important aspect of authorization is that every institution or organization to
whom you may be approaching for research may have their own principle for conducting research.
For example, lots of ministries in the government of India may have their own set of guidelines
for every researcher who may come to them for any questions. So, you have to make sure
or the researcher has to make sure that he has comp… complied with all these guidelines
and he has to make sure that he gets the requisite pre-authorization to conduct the research
before he starts the research.
Second thing is that he has to follow appropriate techniques and processes, well this is a very
technical point and it does not sound very ethical but the truth is that ethics does
fall out, ethics does come out from the technical things of a research process itself.
So, if a researcher is not able to follow the techniques that he has read during his education time
etcetera, he may not do it correctly or he may be doing a he may be applying a process
correctly but he may be applying it in a wrong place.
So, it is not shameful to go back to the books again and again for checking and referencing
and seeing whether what you are doing or what you are conducting the process that you have
taken up is correct or not. But it is very shameful if you are doing a research or if
you are applying a particular process without actually knowing what you are doing.
Next thing is confidentiality, so as we have already seen that respect of, respect for
confidentiality of the people from whom the researcher may be collecting data is very
important and with a, it is not only an ethical duty but an obligation of the researcher towards the society.
So, researcher has to make sure to tell the people from whom he is collecting
data and he has to ensure them and that he will not be using any confidential information
to whom to which he may gain access without their permission.
Next is research responsibility. This research responsibility is not only towards the society
but the research field in itself. The researcher has to make sure that whatever research he
does, he is putting it into the knowledge bank of the existing field, so his research
is not only going to affect the social dynamics in that particular field but also will steer
and affect the future research in that particular field.
Next is respect for people rights, dignity and diversity. Well the researcher has to
know that whatever s… social problems he is looking at may be influenced by or may
be affected by lot of people. Now, society is composed of diverse people, there are large
number of people having conflicting interest.
The researcher has to make sure that during the ongoing process of research as well after
he has come up with his results, he is not producing any more conflict in the existing
conflict of interest. In other words, he has to make sure that he retains and maintains
the balance between the conflict of interests.
He has to make sure that he respects the diversity of all the people present in the society to
whom he has approached for the research or on whom the research has any kind of effect.
Well the most important thing that the researcher has has to ensure is that he does not plagiaries
anything in the research.
What is plagiarism? Plagiarism is the act of taking up anyone else’s work and shh…
presenting it or showing it as as your own. Well as serious as that sounds, it is a fact
that plagiarism is one of the most common problem that is plaguing the research world today.
What are the causes of plagiarism? First and foremost, it is easy. It is very easy to pick
up another person’s work and show it as your own. You do not have to make any efforts
and you can just have something to your credit print .
Second thing is laziness. Sometimes researchers are very lazy to make efforts, to make the
requisite efforts to produce an original work. Next problem is disinterest. Sometimes a researcher
is not interested in the field that he is chosen for research, that researcher has to
make sure that whatever field he has chosen for research is of his interest.
If it is of his, if it is not of his interest or if it has been imposed upon him by the
supervisor or the institution etcetera, he may not put in the requisite amount of efforts
or he may do a half-hearted job. In such scenarios the easiest way of doing work is to plagiarise
someone else’s work.
The next problem is some other professional commitments. Well the researcher also hav…
may have some other professional commitments like teaching or some other research works
etcetera, or he may be employed in some other place, in such scenarios the research gets
affected because again the researcher wants to have a easy way out and for the same he
can use someone else’s work and show it as his own.
Another problem is, another cause of plagiarism is that it saves time. So, often, very often
amateur researchers or student researchers or unguided freelance researchers just do
a research and they try to plagiarise someone else’s work because it is going to save
their time and within lesser time they are going to have a research report in their name,
whether that research report is original or not or whether that research report is going
to be of any use to them or to the society or not is none of their concerns.
They are only concerned with having a credit to a particular research report.
Another problem that researchers often face is the pressure of competitions.
Well, in today’s age where the research field itself is growing into a very varied field with lots
of opportunities and scope, it is very difficult to for a researcher to concentrate and do
a particular research without having much money in the hands and doing the research ethically.
For this purpose what the researcher does is, he takes five researches or five research
works in hand and he can plagiarise material from one research work to another research
work, this saves his his time and as I said he gets more than one research report to his
credit, but that is not an ethical thing to do and that again, it increases the instances of plagiarism.
Last and most important reason for plagiarism to happen is that there are hardly any checks.
In a country like India where technology is increasingly being used by researchers, even
amateur and student researchers to make their research easy, plagiarism has also become
easy and because plagiarism has become easy it was but a natural consequence that some
or the other check or balance should have been institutionalized but that has not happened.
Let us look further whether some institutional checks have been conducted or not till date,
but before that let us look at what are the types of plagiarism. First and foremost and
the most commonest kind is the direct plagiarism. Direct plagiarism means where a person copies
a whole chunk of some someone else’s work and shows it as his own.
So, a work may be an idea or a word may be the complete consequence of an idea that is
the research report or a article etcetera. So, where a person uses someone else’s literary
work whether it is in a book or in an article or in a research report etcetera, where that
particular material written by someone else or authored by someone else is used and produced
as your own it is called as direct plagiarism.
Another form of plagiarism is indirect plagiarism, wherein the idea of another person is copied.
Now, one would think that two people can think the same thing that is true. However, the
way of presenting an idea and the way of communicating that idea or the way of converting the idea
into a particular literary work differs.
However, sometimes it has it has been seen that a researcher very cleverly change some
words here and there, change some certain patterns here and there and produced the idea
or the a particular research report of someone else in his own name, saying that it was my
idea. That kind of plagiarism is called as indirect plagiarism.
Third and a very common kind of plagiarism is patch writing, patch writing is where a
researcher or let’s say an unethical researcher or a plagiariser uses a whole chunk of anyone
else’s literary work and puts it in his own research. It may be intentional or it
may be unintentional that is all up to the researcher but in direct plagiarism the researcher
may have used little pieces of information here and there or little pieces of sentences,
etcetera, here and there from other person’s research. In patch writing a whole paragraph
or a whole page etcetera, is completely picked up from the original place and put in the
plagiarised material that is the research work of an unethical researcher.
Another type of plagiarism that happens and it is very rampant is unintended plagiarism.
Unintended plagiarism as the name suggests is not the intention of the plagiariser.
In that case, the plagiariser or the unethical researcher may have forgotten to cite the
reference or cite the place from which he may have taken a particular information or
taken a particular literary work. In this case the researcher may not have intended
but his carelessness is what causes the plagiarism.
So, that is also not forgivable because where we are talking about professionalism, research
is a professionalism. So, in cases of professionalism such kind of carelessness is not neither desirable nor acceptable.
material in his own research work. So, a person may have published something earlier, an article
or a research work etcetera, and in subsequent research work he uses his own previously published
article. That is that may sound like it is not plagiarism because after all, that person
is using his own intellectual product, but the fact is because it has already been published
he has to either cite it or not use it completely.
He can take an idea from it, he can get inspired from it, after all it his own work, he cannot
plagiarise the whole thing. So, what is the thing that has caused plagiarism the most?
The answer unfortunately is technology. Technology has been playing well, it has been like a
stepbrother to research because on one hand it has helped to ameliorate the problems of
researchers in a big way. Technology has helped research in a very major way but on the other
hand technology has been shaking hands with plagiarism also.
On the one hand it has made plagiarism easy, on the other hand it has given researchers
the right or the access to a lot of open access content. There is a lot of easy web sharing
which helps the researchers to share their content easily via emails or whatever, in
in whatever way, the technology is helping the researchers to not only share their content
but also access a lot of scholarly articles.
For example, a lot of research work is available online today. It is a very common thing to
not refer to books first, but to go to the internet and see what is available and see
what is the primary explanation of a particular thing.
In such a scenario plagiarism has also been made easy because a lot of scholarly articles,
a lot of articles resear… written by research scholars which may or may not be within the
copyright time period, are available online in an open access fashion. So, this has made
plagiarism very easy. Plagiarism being easy has become a very tough thing for the researchers
to handle, especially those researchers who have been in the research field for a long
time but are now supervising amateur researchers.
So, is there any protection against plagiarism or is it all just hot air? The answer is ‘yes’,
even though plagiarism is an unethical way of doing research, yet it is a legal wrong
when it comes to The Copyright Act of nineteen fifty seven. In India, this act protects all
kinds of literary works, so a research report or an article or anything that is published
in the way of literature is given protection under The Copyright Act.
Under The Copyright Act, a person who has who or who is the original author of any piece
of writing has the exclusive right to use that particular piece of writing whether that
is a research report or a thesis, a dissertation or any small paper or an article even.
He has the exclusive right to use that piece of writing for monetary benefits or he also
has the exclusive right to assign any license to a person, to another person to use that particular thing.
So, in other words, this Copyright Act gives the exclusive right to this person to not
only use his particular, his piece of writing for monetary benefits but also he can exclude
the other people and if he does not want to exclude the other people he can give them
license to use it.
Without their permission if a person uses anyone’s original piece of writing, he is
liable to be punished under The Copyright Act. The remedies that are given under The
Copyright Act are compensation to the person whose copyright has been infringed, injunction
by the court which the court says, puts a stop on all the manufacturer of publishing
or all the publishing on the things that the plagiarizer might have done and the third
thing imprisonment and penalty.
In all these ways The Copyright Act protects against plagiarism. Well this is all about
plagiarism, but how do we uphold research ethics? All said and done, it is the self-discipline
of the person himself by way of which he can uphold research ethics.
As we have seen certain checkpoints during research, which the researcher has to take
care that he is not violating any research ethics at that particular point. It is after
all the self discipline of the researcher himself which can keep him on the track for
an ethical research.
Self-discipline is not only in terms of doing an ethical research when it comes to plagiarism,
but also in terms of following all the technicalities of the research process, right from the time
of the research problem formulation to the time of the last word when he is writing for
the research report.
Second thing is that there should be checks by the supervisor, so the supervisor or any
institution under which the researcher may be doing his research or any sponsoring institution
also for that matter should keep some kind of checks. These checks may be in the form
of policy guidelines or as these days some softwares, some software companies are coming
up with anti-plagiarism softwares.
One example of such a software is Turn It In, which basically makes sure or ensures
that the person who is submitting a research report or any piece of writing has not plagiarised
from any open access content or any book that have that are within the copyright term.
Next is institutional checks, Turn It In is one example of such checks and it is also
desirable that the institution lays down from the very beginning and takes an undertaking
from the researcher that he or she will conduct the research in an ethical manner following
all the rules that have been laid down and following the code of ethics that is acceptable,
that is an acceptable standard.
Next thing is referencing, which is a very important and crucial thing especially in
legal research. Referencing means citing or giving the complete name of the a source from
a particular piece of writing has been taken. So, for example, a researcher while writing
a research report may like to quote a particular author, if not a huge chunk of it maybe two
or three sentences from that author and he feels that converting it into his own words
may result in losing the essence of what the other author has said.
In such a case he may use the quote, he may quote that particular author but he should
ensure that he has referenced that author, he has cited that author in the prescribed
manner. This prescribed manner is there are various institutions which have come up with
their own set of citation rules. Some, popular ones are Oscola, MLA Handbook, the Harvard
Style Bluebook, APA , etcetera.
Last and but but never the least is using the technology ethically. So, technology may
be a friend to plagiarism but it is a greater friend to researcher and it is only up to
the researcher to use the technology in an ethical or an unethical way. At the end of
the day the researcher is himself, his own master and is himself is his own student when
it comes to using the technology as a research tool.
So, it has to be ensured by the researcher that he is not going aboard or he is not going
overboard with using the technology for the sake of research. So, summing up what we have
learnt in this module. First and foremost, we saw that the research is not only a value
addition to the society but also to the field of research.
So, research problems may be coming out from the society itself because of the social dynamics
there might be some soc… social problems which a researcher observes and he is able
to formulate a research problem out of them.
Research is a value addition to the society in the sense because researcher does the research
or he he proposes to do the research with the thought that he will be able to help in
ameliorating that particular problem from the society. So, the researcher has to take
care and he has to know that he is a responsible person for this research not only for the
society but also for the future research in the same field.
Next thing is that ethicals research sets a particular standard, it sets a precedent,
so it is desirable that a researcher follows ethics in his research right from the step
one to the last step of his research. It will not only make him feel good but will also
set a good precedent for all the future researches, and for all the researches that he might be
supervising in the future.
For this purpose there might not be any law but institutions can come up with their own
policy guidelines. In fact, an association as we have already seen American Sociological
Association has come up with certain points, with certain pointers that give the code of ethics.
Next is how can be, how can res… ethical research be done? One has to follow the code
of ethics that we discussed. Second thing, one has to take care at certain points during
the research, at those points during the research when the researcher may digress to an unethical
part, he has to make sure that he comes back and he does only an ethical research.
He has to promise to himself, he has to commit to the research as well as show himself that
this is a professional demand and a professional moral, ethical obligation that he does an ethical research.
Next we learnt about plagiarism, we learnt how plagiarism is done and what are the causes,
why is has it become very rampant? And we learnt the various kinds of plagiarism.
We also saw that there are some plagiarism whi... which may not look like plagiarism like unintended
or self-plagiarism, but in fact, it is plagiarism and it should, the researcher should make
all efforts to avoid it and prevent it.
Technology has been a friend to plagiarism as we have already seen, plagiarism has been
made mighty easy with technology. Like, for example, in earlier times it was very difficult
to copy a whole book because there were no computers, so one had to type everything because
there were no photocopy machines, that during that time plagiarism even though it was conducted
but it required a lot of efforts.
But today plagiarism has become as easy as research itself, so it is it is in the desire
or it it is in the interest of the ethical research that the research, sorry, that the
researcher makes a commitment to himself that he will not use technology unethically, he
will not use the technology for plagiarism, but he will the use the technology as a friend
to the researcher.
We also learnt certain protection that is given under The Copyright Act against plagiarism
and we learnt some tips to uphold research ethics which vary from the institution as
well as to the researcher himself.
I am Doctor Nuzhat Parveen Khan, Associate Professor, Faculty of Law, Jamia Millia Islamia, New Delhi.
Today the topic of our discussion is “Jurimetrics- The Science of Law.”
The learning objective of this particular subject Jurimetrics is Jurimetrics is the
study of science of law. It is made up of two words- Juris which means law, E-metrics
which means eco metrics. Jurimetrics is a step towards seeking new alternatives in the
field of legal enquiry and is not to be treated as a science.
Jurimetrics involves a stricty, strictly empirical approach to the law and examines a wide range
of scientific and legal topics that are interrelated. The term Jurimetrics was coined by Lee Loevinger
in the year nineteen forty nine who introduced this word into legal vocabulary later on in
the late fifties and this wo,... Jurimetrics signifies scientific investigation of legal problem.
Further as the use of computers in law practice began to revolutionize the areas of legal
research in the evidence analysis, data management, the Jurimetrics gained further momentum in
legal researches.wo... In the recent years, an attempt to predict judicial behavior has also
taken a mechanical term for which the term Jurimetrics become more appropriate.
The Jurimetrics takes the form of different kind of investigations into legal phenomena
in the olden days was not to eliminate the reasons or philosophy from jurisprudence or
to find out substitute for necessity values which are an intrinsic part of lawmaking.
methodologies and by using symbolic logics. We as a law student know that law can develop
only by continuously drawing new values and solutions from the li… life of the community
and this is achieved partly by the development of new laws and partly by the standards and
principles which are implied in particular branches of law. And we also know that it
is a legislature which is entrusted with the work of making of the law and it is further
the lawyers and the judges who are scientifically and intrinsically involved in the study of law.
So, how can we say or how far the work or, of a judge, task of a judge in developing
the law can be described as scientific? What is the theory? The theory which they follow
is theory of logical plenitude. What is this logical plenitude theory which the judges
law is not a mere collection of detailed rules but an organic body of principles with inherent
scope of growth and flexibility to adapt to new circumstances.
A rational system for the exercise of authority of human being. Further, the Doctrine of Logical
Plenitude is to be used in a way to make it a narrowing force because if a case is decided
purely by logical deductions from the actual rules then we will crush its growth. The growth
of the law will be crushed if the logical plenitude theory is applied in strict sense.
Further, leading works on Jurisprudence, one of the work Jurimetrics Symposium contain
an introduction to the new discipline of science of law and also a number of the types of works
applications to the law, it is being concluded by various studies that the most perfect machine
even will never be able to replace the creative efforts of responsibility of man in the decision
on a public matter that is the legal regulation of social relations.
The scientific development in the codification of law is also led to the danger of “machine-made
justice”. By allowing a proportion of legal inquiries to be conducted by machines rather
than by individual judges may cause judges and lawyers to avoid the responsibility for
their hard legal decisions, but to resort to ready-made answers based on computers,
which definitely is not a good sign.
However, the vast range and huge accumulation of material relevant to the legal process
seemed to demand some kind of legal some kind of mechanical and mathematical approach, if
only towards information storages and retrieval, which means just to sort out the material,
we can use mechanical tools, but with regard to reasoning the decision, it is necessary
that there should be some legal reasoning and legal reasoning is a process through which
data is interpreted as high-level concepts.
Then further legal reasoning takes intensive factual interpretations and the drawing of
conclusions through heuristic computations. Further, it is thought that artificial intelligence
tools, some form of computational models, which are appearing nowadays as legal expert
system shortly we can call them L E X . These L E X can be devised for the analysis of legal
problems within defined domain where possible to provide basic legal advice derived from
the reasoning processes.
Legal expert system is a relatively young industry and it is a very authoritative definition
of this product. It is worth noting that it is with every other kind of expert system
which differs from legal information retrieval system in the aa,... is the answer given by
the LEX , but the answer given by the LEX depends and who is asking the questions and
they are most of the time very made up answers.
Following other desirable elements of the LEX . They includes high performance problem solvers.
They are built with the assistance of human experts. L E X operates in specific problem areas.
L E X also help in augmenting rather than supplementing humans.
They are not intended for use by laymen. That means those who are experts in the legal skills
can use these legal expert systems and the L E X are transparent also because they explain
the lines of reasoning. They are flexible also.
Generally LEX consist of or composed of three component. It has one, number one, it is a
legal knowledgebase. Number two, there should is a, there should be an inference engine
being its reasoning mechanism. Thirdly, it should be having a user interface. The potential
contributor of LEX to the general public takes the form of following benefits. The bene…
benefits are there, though it is machine made logic, but it has some benefits and the benefits
includes, it elevates the workload of lawyers. That is why it enhances the quality of their
professional work. It offers public ready access to simple and legal advice at all the times.
It also offers the prospect of a much lower rate of legal service knowledge. In law, data
is being represented in na… natural language, which represent the facts in legal case that
are human events, which may lead to a disputes. One of the objective of legal argument is
to interpret, analyze the fact of the case and to try to fit the case into the defined rules of law.
Now, the complexity of modern statutory provision with collateral amendments, statutory instruments
seems to require more than traditional methods to enshrine ex… expound their meaning and
under those circumstances, the Jurimetrics with the help of these machinic tools becomes
a helpful instrument.
The symbolic logic could perhaps provide useful tool to this end. Computers will help in eliminating
arithmetical errors and data transportation oversights this, through which the this this
may further leads to oversight mistakes can be avoided which may further bring the
information which can be relied by the judges and even by the lawyers while they are dealing
with the cases.
They can, judges and lawyers with the help of machinic tools can also easily avoid the responsibility
of hard legal decisions by resorting to re… ready-made answer based on the questions.
In drawing distinction between a scientific method and philosophic method, the ultimate
test of any approach should be in its ability to advance knowledge which can be utilized
in solving manifold human problems as the method, these methods are only means to an end.
In this respect, no matter how Jurispu… Jurimetrics is placed whether within or outside

Jurimetrics substantially involves the use of quantitative methods in judicial research.

So, when we talk about projective technique, let’s start it, how it was used for the
first time?
So, projective technique is the method initially used by psychologist.
It made up of, it is made up of two words, if you can see one is project and the other
one is technique.
What is projection?
A defense mechanism with which the ego products, protects itself from anxiety by externalizing unpleasant feelings.
What is projective technique?
The use of vague, ambiguous, unstructured stimulus objects or situation, in which subject
projects his or her personality, attitude, opinions, self-com… conception to give the
situation some structure.
It is used in Clinical psychology and Consumer Marketing and Advertising Research.
Generally known as motivation research.
It uncovers feelings, beliefs, attitudes and motivations, which may many consumers find
difficult to articulate.
It discovers the person’s characteristic, modes of perceiving his or her world and how
to believe in it.
It enters the private word of the subject to uncover the ee… inner perspective in
a way they feel comfortable with.
So, in other words we can say that projective technique means projecting one’s internal
state that is attitude, emotions, motives, values and needs to external object.
When a person is questioned to measure the extent of his knowledge of subject matter,
he gets little opportunity to project himself.
On the other hand, if we ask him to write about himself, he gets better opportunity
to express himself, to project his personality in writing.
According to Kerlinger, a basic principle of projective technique is that the more unstructured
and ambiguous a stimulus is, the more a subject can and will project his emotions, attitude and values.
A highly structured sim… stimulus as in personality questionnaire leaves very little
choice of one’s own interpretation.
When an individual is questioned and the question is disguised, he is more likely to give a
true answer – Consciously or unconsciously.
In explaining the project technique, Ram Ahuja gives a beautiful example.
He says, “If a Doctor is asked, why did he purchased an expensive car?
He will say, “Because it has a comfortable ride, because it gives a better mileage, because
it does not require much maintenance and so on.”
But, if we ask him, “Why did his brother, who is equally rich bi… bought a big car?”
He would say, “Because he is a status seeker.”
A person tells the truth when he is given a mask.
This indirect method of discovering an individual’s attitude, motivations, and defensive way of
responding is called as projective technique.
Projective technique is best used for assessing individual’s personality, attributes or
eliciting his inner feeling.
Since, projective method avoids direct questions about the topic of interest it is regarded
as indirect data gathering procedure.
According to Zikmund, projective technique is an indirect mean of questioning that enables
the respondent to project beliefs and feelings onto a third party, to an inanimate object,
or into a task situation.
These tests consist of standardized procedures for eliciting responses to ambiguous stimuli
interview like exchange.
The tests provides vaguely defined or unstructured task.
Such task allow the subject to see, say, or do what they wish to with minimal guidance
or restrictions from the interviewer.
Projective techniques got the name from the assumption that the subject projects his or
her unconscious thought and feelings onto the screen provided by the unstructured task.
Because of the emphasis on the unconscious, most projective techniques are identified
with psychoanalytical theory.
Projective Technique is a way of transcending communication bury… barriers.
People do not share their inner most feeling.
They are unaware of their underlying motives, aspirations, values and attitudes.
They fear being considered irrational or stupid and are reluctant to admit to certain type of behavior.
They tend to offer answers that are socially acceptable and stereotypical in a interview situation.
Instead of questioning them directly, talking about a third party or an object, the subject
projects their cov… covert feelings to a third party or object.
It helps in understanding the behavior and personality of low literate consumers, children,
adolescents, impulsive, compulsive or addictive buyers.
People in the face of catastrophe like hurricane Katrina, earthquake, war, etcetera.
It also helps in understanding the behavior of gay and lesbian consumers.
The origin and early development of projective test are closely inter-with with development within psychoanalysis.
Indeed Freud’s theory of dreams and technique of dream interpretation may be considered
the most important single source of the dominant ideas in the area.
At about this time Jung’s Studies in Word-association appeared, which also has been heavily influential
in the development of the projective testing.
The Rorschach’s test, best known for all projective tests, was developed by a student
of Jung’s and was undown… undoubtedly influence by psychoanalytical theory and practice.
The term projective technique came to be associated with these instruments primarily as a result
of the writings of Henry Murray and Frank during the nineteen thirties.
However, the relationship between the concept of projection and these instrument is anything but precise.
Indeed, one can say that projection as the term is conventionally used within psychoanalysis
today, is seldom directly involved in projective technique responses.
In the two decades following World War One, there was a very rapid development and application
of aptitude and ability tests as exemplified by the Stanford Binet and various group tests.
Following World War Two there were comparable developments in the area of personality testing
with projective technique receiving the most prominent attention.
It was during this period that the society for projective technique, made up of persons
involved in the study and application of these devices, was formed.
At the same time the journal of projective technique, a journal that contains only papers
dealing with these instruments, appeared.
In addition, an extraordinarily large number of articles and books concerning these technique
have been published.
Even for a single instrument, such as the Rorschach test, a total bibliography would
now include more than a thousand items.
Moreover, within modern graduate programs in psychology, the inclusive of one or more
courses dealing with projective technique has become standard.
So, the development and application of these instruments have been associated closely with clinical activities.
For the most part individual drawn to these devices have been working in clinical settings,
often with disturbed persons and typically under circumstances where individual subjects
could be subjected to a relatively intensive and detailed study.
Moreover, the techniques have been considered most attractive and useful by persons who
are heavily influenced by psychoanalytical theory or some variety of holistic theory.
Seldom has a heavy emphasis upon the objectivity, per… precision and psychometric elegance
been characteristic of work with these devices.
The characteristics of projective techniques.
Kidder has given some important characteristics of projective technique.
The different stimuli like inkblot test, picture test, doll test, etcetera.
Capable of arousing different kinds of reaction.
There are no right or wrong answers.
The respondent is not faced with a set of limited alternatives.
The emphasis is on respondent’s perception and the meaning given to the subject matter.
The individual has not to talk directly about himself or herself.
So, the purpose of the test is not indicated to the individual.
The responses are interpreted as indicating the individuals own view of the word.
The individuals response are not taken at face value that is with the meaning that this
subject presumably would expect them to have have but are interpreted in terms of some
pre-established psychological conceptuals of what responses to the specific test situation mean.
The interpretation considers responses not in isolation, but is respect to patterns.
The tester attempts to arrive at a psychological coherent picture of the individual by delivering
the full meaning of any particular response from the total record of the person’s replies.
So, given these general remarks concerning the nature and origin of projective techniques,
it may be helpful to provide concrete identification of the intu… instruments by means of representative illustration.
So, for doing that we will be classifying the projective techniques.
There are many different approaches to classify these tests, but the most useful approach
focuses on the nature of the response evoked from the subject.
On this basis, projective technique may be grouped broadly into the following categories
first, association, second, construction, third, completion, fourth, choice or ordering
and finally, expression.
First, association – Included association techniques are those instruments that tend
to minimize ideation and emphasize immediacy of response.
The subject is instructed not to reflect but rather to respond to the stimulus with the
first word, image or percept that occurs to him.
In this there is one concept called word association.
An early and well known example is the word association technique, which involves the
oral presentation of a series of disconnected word, one at a time, to which the subject
is instructed to respond with the first word that occurs to him.
Typically, both the subjects association and reaction time to each word are recorded.
Word association test can take many forms as there is no single excepted list of words.
Simply put, when using this type of test, the assessor would read a list of words, asking
the participant to write down the very first that comes to mind after each.
The object is to bypass defense mechanism that are at play and get to the unconscious
before these defense have a chance to work.
As you might guess, there are some words that are common on such a test like mother, father,
and sex, being at the top of this list.
There is research on word association test, but since there is no standard form, the efficacy
of such has not been determined.
Like many of the projective technique, it may be that this assertion provides some quality
information that in the very least can inspire further investigation.
The latter is similar to Jung’s, which contains many words of psychoanalytic significance,
particularly with regard to psychosexual conflict.
Depending upon the particular purpose of the user, scoring and interpretation may involve
an analysis of the count, content of the association, in terms of their relevance to a particular
motive or conflict as such as dominance or aggression, or in judgement concern the degree
of general adjustment to the general admi… assessment is to be obtained.
The subject’s response may be compared with the typical performance of psychiatric and
normal group on the same list of word.
In addition of their content, association are often analyzed in terms of proportion
of common responses, temporal deviation and associative disturbances, such as repeating
the stimulus word or giving extremely remote association.
Rorschach and other inkblot techniques.
By far the most popular projective technique, in terms of frequency of clinical and research
appliance is the Rorschach technique, which consist of ten symmetrical inkblots.
The Rorschach is the most commonly used projective technique.
The test consist of ten white cards and blots of ink on them in there, in either black or
black and red, or multi-colored.
These inkblots were originally random in design and these have been maintained although much
research has gone into each card.
Typically the cards are presented individually and in a set of order, with instructions to
the subject that the, that he report what the figure resembles or suggest to him.
Responses to each card are recorded verbatim and reaction times are noted.
Following which an inquiry is conducted wherein the subject identify the characteristics of
the stimuli, which determine or contribute to his associations.
If you ever, if you have ever looked to this sky and saw some images in the cloud, then
you can appreciate the idea behind the Rorschach test.
If the cards have no specific shape, just like the clouds, the shapes we see are projected
from our unconsciousness.
In other words, it is not uncommon for children to see bunny rabbits, kitty cats, and monsters in the cloud.
These images represent their needs for life and love as well as their underlying fears
about death and aggression.
The research that has taken place with the Rorschach card has produced a standardized
protocol, eliminating the biggest criticism of projective test.
They have also helped us developed standardized interpretation, which allows for more congruency between evaluators.
The standardization allows us to compare the results of one person’s Rorschach to anothers,
and while it is the most accepted projective technique, it continues to lag far behind,
more commonly used assessment devices.
There are variety of scoring system in use, the most popular of which are by Beck and Klopfer.
The, those aspects of responses which are usually scored are location, the relative
size of the blot area incorporated including the use of white space.
Determinants, the use of colour and shading in comparison with the forms or shape of the
blot, and the presents of movement either human, animal or inanimate in the response.
Also noted are the accuracy of form of perception, the incidents of popularity and original responses
and the total number of responses.
The content of responses is also classified at least in terms of human, animals, anatomical,
nature, and abstract classes, although some scoring conventions are quite elaborated in
the, in this respect.
Various scores representing the number of responses falling into each category are usually
further transformed into ratios of score, which are considered essential for interpretation.
Most system of interpretation of these quantitative scores and ratios prescribed inferences to
be drawn regarding the more general organization of personality rather than specific motives or conflict.
It is usually emphasized that the interpreter must consider the entire profile of scores
rather than isolated scores.
Modification of this technique have involved developing new stimuli and move objective
scores procedures, as well as alternative forms and group version of the test.
Perhaps the most interesting modification is the Holtzman Inkblot Technique, which introduced
desirable psychometric properties to basic Rorschach approach.
Second one is the construction.
Construction technique requires the subject to go beyond simple association to a stimulus
and to create or construct a more elaborate product, which is typically a complete art
form, such as a story or a picture.
The Thematic Apperception Test was developed by Henry Murray, a student of psychoanalytical thought.
The thematic test consist of numerous cards and with black and white and grayscale pictures.
These pictures were chosen for reason.
First, they are ambiguous to some extents and portray emotions and thoughts without specifying details.
An example would be a silhouette of a man looking of into the distance, while there
is a obvious emotional and intellectual activity, the details are not revealed.
The Thematic Appreciation Test, that is also known as TAT , consist of cards containing
black and white pictures of vague scenes, and the instructions re… instructions requested
the subject to compose a story to fit each picture, describing what the people are thinking and feeling.
What led to the scene depicted and what the outcome will be?
So, analyze, analysis of TAT stories, whi… which are usually recorded verbatim, is far
from standardized, although a number of general scoring system have been proposed.
Most of this system focus on the content of behavior and experiences described in the
story, although they differ considerably in the unit of analysis employed at the degree
of inference required.
As used clinically, interpretation typically has not rested upon a set of objective scores
for specific variables.
The base, the basic assumption of most scheme is one of a psychological isomorphy between
disposition attributes to the part of the major character in this story and those that
exist in the storyteller.
The Blacky Picture test.
Closely related to TAT is the Blacky Pictures test, which is intended to investigate eleven
specific psychoanalytical variables, including oral eroticism, oedipal intensity, and castration anxiety.
The test consist of twelve cartoons concerned with the experience in a life of a dog named
Blacky, including his relationship with Mama, Papa, Tippy, a sibling.
As its central feature the procedure involves story constructing in response to the picture
but adds indication of pre… preferences and a series of direct questions for each picture.
While ad… administration is highly standardized, scoring and interpretation are not standardized.
Then third technique is called the completion.
Completion technique present some type of incomplete products, with the requirement
that the subject completes it in any manner he wishes to and the restriction that the
completion meets certain standards of good form or rationality.
Best known of these devices are the sentence-completion test, which are widely used by both clinically
and personality investigators.
Typically such a device consist of thirty to one hundred brief sentences stems, which
the subject is instructed to complete with the first word that comes to his mind.
In some cases the instruction to the subject emphasize that the completion should reveal
his or her own feelings.
The type of scoring employed and the customary inferences divide from this techniques suggest
its closed knit relationship with the TAT.
The technique is considered most efficient in assessing the content of personality, that
is attitude, motives, and conflicts, at a more conscious or manifest level than such
instrument as the Rorschach or TAT. Other example of completion tests are story completion
and argument completion tests.
Many test of this type have been developed, some of which investigate particular personality features.
Others are designed specifically for children or adolescents.
Subjects are asked to complete sentences with such oo… open ended beginnings as ‘I wish
to’ so and so or ‘My Mother’ so and so.
Although the same sentence beginning are shown to different test takers, there are no norms
for comparing their answers to those previous subjects.
Still other types of projective techniques have been developed, including some that ask
the subject to create drawing or complete a story.
Lindzey call this as completion technique.
The respondents are given some incomplete stories or sentences for completion.
In this story, the end is not given but the children are asked to finish it.
A partial sentence asked to complete with the first word or phrase that come to their mind.
For example, a female teacher should be dash dash dash, a male teacher should not be dash
dash dash, a good housewife is dash dash dash, and ef… an efficient manager is dash dash
dash, when someone interferes in my studies, I feel dash dash dash.
Though sentence completion method is also based on the assumption of free association,
but sentence completion questions tend to be more extensive than answers to word association test.
This assessment can take num… numerous form, but the main idea behind it is completion
of partially completed sentence.
Item on such a test might look like following- A best friend dash dash dash, Mothers dash
dash dash, my worse childhood experience was dash dash dash.
Obviously, a test such as this is somewhat simple to manipulate, and that is a re…
recognized negative form.
However, many see this assessment as a means to get information that may not be at the
surface level or to prompt an individual to think about something that he may have forgotten or suppressed.
The incomplete sentence such as also work well with children, some say even better,
because they tend to be more honest and less wise as to, as to the purpose of the assessment.
Then third one is the Choice of ordering Technique.
Choice of ordering technique requires the respondents choose from a number of alternatives,
the item or the arrangement that fits some  specified criteria such as meaningful, relevance, or attractiveness.
In some cases, such as multiple choice versions, the Rorschach and TAT, the subject is required
to select a number of hypothetical responses, the one that seems most appropriate to him.
The Szondi test.
Perhaps, best known of known of these techniques are the Szondi test.
This test was devised by Szondi, a Hungarian psychiatrist in nineteen thirty’s, and made
popular in the United States through the efforts of Susan Deri.
The test material consist of forty eight photographs of individuals drawn from eight psychiatric
diagnostic categories or rather complex and lengthy administration procedure elicits from
the subject expressions of preference for the different photographs.
That test is based on the assumptions that a person can be described in terms of eight
need system, presumably reflected in the photographs with the subject selection and rejection,
indicating the degree or of strength of or tension in each.
Although the test enjoyed considerable popularity in clinical settings during the nineteen fifty’s,
more recently there has been less evidence of application.
Despite some positive features, such as the recommendation of repeated administration
and a highly objective scoring system, the theoretical rationale of the test has been
appeared to be anything but compelling to most American psychologists.
Attempts at empirical verification of the test seem to be overwhelming negative.
A recent volume of Szondi, Moser, and Webb provides a strongly partition description
of the technique and rationale.
Picture arrangement test – A more recent example of an ordering technique is the Tomkins
Horn Picture Arrangement Test.
This developed, this device consist of twenty five plates, each of which contain three line
drawings and depicts the same figure involved in the different but related activities.
The subject is asked to indicate the order in which these activities took place and to
provide a sentence indicating what is going on the picture.
The effort of the authors have been developed primarily to be developing objective methods
for dealing with the arrangement selected by the subject, although they provide suggestion
for the use of the descriptive statements as well.
This test is unique in its consideration for interpretation of only those responses that
are relatively rare in occurrence.
Rare responses patterns from a subject provide a basis for estimating certain tendencies
such as hypochondria for avoidance of people and for distinguishing normal from abnormal subjects.
The existence of a highly objective scoring procedure, coupled with the demonstration
of certain distinct differences in the performance of normal and disturbed subjects, identifies
this instrument possessing object and nominating property that are not encountered anywhere
else in the domain of projective techniques.
On the other hand, the data collected are sharply delimited, and the process of demonstrating
that the test sensitive useful has only begun.
Expressive methods, and last one is the expressive method.
Expressive method differs from construction technique in that they place as much emphasis
upon the matt… manner and style in which product is created as upon the product itself.
They are often considered to be therapeutic as well as diagnostic devices, since the subject
is presumed to relieve his difficulties in the process of revealing them.
Play is the most popular among the expressive instruments, originating in play therapy these
methods have been adapted for the diagnosis and measurement of personality, primarily in children.
All the approaches present the subject with an array of toys which he is encouraged to
use in some manner.
Among the objects frequently selected are dolls representing adults and children of
both the sexes and various age age levels.
Typically, the examiner is responsible for recording as much of these subject’s behaviour
as possible, including his choice and arrangement of toys, accompanying comments, and exper… expressive behaviour.
This projective method is used extensively both in theory and data gathering for interviews.
For example, the interviewer studying the sibling rivalry can set a scene containing
a mother doll who is breast-feeding a baby doll, with another doll of the same gender
as the responding looking on, as the respondent looking on.
The investigator then ask the child, “What he or she thinks?”
The child doll will say and do when he or she encounters the mother baby.
Dolls have also been used in extensively in studying the prejudices.
The researcher, for example, might produce a doll representing a maid servant and a doll
representing a princess, a doll representing a white person or a doll representing a black
person, ask the child which one he or she would rather play with and which is smarter.
The researcher, without asking the question, can simply observe which doll child chooses
to play with.
The similar methods in expressive techniques are role play and drawing and painting.
The, there is also a variety of drawings and painting techniques that have been used in personality assessment.
So, except for the work carried out by Sears and his associates, which has focused on measures
of aggression and dependency, little has been done with this technique in the way standardize
and specification of just how the process of interpretation shall take place.
In most instances, it is assumed that the examiner will recognise important motives
and conflicts when he sees them.
The limitations of projective technique method is that the information derived about subjects
personality characteristics is indirectly or inferred.
Against this the techniques personality questionnaire gives more direct information.
The difference between the projective test and personality questionnaire is that the
items in the personality questionnaire are structured and they being free from any ambiguity,
they convey the same sense to whosever take, whosoever takes the test.
The difference in the response made by the different subject is no way determined by
difference in their perception and understanding of the given items.
On the other hand, in projective test, the stimulus is unstructured, ambiguous and unclear.
The responses in the projective test tell nothing directly about the subject, they constitute
a description of the stimuli.
Project test lack the objectivity of the personality test.
Since, the subject does not think that his personality is being assessed, it does not
motivate him to give a fake response.
And the as we have discussed the limitations of this method, there are few advantage also
of these method.
The projective test assumption that the individual responses to ambiguous stimulus presented
to him reflects significant and relatively enduring personality attributes.
The advantage of this technique is that it is relatively disguised and therefore non-reactive
compared with more obtrusive self report measures.
The respondents cannot in infer with answer will produce the desired impressions.
In spite of their best intention, the subjects maybe unable to describe their feelings and
attributes as accuracy as they may be discerned in the projective test situation.
For example, when the students are asked, “What are the qualities of a good and bad teacher?”
They may not freely point out these qualities.
But, when they are show me some pictures, situations of teachers, and are asked to point
out what is the, what the teacher should do or should not do?
They will feel more, more free to give their choices.
Projective test produce more extensive information than a questionnaire or even an interview.
Sometimes seeking access to subjects for the study, it’s difficult when the object is
made explicit to them, but it, if it is not very obvious, the permission may be easily granted.
The evidence suggests that the information about respond’s personality trait is obscured
by information about the respondent’s temporary state and by random noise produced by the
ambiguity to the procedure.
It may, therefore be said that projective techniques have not produced satisfactory
results and seems unlikely to match the widespread use of questionnaire.
So, in the end, we can only say that projective techniques and their application represent
a point of significant intersection for psychology psychoanalytical theory, clinical psychology,
social psychology, and cultural anthropology.
These instruments include a vari… wide array of material, instructions, and interpretation
rules, but in spite of their diversity, there are certain common qualities that distinguish
them from other personality measures, such as inventories, ratings, or situation test.
The most distinct feature of projective techniques concerns the presentation to the subject of
a task that is relatively unstructured.
This lack of structure involves the ambiguous or vaguely defined stimuli and a relatively
unrestricted set of responses alternative by means of which the subject may assign meaning
to the stimulus material.
It is generally assumed that in the process of choosing between the many alternatives
the structuring or interpreting the ambiguous stimulus material, the subject reveals significant
and fundamental aspect of himself.
Ordinary, such devices are considered to be particularly responsive to latent or unconscious
components of the person and consistently there is a minimum of subject awareness and
concerning the purpose of test.
The response data are typically profuse and often involves fantasy or imaginary crenation.
The instruments are highly multidimensional that is they are intended to provide information
concerning a large number of personality dimensions.
So, one may conclude that if projective technique represents the royal road to the unconscious,
the necessary roadmaps have yet to become common knowledge.
Nevertheless, the instrument seem to have found a useful place within the psychologists
array of assessment tools.
So, this was the projective technique module.
I hope you have understood the concept and you are finding it very beneficial for your
un… study or understanding.
Thank you.
