And today, we are going to discuss Content Analysis as a part of the Research Methodology module only.
And if you remember, I am Doctor Ritu Sharma from National Law University and today I am
going to deal with the concept of Content Analysis.
So, while discussing the concept of Content an…
Analysis, we will try to understand the meaning of it and the definitions of Content Analysis.
Then try to understand the characteristics of Content Analysis and the steps and processes
that are there in Content Analysis.
We will also try to examine the sources of Content Analysis and try to understand the
advantages and disadvantages of the technique.
So, Content Analysis is a technique of interpreting various kinds of textual material to arrive
at a valid inference.
It analyzes various documents systematically and converts qualitative datas into a quantitative data.
This method is commonly used in social sciences, but has recently gained property in other discipline as well.
Content Analysis is a method of summarizing the various aspects of contents in the form
of material or documents and is a very objective evaluatent… of the material under analysis.
It is not to be confused with book review or summarizing television shows.
They are also Content Analysis.
A Content Analysis been ala… analyzed written material and change into numbers and percentage.
So Content Analysis is one of the classical procedure for analyzing textual material,
be it interview or media products.
It differs from coding in the sense that rather than generating categories from the data themselves,
it uses categories brought from the outside and fits the empirical materially against
them, of course, modifying the categories wherever necessary.
Content Analysis, though it often analyzes written words is a quantitative method.
The result of Content Analysis are numbers and percentage.
So it can be used in giving results both in quantitative as well as qualitative form.
One of the best example of Content Analysis is the analysis done by some researcher during
nineteen eighty four was that of violence against six, Sikhs as reported in newspapers and magazines.
For understanding the concept of Content Analysis, we should first understand the meaning of content.
One can say that a content denotes what is contained and Content Analysis is the analysis
of what is contained in a message.
Acc… According to Nachmias and Nachmias, “Broadly Content Analysis may be seen as a method where
the content of the message forms the basis for drawing inferences and conclusion about the content.”
They further say that, “The Content Analysis falls in the interface of observation and document analysis.”
Kerlinger calls it as a method of observation in the sense that instead of asking people
to respond to questions, it takes the communication that people have produced and ask questions of communication.
Therefore, it is also considered as an unobtrusive or non-reactive method of social research.
A number of definition of Content Analysis are given by various researchers.
According to Berelson, “Content Analysis is a research technique for the objective,
systematic and quantitative description of the manifested content of communication.”
Holsti on the other hand say that it is “any technique of for making inferences by systematically
and objectively identifying special characteristic of messages.”
While defining Content Analysis Kerlinger says that, “Content analysis as a method
of studying and analyzing communication in a systematic, objective and quantifying manner
for the purpose of measuring variables.”
Krippendorff defines Content Analysis as a “Research technique for making replicable
and valid inferences from date to their context.”
As for Weber, “It is the Research Methodology that utilizes a set of procedure to make valid
and inferences from text.
These inferences are about sender’s messages, the message itself, or the audience of the messages.”
According to Stone, “Content Analysis refers to any procedure for assessing the relative
extent to which specified reference, attitude, or themes permeate a given message or document.”
Meaning of the and definition of Content Analysis – Content Analysis is a method of social
research that aims at the analysis of the content quality and or quantitative of document,
books, newspaper, magazines and other forms of written material.
According to Berelson, “Content Analysis is a research technique for the objective,
systematic and quantitative description of the manifest content of communication.”
The word ‘communication’ here refers to “available written material or print media.”
The word ‘manifest’ means ‘which is presented outwardly’.
It thus, exclude the implied meaning.
According to Eckhardt and Ermann, as a qualify qualitative technique, Content Analysis is
directed towards more subjective information such as attitude, motivate motives and values,
while a quantitative method is employed when determining the time frequency of duration of the event.
In the latter context, it also makes inferences about conduct, intentions, ideologies, sentiments
and values of the individual groups.
The content, in Content Analysis may be manifest or latent.
The former refers to the visible actual part of the text as manifested in the document,
that is sentences, paragraph and so on.
It involves counting frequency of appearance of the research unit.
The latter is the underlying or implied meaning conveyed.
Here the researcher reads between the lines and analyzes the hidden meaning significant
for the object of the study.
Gardner describes it as “A research method for the investigating problem, which the content
of communication serves as a basis of inferences.”
At other stage he says, “Content Analysis is a technique for making inferences by systematically
and objectively identifying specified characteristics of message or communication.”
All the definition help us to understand that in Content Analysis emphasis is placed on
aspects such as system, objectivity, quantification, and context.
The Content Analysis is all about making valid, replicable and objective inferences about
the message on the basis of explicit rules.
The material for the Content Analysis can be letters, diaries, newspaper, content, folk
songs, short stories, message, radio, television, documents, text or any other symbol.
Let us discuss some characteristics of Content Analysis.
Gardner has referred to four characteristics of Content Analysis.
They are objectivity that is carrying out analysis on the basis of explicitly formulated
rules, which will enable two or more persons to obtain the same results from the same documents.
Secondly, systematic, that is including and excluding the content or categories according
to consistency applied criteria of selection.
This eliminated analysis in which only materials sup… supporting the investigators hypothesis are examined.
Third is generality, that is findings must have theoretical relevance.
Purely descriptive information about content, unrelated to other attributes of content or
to the cha… characteristics of the sender or recipient of the communication is of the
little scientific values.
Then is quantification, that is the answers of the question raised should be a quantitative terms.
Some scholars like Kaplan and Goldsen equate the term quantitative with numerical that
is classifying content in prescribed numerical terms.
This means that inferences must be derived strictly from counts of frequency.
It also means that information should be conveyed as “Forty percent people or forty out of
hundred people had this opinion,” because it is more precise than the statement “less
than half or a large number of people had this opinion.”
But others say that qualitative and quantitativeness are not dichotomous attributes, but fall along
a continuum, that is, inferences are drawn from the combined frequencies and non-frequency techniques.
Despite the advantages of quantitative method, the tendency to equate Content Analysis with
tabulation of frequency has been criticized on a number of grounds.
One, the most important argument is that such a restriction leads to a bias in the selection
of problem to be investigated.
Undue emphasis is placed on precision at the cost of the problem significance.
Other arguments is that more meaningful inferences can be drawn by non-quantitative measure.
Qualitative analysis is more superior to the problems of applied social sciences.
The proponent of qualitative techniques also question the assumption of the proponent of
the qualitative technique.
For purpose of inferences, frequency of assertion is necessarily related to the importance of assumption.
They, that is proponent of the qualitative techniques, say that the single appearance
or omission of an attribute to in a document may be or of more significance than the relative
frequency other than the characteristics.
Whether stated explicitly or not, even the most rigorous qualitative study uses quantitative
techniques at some stage in the research.
So, as steps in the let’s understand the steps in the Content Analysis.
According to Sarantakos, Content Analysis involves the same steps as in the method of
research, namely selection of the area of the search, formulation of the research topic,
designing research, collecting data and analyzing data.
The difference in Content Analysis and other methods lies only in the content of each step.
In the selection of the research area, the topic can be one, whose various aspects are
discussed by the newspaper, magazines, books, TV , and movies.
For example, a communal violence, match fixing, police expresses at the police station, cast
conflicts, violence, etcetera.
So, formulation of research topic involves explaining and operationalizing the topic,
selection of units, determining categories and formulating hypothesis.
Research design aims at determining the size of sampling, method of collecting data and
method of checking reliability.
Data collection involves counting frequencies, gathering information on the intensity of
the units, determining significance of units and evaluating unit and intensity of the statement.
Lastly, the analysis and interpretation of data aims at giving inferences and conclusion.
The processes involved in the Content Analysis.
The research through Content Analysis involves four methods.
One, specifying the problem, two, sampling, three, choosing units for analysis, four, category construction.
We shall analyze each of these categories separately.
Specifying the problem – This aims at identifying the specific research questions in the problem selected.
Ram Ahuja illustrates this by giving an example of caste violence in Bihar.
The research questions could be, “What senas are formed by different lower and upper caste?
B – What are the prominent castes involved?
C – What are the main causes of violence?
D – What are the geographical areas of their concentration?
Which political party support different caste?
F – Whom do the Naxalites support and how has the the support increased the intensity of violence?
G – What has been the role of police and paramilitary forces in controlling violence?
Spelling out these and other similar questions enable a researcher to narrow down his focus
so that he can collect data around these questions.
The problem has also to be specified theoretically in terms of the theories on collective violence,
political behavior, mutual interdependence of caste and jajmani system, formation of
political parties on caste basis, seeking votes on the caste basis, and forming ministries
on the caste basis and so on.
Logically this will determine the attention of the researchers to the kind of data sources
that is books and journals dealing with these themes, say, caste and politics in India,
jajmani system, collective violence, police and violence, and so forth.
These books and journals will provide an opportunity to the researcher for more rigorous comparative
and theoretical analysis than data source might.
So, sampling here refers to the sampling of newspaper, magazines and books, TV serial
songs, novels, etcetera.
Sampling of books means sampling of old and new books and popular magazines known for their analytical views.
Taking Ram Ahuja’s example further on caste violence in Bihar, one can sa… sample out
magazines like India Today, The Week, Outlook, Frontline, Seminar and Economic Political Weekly.
Among books could be sampling of old books published in nineteen fifties, sixties, seventies
and early nineteen eighties dealing with Bihar problems or new biks… books published in
nineteen eighties and nineteen nighties and in two thousands.
This sampled material will enable researcher to give some elegant theoretical statements.
It should be remembered that sampling in the case of Content Analysis is a multistage process.
Even when the researcher decides to focus on specific magazines and journals, will he
be able to go through all the issues of the magazines of last fifty years.
Would it be feasible for him to read between fifteen hundred to two fif… two thousand
five hundred issues of each of the eight or ten magazines mentioned above?
Therefore, money and manpower requires the sampling to be confined to specific period
in multistage process.
So, choosing the unit of analysis.
After determining the sampled material for scrutiny, the question arises, what exactly
ought to be the unit for analysis?
Should unit of analysis be words like violence, aggression, etcetera., sentences, paragraphs,
chapters, or whole book or magazines?
Researchers have to setup categories for tabulation, the theme, persons, behavior, and so on.
Gardner has pointed out following units of analysis.
First, the single word, this is used more ris… more on research in psychotherapy and literary direction.
The theme of the subject- Example, propaganda, advertisement, values, advertisement, values,
attitude, violence, etcetera.
This is used more in mass media and research.
The sentence or the paragraph, this is more used in the mass media involving a great volume of data.
The item – That is the entire book, film, article, or radio program is characterized the context units.
Category construction – This refers to the classifying the content of the material being investigated.
The constructed category must reflect the major theoretical concepts on which the study is based.
For example, in the illustration of caste violence some useful category should be status
of caste, occupational aspiration of caste, power in interaction, personality characteristic
of caste leader, etcetera.
Creating completely exhaustive category is not an easy task.
Among the type of category used frequently in Content Analysis research, Berelson has
suggested the following.
A. ‘What is said category’ and B.  ‘How it is said category’.
Subject matter- What is the communication about?
Direction- How is the subject matter related?
Standard- What is the basis which the classification is made- What values and goals are revealed?
Methods- What means are used to achieve goals?
Traits- What are the characteristics used in description of people?
Actor- Who is represented as undertaking certain acts?
Authority- In whose name are statements made?
Origin- Where does the communication originated?
Target- To what person or group is the communication directed to?
Location- Where does the action takes place?
Conflict- What are the sources and levels of conflict?
And finally the time- When does the action takes place?
So, how is said category talks about the type of communication, like what is the medium
of communication, newspaper, TV , movie, etcetera.
Then, form of statement- What is the form of communication?
And then, device- What is the propagandist method used?
Now, once we have constructed the categories, let’s understand the sources of data for
the Content Analysis.
Since, Content Analysis is done through written material, five sources are said to be important
in collecting data.
These are printed material, that is, newspaper, books, magazines, documents, filmed material, and records.
Newspaper are the most widely available form of written words.
They are not only reports national, international, state and local events, but also deal with
social, political, economic, and cultural issues.
They present the opinion of the intellectual expert as well as the common people.
Newspaper does provide a wealth of information.
Books and magazines too serve as a possible source of Content Analysis.
Various collection of books, magazines and documents available in vari… libraries could
be used for examining anything from simple to complex issues or from old to current topic.
Documents available in the archives may be more difficult to obtain and if available
at all, requires special handling and care.
Many a times, letters let… written to the relatives, kins, or friends or acquaintance,
reveal fascinating views on the social situation during the specific period of history.
Films including videotapes provide another sources of data.
By analyzing the content of film, one can pick out themselves issue and belief for analysis.
Records are obtained through sorting out files from offices, archives, college libraries,
information center, etcetera.
Example, correspondence between Viceroys and Congress leaders during the struggle for freedom
that can also be obtained.
The Parliament record contains all the speeches, testimonies and other bits of information
that occur in legislative bodies.
Some records may not be easily available for Content Analysis, example, inter-office memos.
The police and courtroom record are also not made available to criminology and sociology
researchers for the Content Analysis.
Some records become highly restrictive when the researchers want to them to study scam,
particularly involving highly-placed politicians and bureaucrats.
In one case, even the Supreme Court of India had to admonish the CBI when it reported the
loss of records required for scrutinizing purchase worth crores of rupees.
Since, the Content Analysis is dependent on the access to documents, it is doubtful that
much can be done without these secret records that can tell us a great deal about the inner
working of our government and its institutions.
Now, let us understand the type of Content Analysis.
Sanders and Pinhey have suggested five types of Content Analysis.
First, word counting analysis, second, conceptual analysis, semantic analysis, evaluative assertion
analysis, and contextual ana… analysis.
All these types of Content Analysis can be explained beautifully with the help of examples
explained by Ram Ahuja in his book on Research Methodology.
Word counting analysis – This is counting the use of certain keywords in different texts.
For example, one can count the word ‘democracy’ and ‘totalitarianism’ to measure the degree
of democratization in five nation India, England, Canada, France in a simp… sample of elite newspapers.
The object could be to find out whether there were any blatant difference between the nation
as represented by elite newspapers.
This may involves several months and numerous codes and analysis.
Similarly, terrorism and authoritarianism can be studied in Pakistan, Israel, af… Afghanistan, etcetera.
Then is conceptual analysis – This is the analysis of wo… words grouped into conceptual
clusters or ideas.
The constructive variable in in a research hypothesis.
For example, a conceptual cluster may be formed around the ideas of deviance.
Words like crime, anomie, corruption, assault, juvenile delinquency, sexual harassment, embezzlement,
etcetera., could be, could all be clustered around ‘deviance’.
Using conceptual analysis, a researcher wants to find relationship between public concern
in different sectors of society through the analysis of newspaper articles that attempts
to connect one sector with the another.
Semantic analysis – In this the researcher would be interested not only in the type of
words used, but also in scaling their intensity weights, like using weak and strong words,
positive and negative words, and so on.
For positive and strong word, plus score would be used and for negative and weak words, minus
score would be used.
For example, love plus two, dislike minus one, and so on.
Measuring these positive and negative scores, community’s feeling can be assessed through Content Analysis.
Then then is evaluation assertion analysis.
Suppose relation between labour and entrepreneurs are to be analyzed during the labour movement
through Content Analysis of newspaper articles by finding out how one treated the other by
use of certain words, it becomes possible to point out the condition that lead to strike.
And finally, contextual analysis – This is to, this is used to predict future verbal
behavior based on the analysis of known words and concepts.
For example, by use of words like militant, firing, bombing, explosion, etcetera., one
can establish scale for known verbal behavior.
Sarantakos has indicated five types of Content Analysis.
First one is descriptive analysis- Where analysis means counting the frequency in appearance
of certain elements of the research question and comparing it with the other element.
Second is categorical analysis- Where analysis involves a study of the documents by means
of set of categories producing nominal as well as ordinal and interval data, which are
then processed statistically.
Intensity analysis- Which is processed by means of multi-step scales based on theoretical criteria.
Then contingency analysis- Which is basically a semantic analysis that is usually employed
to make an inference from the text about the personality of the author.
And finally, contextual analysis- Where sequence in which concept appears together is examined.
The systematic appearance is not considered accidental, but it expresses the, a thinking
pattern of the author.
Summarizing the Content Analysis – Here the material is paraphrased, that is omitting
less relevant passages or those having the same meaning are reduced.
Thus, the material becomes more coherent, economical, and manageable.
It is a kind of editing of the material in the order to draw out its essence.
Explicable Content Analysis – This work in opposite way.
Here, statements which are puzzling, contradictory, or unclear are explained or clear clarified
by keeping in mind their context or by looking for clues in other parts of the text that
would help make their meaning clear.
Then structuring Content Analysis – Here the researcher looks for type or formal structure
in the material by applying categories that emerged at the stage of formulating the research
question itself, and organizing the material accordingly.
Thus, qualitative Content Analysis helps the researcher to reduce to manageable level large
masses of text using a uniform scheme of categories, which also helps the comparison of different
cases to which is applied throughout.
According to Berelson, following five procedures can be used to determine the objectivity in
Content Analysis.
First is the rule guide procedure.
It may be said that the objectivity in Content Analysis requires three criti… criteria.
What is important is not the categories developed by researcher for analyzing the content material
or the procedures adopted for placing a unit of communication in one or another category,
but to spell out the rules and methods used by the researcher so that it could be evaluated
how conclusion wo… were reached.
Secondly, systematic procedure- Besides the rule guiding procedure, which could be replicated
by other researchers adopted the adopting the systematic procedure also contributes
to the objectivity of the Content Analysis.
Then, quantitative description- Counting the frequencies appearing in different papers,
magazines and communications and comparing their validity is essential.
This is to assess the intensity of a particular variable.
Qualitative data becomes more valid when it is quantitatively assessed.
Focus on the qualitative analysis.
Merely concentrating on counting the frequency in Content Analysis will be missing the overall
sense of a body of communication.
Therefore, both quantitative and qualitative technique must be used in conjunction with one another.
Assessing only the manifest content of communication.
It has already been stated that besides the manifest content, there could be the latent
content too in which the researcher has to read between the lines and give meaning to
to it as he perceives it.
This affects the objectivity of the analysis.
It is, therefore, necessary that emphasis be given only what appears explicitly in communication.
This does not mean that the researcher will totally refrain from engaging in any interpretation
of the material studied.
Without interpretation, how could content be analyzed?
Then let’s discuss the advantage and disadvantages of the Content Analysis.
Ram Ahuja has given following advantages and disadvantages of Content Analysis.
One of the significant advantage of Content Analysis is that it is thoroughly unobtrusive
method that is it has no effect on the subject being studied.
In other methods like interview, observation, experiment, etcetera., the researcher is directly
involved with the person.
Content Analysis eliminates the source of responses bias that threatens research whenever
the respondents are directly questioned or observed.
It can be used as a reliable central technique in historical research concerned with the
particular period or with friends over time by studying people who are no longer available
to answer the questions.
Thirdly, it makes possible to a possible a variety of cross cultural studies that would
likely be unfeasible using the other methods.
And finally, it can be used to test preliminary ideas, hypothesis or theories prior to a more complete investigation.
It is powerful tool for evaluating personal social values.
People are more candid while writing down the thoughts than when confrontely it by interviewer
or a questionnaire.
Therefore, studying society where people are more literate, Content Analysis proves to
be a more reliable method of research.
Thit… met… This method is more useful when research budget is small and resources are limited.
It is easier to repeat the study through this method.
Repetition of study through other method may not be feasible either because the event under
study may no longer exist or because of cost, time, and money.
Since, Content Analysis is a heavily planned method, it lacks the spontaneity and unplanned
qualities of field research.
Determining validity is difficult.
For example, did the newspaper give the real values and feelings of the workers during the strike?
Probably not.
Some required documents may not be available to the researcher which may affect the conclusion
and it is susceptible to coder bias.
In this module we have understood the concept of Content Analysis.
It is a technique of interpreting various kinds of textual material to arrive at valid inference.
It analyzes various documents systematically and converts qualitative data into quantitative data.
We have also understood various types of Content Analysis and the various steps that are to
be taken during the process of Content Analysis.
Finally, we see some advantages and disadvantages of this, but this is the best method that
can be adopted for making any kind of qualitative research into a quantitative research and
it is nowadays used very much in various kinds of social sciences and communication sciences.

So, when, while talking about the measurement.
In our daily life, we only distinguish the characters and qualities of things and on
the basis of this we reject or choose certain things.
In day today affairs, it is necessary to make judgements upon qualities which cannot ordinarily
be differentiated from one another.
Propositions affirming qualitative differences are the first fruits of enquiry in any sciences,
it is more necessary to know the magnitude of such difference precisely.
This is required for the accuracy of statement and for discovering comprehensive principles
on the basis of which the subject matter can be known to be systematically related.
So, if we can know the degree of qualitative difference, we can not only rule out re...,
errors but can take up adequate measures to control the indicated changes as well if required.
In science, the accurate measurement of phenomena can give us great practical control over the
studied subject and can make possible the formulation of principles of law which can
make conformation or refutation unambiguous and clear.
So, quan… quantitative distinctions are substituted for qualitative ones, for theoretical
and practical reasons.
But many people without knowing the meaning and justification often use quantitative distinction.
For indicating the qualitative difference, the use of number requires a careful examination,
if we are to avoid absurdity and errors.
In order to deal with simple matters in our daily life and in sciences we need not resort
to complicated methods of registering differences.
Measurement, calculation and the often difficult deduction of consequences from premises would
not require the elaborate techniques which they in fact do require.
But sometimes a more intricate technique than a bare common sense method is required for
formulating, collecting and estimating evidence.
Investigations cannot, perhaps, be properly and fru… fruitfully carried on without the
introduction of quantitative methods.
Scientific methods, therefore, must study the foundation of applied mathematics.
Now, formal conditions of measurement.
For measuring the quality difference, the minimum requirement for employing numbers
may be stated in the following first two conditions.
In a set of bodies, given A one, A two, till A n, one must with reference to a certain
quality be able to arrange them in such a way that between any two bodies, one and only
one of the following relations hold, A one is greater than A two.
A one and A two, third A one is equal to A two.
On the basis of the signs, less than or greater than, the qualitative difference in bodies can be studied.
The relationship greater than must be asymmetrical.
Second, if A one is greater than A two and A two is greater than A three, then A one
is greater than A three, this is known as transitive condition.
The above two conditions are sufficient for the measurement of intensive qualities.
Example, density, temperature, etcetera.
For the measurement of extensive qualities they are necessary, but not sufficient.
Measurement of extensive qualities require some physical process of addition which should
have the following formula.
If A one plus A two is equal to A three, then A two plus A one is equal to A three.
Second, if X is equal to Y, then X plus Z is greater than Y, where the value of Z is
not zero or negative.
If A is equal to X, B is equal to Y, then A plus B is equal to X plus Y, A plus B plus
C is equal to A plus B plus C.
If these conditions are satisfied measurement becomes possible, with the fulfilment of first
two conditions it cannot be said that all the six conditions hold.
If the IQ of man is twice that of another, we only mean that the first man is higher
than the other on a specific scale of preference.
If it is absurd to say that the first has twice the intelligence or training because
operation for adding intelligence or training has been found out which is consistent with
the last four essential conditions.
Counting is another method which is also very helpful in measurement, counting is a method
of judgement of enumeration.
In actual counting, classification and analyses are required and enumeration of instances
is helpful for induction.
In order to more exactly enumerate the parts of which a whole is compose, we require weighing or measuring.
There is no essential difference between weighing and measuring.
In measurement, we make comparison, in measurement, we express the relation of the parts with
the some common standard or units.
Through measurement the things are reduced to common terms, it is really the business
of the physio-mathematical sciences.
Counting and measuring helps us in achieving the exact body of knowledge which we call science.
Counting gives us the exact knowledge and tries to avoid the vague ideas.
When we suspect significant connection between groups counted, counting is taken up.
Counting makes our ideas precise and it helps in distinguishing various features of different groups.
However, only a discrete group can be counted.
The number of individuals in a group represents an invariant property of the group from this
arise the great importance of counting as a method of clarifying our ideas.
Applied arithmetic is partly a collection of rules through which the invariant property
can be easily discovered.
Counting must be objective.
It is very difficult to count unless we know that what it is and we, that we are counting.
Where the difference between the groups is not distinct, the interpretation of the number
obtained by counting is uncertain.
Thus, it is not easy to draw the line of a demarcation between skilled and unskilled workers.
In a social science research, the information which we get from the questionnaires is not
always reliable, clear or distinct.
The answer may also be affected by ignorance, dishonesty and vanity.
However, if the groups are very large in number or difficult to examine exhaustively, then
enumeration is not under taken.
In such cases, sampling method is practised.
Measurement of qualitative data.
In social sciences, we face problems which are subjective and qualitative.
For example, skills, values, attitude, utilities, etcetera.
Qualitative data cannot be quantitative or objectively measured, but qualitative data
cease to be of much scientific value unless such datas are quantified.
Professor Menegazzi pleaded for great attention to the qualitative aspect of social life to
the synthetic or aggregative approach to the problem.
It is to some extent possible to measure the intensive and extensive qualities.
The qualitative data can be translated more or less satisfactorily to quantitative terms.
The technique of such translation has several steps, descriptions, categorization and determination
of quantitative incidents and interrelations.
These steps are generally known as “content analysis”.
About the content analysis you will be dealing in detail in a separate module, but just to
explain you the concept, we can go very briefly about the measurement of intensive qualities
and extensive qualities.
There are some things like hardness, density, intelligence, etcetera which have non additive qualities.
These qualities are called intensive qualities, these qualities can be measured only in the
sense that the different degrees of the quality may be arranged in a series.
In this case, questions regarding how much or how many times are meaningless.
The qualities cannot be added.
Characters of things cannot always be distinguish because they form a continuous series with one another.
Sometime it is sufficient to know that one piece of wood is harder than the other one.
But if we want to know how hard one piece of wood is as compared to the other piece.
Then we require very certain and uniform criteria, the varying degrees of qualities can be indicated
be assigning different numbers.
For example, IQ of A is fifty and IQ of B is hundred, but in this way, we cannot get
the correct measurement, it should not be considered that measurement requires nothing
more than the assigning of numbers.
But by assigning numbers, we can only indicate the degree of intensity that is which one
is higher and which one is lower.
In the above example, it should not be interpreted that B is not possible in the case of an intensive
quality by the assigned numbers.
All qualities cannot be measured in the same senses.
Numbers have three uses to perform, one, as identification marks or tags.
Two, as signs to indicate the position of the degree of quality in a series of degrees.
Three, as a sign indicating qualitative relationship between different qualities.
Talking about the first, sometimes number can be used to indicate names or identity.
Example, convict number hundred, convict number two hundred, etcetera.
Numbers are more convenient than verbal names for various reason.
But the assigning of the numbers does not indicate any relationship between the object
number co… corresponding to the numerical relationship between the assigned numbers.
Thus, convict number hundred is not twice as criminal as convict number fifty.
And talking about the second point, a scientifically more important use of number is when the order
of number, numerical magnitude is the same as the order of the position of the character
studied in a scale of or ladder of qualities.
Intensive quality can be arranged as a relation property.
For example, if any, if by experiment, we can show that diamond is harder than glass
and glass is harder than pinewood, then we can show that diamond is harder than pinewood.
Here, relationship properly is said to be asymmetrical, if A one is harder than A two,
but A two is not harder than A one.
By arranging the bodies in a line, linear series, according to quality, we can get a
scale or ladder of this quality.
If the relation of magnitude of numbers is asymmetrical and done in the preparation of
the index numbers, this will increase the validity of the scale.
However, in social qualitative measurement, absolute reliability and perfect validity
should not be expected.
There are some other requirements of measurement.
For effective measurement, the unit of enumeration must be determined, either a single respondent
or a part of the content may be taken as the unit of enumeration.
It is better to have the same system of categories, same units of enumeration and the same operational
definitions in order to know quantitatively the degree of deviation it is very necessary
to have certain norms.
The tools of measurement of qualitative data can be applied if the following steps are
taken into consideration.
First, this, the data should be specified and a matrix should be developed within attitude
scale and scoring devices.
Second, the coded data should be properly tabulated.
Third, a list of variables in terms of which the content is to be cod… coded, coded should be prepared.
Forth, the categories of each variable should be filled in.
The categories should not be either too broad or too narrow.
Fifth, proper definitions and procedures should be used.
Sixth, the outline of the analysis maybe prepared in the fashion of a pilot survey.
The success of a measurement depends on the theoretical procedure and on the codes.
The method of measurement should be as far as possible, accurate, and the coders must
be neutral, alert, trained and painstaking.
Now, as we have understood the concept of measurement and what is to be kept in mind
while measuring intensive and extensive da… data.
We need to understand scaling now.
So, let's now understand the concept of scaling because to measure anything we need scaling.
In social research, it is very essential to make distinction of degree rather than quality.
The technique of registering difference in degree may be of two type.
Firstly, one can make a judgement about some characteristics of an individual and place
him on a scale which is meant for measuring the charac..., that characteristic.
A scale is a continuum from highest to lowest point, and has intermediate points in between
these two extremes.
The techniques may consist of questionnaire prepared in such a fashion that the score
of individual’s response give him a particular place on the scale.
A scale is a method of measurement.
In social research, attitude, behaviour and other qualitative characteristics are measured
by means of different scales.
The scalability of a phenomenon depends on its continuum.
The various factors of the phenomenon must be logically interrelated and should be capable
of continued measurement.
A scale must be reliable.
The following methods that we have already discussed in our module on reliability and
validity can be used to test the reliability of a scale.
Like, first is retest method - According to this method the same scale is applied twice
to the same population for the same objective and if the two re… results are similar,
the scale is regarded as reliable.
For this matter, the test can be done on two similar groups also.
Second is multiple forms - According to this technique two types of scales are constructed
and they are applied to the same population.
In case the two results are more or less similar, the scales maybe regarded as reliable.
Third is split half method - In this method, the scale may be divided into two equal parts.
The, then each part is taken as a whole that is as a complete scale and measurement is made separately.
The correlation between the two scores obtained this way is estimated and the degree of correlation
is high, the scale may be regarded as reliable.
In a scale, proper weightage should be given to the various points provided the various
items are disproportionate or unequal.
However, a scale must be valid, that is it should correctly measure things.
There are at least four different cri… criterias of measuring validity.
First is logical validity - The scale must confirm to the common sense reasoning and
therefore is a partly subjective, but still in some very clear cases this crude method
may be helpful.
Second is unknown groups - In this method, the scale is applied to the known category
of people, then the result obtained is compared with the known facts.
If they are similar the scale is considered to be valid.
Third, opinion of Jury - This method depends on the considered opinion of many Juries,
who will have no bias.
If several Juries give the same opinion, the method of measurement may be considered as valid.
Fourth, independent method - A thing maybe separately measured separately with the separate
independent criteria and if the result are similar, the scale may be said to be valid.
However, these methods of testing and validity of a scale are not free from flaws, thus,
they have the, to be used very cautiously.
The scaling method is used when the researcher wishes to utilise simultaneously a number
of observation on a respondent.
A number of difficulties maybe encountered by the researcher in arranging the meaningful
responses logically and incorporating the responses in the analysis of attitude.
Re… reasonable reliability is one attribute required for a scale, validity is another,
but they are related matters, it is very difficult to objectively interpret validity.
Where a scale is developed on the basis of objective criteria, the validity can be judged
by testing the criteria itself.
The validity maybe for the future that is predictive validity or for the present that
is concurrent validity.
So, there is need for the scaling technique and the, when and where to use.
The difficulty of applying rigorous and objective test in attitude measurement arises from the
fact that such measurement is indirect for attitude is inferred from verbal responses.
An attitude is an abstraction and as such it is almost impossible to assess its validity directly.
A scale is applicable to a particular group or class, it is not universally applicable.
Human behaviour is heterogeneous and unpredictable.
Social phenomena are complex and qualitative in nature.
The concepts themselves are not defined properly, thus qua… quantitative measurement is a baffling affair.
There is no universally valid or recognized measuring rod.
This measuring unit itself may be variable.
A valid scale in the ultimate analysis is also a subjective consideration, but the most
baffling problem is the criteria of validity.
Human behaviour is fle… flexible and variable.
Whatever attitude is expressed at a point of time may not be taken as a reliable, even
a valid scale may not remain valid during the period of analysis.
There is often a dichotomy between the express, expressed attitude and overt action.
The intelligibility of social phenomena is an obstacle to scale construction.
The scores of the scale cannot be correctly tested because of the intangi… intangibility
of the social phenomena.
The social phenomena cannot be experimental in a controlled way.
The phenomena may be individual, private or esoteric.
Therefore, they cannot be properly washed and evaluated.
Thus, scale cannot measure all the causative variables involved.
Despite these limitations, the scaling technique can be improved to measure the social phenomena
more or less accurately.
The sociometric type of analysis is a case in point.
Chi..., let's now understand the different types of scales.
There are the following four main types of scales- nominal, ordinal, interval and ratio scales.
We will be discussing each of it, it in detail.
A nominal scale - A nominal scale consists of two or more named category into which individual
objects or responses are classified.
In a nominal scale, it is possible to distinguish two or more categories relating to the specified attributes.
The members of these categories differ with respect to the specified attribute which is the measure.
It is a simple method of classification rather than arrangement along a continuum.
The question of dimensions is not important in this type of scale.
If desired, the difference, different groups maybe numbered.
Classification of individual according to religion is an example of nominal scale.
Then comes the Ordinal Scale - In this type of scale numbers, example one, two, three,
etcetera are assigned to indicate the only the relative position.
The scale purpose is to give ranks to the individual along the specified continuum,
but such a scale like the nominal scale does not measure the distance between the positions.
In this scale, it is very essential to determine the order of position in terms of more or
less, better or worse and so on in relation to the attribute which is being measured.
For instance, X is regarded as more beautiful than Y.
The ordinal scale can indicate only a person’s relative position, but it cannot cardinally
measure the difference between the persons.
One can say, for example, X is greater than Y, but he cannot say by how much.
Third is Interval or Cardinal Scale - This scale has equal units of measurement.
Thus, it is possible to interpret not only the order of scale scores but also the distance between them.
Thus, two persons with scale position four and five are as far apart as two person with
scale position of ten and eleven.
A person having the score of ten cannot be regarded as two times higher or better than
a person whose score is five.
When we talk of ten degree Celsius rise in temperature, it does not mean that it is twice
as hot as five degree Celsius.
In an Interval scale, the intervals remains the equal.
Then comes the Ratio Scale - This scale incorporates the properties of an interval scale together
with the fixed origin or zero point.
Weight, length and time are obvious example of ratio scales.
On the basis of ratio scale, one can compare both difference in scores and the relative
magnitude of score.
For instance, the difference between ten and fifteen minutes is the same as the difference
between fifteen and twenty minutes and ten minutes is twice as long as five minutes.
Then comes the Rating Scale - Another important type of scale which is, which is often used
in everyday life.
The rating, ranking and attitude scales have one common method of assigning numerical position
to individual, so that variation in degree may be asserted.
While preparing a rating scale, the rater places the individual at a particular point
along a continuum and a numerical value is attached to this point.
The following are the main types of rating scales used in research.
First is Graphic Rating Scale - This is most common used rating scale.
Under this method, the rater indicates his rating by putting a tick at the point selected
by him on the line chosen or measuring an attribute any specific point from lowest to the highest.
The different scale point may indicate brief descri… descriptions about attitude level.
This may help the rater to indicate his own preferences.
The following is the example of a graphic rating scale.
We can, from one to five we can place it like this, one means he feels strongly for the
students management.
Two means generally feels the necessity for participation, three means part, partly favours
or partly disfavours.
Forth means generally feels no necessity of participation, five means feels no necessity
of participation at all.
The rater may mark anyone of five points to indicate his own rating and thereby may reveal his preferences.
The graphic rating scale is a very simple and convenient device to use, it ensures a
fair level of fineness of scoring.
In the rating scale, vague, unlikely and extreme statement should be avoided.
Secondly, as far as possible the description statement should closely correspond to the
numerical points on the scale.
Then it is the Itemized Rating Scale - Itemized Rating Scale is also known as specific category
scale or numerical scale.
In this scale, the rater has to select one of the limited number of categories that are
in order in terms of their scale position.
Generally, in such a scale, there are five or seven categories.
Barker, Dembo and Lewin prepared a seven point scale for rating constructiveness among children.
As a general rule, the more clear defined the categories, the more reliable becomes the rating.
The number of sepc… specification, however, depends on the nature of the research problem.
